steps: Rinse the duck thoroughly, inside and out, and pat it completely dry with paper towels. Remove any excess fat, especially around the cavity.
Place the duck on a wire rack set in a clean sink.

Bring 3 cups of water to a rolling boil in a large saucepan. Carefully pour half of the boiling water over the duck, ensuring all skin is scalded. Flip the duck and pour the remaining boiling water over the other side. This helps to tighten the skin.
Pat the duck dry again and use a knife tip or skewer to poke small holes all over the skin, being careful not to pierce the meat.
In a small bowl, mix the baking soda and kosher salt. Sprinkle this mixture evenly over all sides of the duck.

In a small saucepan, combine the honey, maple syrup, Shaoxing rice wine, and ¼ cup water. Bring to a simmer over medium-high heat and cook for 8-10 minutes until the mixture thickens slightly into a syrup. Remove from heat and let it cool to room temperature.
In another small saucepan, combine the hoisin sauce, cinnamon, ginger, brown sugar, red wine vinegar, sesame oil, and star anise. Bring to a boil, then remove from heat and let cool.
Liberally brush the duck all over with the cooled honey-maple syrup glaze. Then, brush with the hoisin-spice glaze.

Transfer the duck, still on the wire rack, to a baking pan. Refrigerate uncovered for at least 8 hours, or preferably overnight (up to 24 hours). This crucial step allows the skin to dry out, which is essential for crispiness. If possible, ensure good air circulation around the duck.
Remove the duck from the refrigerator 30 minutes before cooking to bring it closer to room temperature.
Preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C).
Place the duck, breast-side up, on the wire rack in the roasting pan. You can add 1-2 inches of water to the bottom of the roasting pan to catch fat and prevent splattering.

Roast for approximately 80 minutes, or until the skin is dark brown and crispy. The internal temperature in the thickest part of the breast should reach 160°F (71°C). If the skin starts to get too dark, loosely tent the duck with aluminum foil.
Once cooked, remove the duck from the oven and loosely tent it with foil. Let it rest on a cutting board for 20-30 minutes. This allows the juices to redistribute, resulting in more tender meat.
While the duck is resting, warm the Mandarin pancakes (you can wrap them in moist paper towels and microwave for 15 seconds). Slice the cucumber and scallions into thin slivers.
Carve the duck into thin slices, ensuring each piece has some crispy skin. Arrange the duck on a platter with the pancakes, hoisin sauce, cucumber, and scallions.
Diners can assemble their own Peking Duck wraps by spreading hoisin sauce on a pancake, adding duck meat and skin, and topping with cucumber and scallions.

drink.description: Beijing’s classic everyday baijiu, traditionally drunk neat with food and bold toasts.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with savory dishes.

ingredients: 2 tbsp neutral oil (for brushing between pancakes)
steps: Mix flour with boiling water, stirring with chopsticks/spoon until shaggy. Add room-temp water as needed to form a soft dough.
Knead 5–8 minutes until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Divide into 12–16 pieces. Roll one piece into a small circle, brush lightly with oil, top with a second circle, and roll the pair together thin (about 6 inches).
Cook in a dry skillet over medium heat 30–60 seconds per side until pale golden spots appear (don’t brown heavily).
While warm, peel the two pancakes apart. Keep covered with a towel to stay soft.

Tianjin.description: Jianbing has a history of over 2,000 years, traced back to the Three Kingdoms period in Shandong province. Legend says chancellor Zhuge Liang invented it to feed his soldiers who had lost their woks. The Tianjin style became famous and was first documented in a newspaper in 1933. Jianbing Guozi is a popular breakfast street food. The Tianjin style is famous for its use of mung bean flour for a softer crepe and is typically filled with youtiao (fried dough sticks), whereas the original Shandong version uses crispier crackers. In 2017, the skill of making Tianjin Jianbing Guozi was listed as a municipal intangible cultural heritage.
steps: Prepare the Batter: Combine warm water, mung bean powder, soybean powder, and all-purpose flour in a mixing bowl. Whisk until smooth. The batter should be thick but runny. Let it rest for at least 20 minutes.

Cook the Crepe: Heat a griddle or a non-stick pan over medium heat with a thin layer of oil. Pour about a cup of batter onto the griddle and spread it evenly in a circular motion to form a thin crepe.
Add Egg and Toppings: Crack the eggs directly onto the crepe and spread them evenly. Before the eggs are fully cooked, sprinkle with chopped green onions and sesame seeds.
Assemble the Jianbing: After about 10 seconds, flip the crepe. Brush the cooked surface with your sweet bean paste or hoisin sauce.
Place the crispy crackers or youtiao in the middle.
Fold the two sides of the crepe over the filling, then fold it in half again to create a rectangle.
Serve immediately while hot and crispy.
ingredients: ¼ cup sweet bean paste or hoisin sauce
2 crispy fried crackers or 1 youtiao (fried dough stick)

drink.dish: Meigui Lu Jiu (玫瑰露酒) – Rose-Infused Spirit
drink.description: A fragrant rose-flavored spirit associated with Tianjin (often used both as a drink and in cooking). This home-style infusion mimics the traditional profile.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) baijiu or neutral spirit (vodka works)
steps: Combine spirit, rose petals, and sugar in a clean jar (add orange peel if using).
Seal and steep 2–5 days at room temperature, shaking once daily, until fragrant.
Strain through a fine sieve/coffee filter.
Serve in small glasses, neat or over a single cube of ice.

Sichuan.description: Created in the late 19th century by a woman named Chen Ma Po (Pock-marked Grandma Chen) in Chengdu. It began as a humble dish for laborers but became the definitive example of Sichuan's 'Mala' (numbing and spicy) flavor profile. The soul of this dish is 'Pixian Doubanjiang', a fermented broad bean paste with chilies from Pixian county. Authentic versions must include Sichuan peppercorns for the signature tingling sensation.
ingredients: 1 block Soft or Silken Tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
1 tbsp Fermented Black Beans (Douchi), rinsed and minced
1 tsp Sichuan Peppercorns, toasted and ground
1 tbsp Cornstarch mixed with 2 tbsp water (slurry)
steps: Blanch tofu cubes in boiling salted water for 2 minutes. Drain carefully.
Fry ground meat in a wok until crispy. Push to the side.
Add doubanjiang to the oil and fry until the oil turns red. Add garlic, ginger, and black beans.
Pour in stock, soy sauce, and sugar. Bring to a boil.
Gently slide in the tofu. Simmer for 3-5 minutes (do not stir vigorously, shake the pan).
Stir in the cornstarch slurry to thicken the sauce.
Finish with chili oil and a generous dusting of ground Sichuan peppercorns and scallions.

drink.description: One of Sichuan’s most famous baijius, traditionally enjoyed neat in small pours at celebrations and formal meals.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Wuliangye baijiu (or another Sichuan strong-aroma baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip (or ‘ganbei’) alongside rich, spicy food.

preliminary_steps.item: Pixian Doubanjiang (Fermented Chili Bean Paste) – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: Pixian doubanjiang (recommended to purchase)
steps: Pixian doubanjiang is a long-fermented chili broad-bean paste; the traditional process takes months.
For authenticity, purchase a reputable Pixian doubanjiang and use as directed in the recipe.
If the recipe calls for cooking it, stir-fry it briefly in oil to ‘bloom’ the flavor before adding liquids.

Guangdong.description: A staple of Cantonese 'Siu Mei' (roasted meats). The name 'Char Siu' literally means 'fork roasted', referring to the traditional method of skewering seasoned pork with long forks and roasting it over an open fire. The signature red ring and glossy sheen come from a glaze of maltose and sometimes red fermented bean curd (Nam Yu). It is often hung in restaurant windows and is considered one of the four 'Kings' of Cantonese roasting.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Shoulder or Pork Butt (cut into long strips)
Marinade: 2 tbsp Hoisin Sauce, 2 tbsp Oyster Sauce, 2 tbsp Soy Sauce
1 tbsp Red Fermented Bean Curd (Nam Yu) + sauce
steps: Cut pork into strips about 2 inches thick. Pierce with a fork to help absorption.
Mix all marinade ingredients. Rub over pork and marinate overnight in the fridge.
Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Place pork on a rack over a roasting pan filled with a little water.
Roast for 20 minutes. Flip and roast for another 20 minutes.
Brush generously with maltose/honey glaze. Roast for 10 more minutes until charred and glossy.
Rest for 10 minutes before slicing against the grain.

drink.dish: Liang Cha (凉茶) – Cantonese Herbal Tea
drink.description: A traditional Cantonese “cooling” herbal tea, commonly sipped for balance in hot/humid weather.
ingredients: 1 tbsp dried prunella (xia ku cao), optional but traditional
1–2 thin slices dried licorice root (or 1 tsp licorice tea)
Rock sugar or honey, to taste (optional)
steps: Bring water to a simmer. Add herbs and gently simmer 10–15 minutes.
Turn off heat, cover, and steep 10 minutes.
Strain. Sweeten lightly if you want.
Serve warm or chilled over ice.

preliminary_steps.item: Red Fermented Bean Curd (Nam Yu) Sauce – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: red fermented bean curd (nam yu) plus its brine (recommended to purchase)
steps: Red fermented bean curd is a fermented product; for authenticity, purchase it.
Mash 1–2 cubes with 1–2 tbsp of its brine to form a smooth sauce before adding to the dish.

Hunan.dish: Mao Shi Hong Shao Rou (Mao's Red Braised Pork)
Hunan.description: Named after Chairman Mao Zedong, a Hunan native who famously loved this dish. Unlike other braised pork recipes, the Hunan style traditionally uses caramelized sugar rather than soy sauce for its deep red color. Hunan cuisine, or Xiang cuisine, is known for its 'gan la' (dry heat) and use of fresh chilies, garlic, and shallots. This dish balances savory, sweet, and spicy notes with melt-in-your-mouth pork belly.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Belly, cut into 1.5-inch cubes
steps: Blanch pork belly cubes in boiling water for 3 minutes. Drain and pat dry.
In a wok, heat oil and melt rock sugar on low heat until it turns amber and bubbly (caramelization).
Immediately add pork and coat in the caramel. Fry until slightly browned.
Add ginger, star anise, cinnamon, and dried chilies. Stir fry for 1 minute.
Add Shaoxing wine and enough hot water to just cover the pork.
Add scallions. Cover and simmer on low heat for 60-90 minutes until pork is fork-tender.
Remove lid, turn up heat, and reduce the sauce until it is thick, sticky, and glossy.

drink.description: A well-known Hunan baijiu, typically served neat for toasts and banquets.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Jiugui-style baijiu (or another Hunan baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with spicy dishes.

Jiangsu.description: Dating back to the Sui Dynasty, these giant meatballs stewed with napa cabbage leaves resemble a lion's head with a mane. It is a classic Huaiyang dish, known for meticulous cutting and soft textures. The secret to the texture is chopping the meat by hand (not grinding) and mixing in water and fat to ensure the meatballs are fluffy and tender, not dense.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Cornstarch, 1 tbsp Shaoxing Wine, 1 tsp Sugar
steps: Combine pork, water chestnuts, ginger, scallions, egg, cornstarch, wine, and sugar.
Stir vigorously in one direction for 5 minutes until the mixture becomes sticky and paste-like.
Form into 4 large meatballs. Fry in oil until golden brown (to set shape) or steam them.
In a clay pot or heavy pan, line the bottom with cabbage leaves.
Place meatballs on top. Cover with more cabbage.
Pour in chicken stock and soy sauce. Bring to a boil.
Simmer covered on low heat for 2 hours until the meatballs are incredibly soft and the cabbage is melting.

drink.description: A signature spirit from Jiangsu, traditionally served neat in small cups at meals and celebrations.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Yanghe Daqu baijiu (or another Jiangsu baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with food.

Zhejiang.description: Named after the famous Song Dynasty poet and statesman Su Dongpo. Legend says he improved the traditional pork dish by slow-braising it in yellow wine while distracted by a game of chess. The pork is traditionally cut into 2-inch squares, tied with twine to hold its shape, and cooked with equal parts wine and soy sauce. It should be tender enough to be cut with chopsticks.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Belly (skin-on), cut into 2-inch squares
steps: Blanch pork squares in boiling water for 5 minutes. Clean any scum.
Tie each square with cooking twine to keep the layers together.
In a clay pot or heavy Dutch oven, create a bed of whole scallions and ginger slices at the bottom (prevents burning).
Place pork skin-side down on the aromatics.
Add rock sugar, soy sauces, and Shaoxing wine. Add water if needed to just cover.
Bring to a boil, then cover and simmer on very low heat for 2 hours.
Flip pork skin-side up. Simmer for another 30 minutes.
Optional: Steam the pork in a bowl for 30 minutes for extra tenderness and to remove excess grease.

drink.dish: Longjing Tea (龙井茶) – Dragon Well Green Tea
drink.description: Zhejiang’s most iconic green tea. The brewing is simple but precise: cooler water, short steeps, and fragrant leaves.
steps: Warm your cup or small teapot with hot water; discard.
Add tea leaves. Pour in 175°F/80°C water.
Steep 1–2 minutes, then drink; refill and re-steep 2–3 more times, shortening steeps as the leaves open.

Fujian.description: A classic dish from Fuzhou, the capital of Fujian. Despite the name, it doesn't always contain lychees; the pork is cross-hatched and curled during frying to resemble the bumpy skin of a lychee fruit. It is known for its bright red color and sweet-and-sour flavor profile, typical of Min cuisine.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Red Yeast Rice powder (for color)
Sauce: 2 tbsp Ketchup, 1 tbsp Sugar, 1 tbsp White Vinegar, 1 tsp Soy Sauce
steps: Cut pork into cubes. Score the surface of each cube in a cross-hatch pattern (this makes it curl).
Marinate pork with salt, pepper, and red yeast powder.
Coat pork and water chestnuts in cornstarch batter.
Deep fry pork until it curls and is crispy. Fry water chestnuts briefly.
In a wok, sauté garlic and scallions. Add sauce ingredients and thicken with starch slurry.
Toss the fried pork and water chestnuts in the sauce until coated.

drink.description: A celebrated Fujian oolong, often brewed gongfu-style for multiple short, aromatic infusions.
steps: Warm cup/teapot, then add tea leaves.
Pour 195°F/90°C water over leaves and steep 30–60 seconds for the first infusion.
Pour out completely and drink. Re-steep several times, adding 10–15 seconds each round.

Shandong.description: Shandong (Lu) cuisine is the oldest of the Four Great Traditions and influenced imperial cooking. This dish features a whole carp fried into a U-shape. The sauce is a perfect balance of sweet and sour, traditionally made without ketchup.
steps: Score the fish deeply on both sides at intervals, cutting towards the head.
Lift the fish by the tail and shake to open the cuts. Dust completely with cornstarch.
Deep fry the fish. Hold the tail and head to curve the body into a U-shape in the oil until set.
Fry until golden and crispy.
Make the sauce: Sauté aromatics, add vinegar, sugar, soy sauce, and water. Thicken with starch.
Pour the hot sauce over the crispy fish immediately before serving.

drink.description: Qingdao’s famous lager from Shandong—crisp, light, and commonly enjoyed with seafood.
steps: Chill well.
Pour into a glass (optional) and serve immediately.

Yunnan.description: Yunnan's most famous dish. Legend says a scholar's wife invented it to keep his lunch warm by covering the broth with a layer of chicken oil. It is served as a boiling hot bowl of broth with separate plates of raw ingredients that cook instantly when added.
ingredients: Raw ingredients (sliced paper-thin): Pork loin, Fish fillet, Ham
Vegetables: Bean sprouts, Chives, Pea tips
steps: Simmer chicken for hours to make a rich, golden broth. Do not skim all the fat (it insulates the heat).
Boil noodles separately and place in a bowl.
Slice meats paper-thin (crucial for cooking safety).
To serve: Bring the broth to a rolling boil in a heated stone bowl.
Add the raw meats and eggs first to cook them. Then add vegetables and noodles.
Mix and enjoy immediately.

drink.description: Yunnan’s iconic fermented tea, brewed with near-boiling water for earthy, layered infusions.
ingredients: 2 tsp Pu'er tea (loose or a small chunk of a cake)
steps: Rinse the leaves quickly with hot water (5 seconds) and discard the rinse.
Pour in hot water and steep 20–40 seconds for the first infusion.
Pour out completely and drink. Re-steep multiple times, gradually increasing steep time.

Shaanxi.description: Often called the 'Chinese Hamburger', this street food dates back to the Qin Dynasty. It consists of chopped, stewed pork belly stuffed into a 'mo', a type of flatbread that is crispy on the outside and soft inside. The meat is spiced with over 20 aromatics.
ingredients: Master Stock: Ginger, Scallions, Star Anise, Cinnamon, Cloves, Fennel, Cardamom
Mo Bread: 2 cups Flour, Yeast, Water
steps: Cut pork into chunks. Blanch in boiling water.
Simmer pork in the master stock with spices and soy sauce for 2-3 hours until it falls apart.
Make the dough. Roll into disks and pan-fry without oil until baked through.
Chop the pork finely with a cleaver, mixing in some of the rich stock and chopped green peppers (optional).
Slice the bun open and stuff generously with the meat.

drink.description: A well-known baijiu style associated with Shaanxi, served neat for toasts and banquets.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Xifengjiu (or another Shaanxi baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with food.

Shanghai.description: The famous soup dumpling. The magic lies in the 'aspic'—a solidified meat broth jelly that is wrapped inside the dumpling. When steamed, the jelly melts into a rich, savory soup encased in the delicate dough skin.
ingredients: Filling: 1 lb Ground Pork, 1 tbsp Ginger, 1 tbsp Shaoxing Wine
Aspic: 1 lb Pork Skin/Trotters, Water, Ginger, Scallions (boiled down and chilled into jelly)
Dough: 2 cups All-purpose flour, Hot water
Black Vinegar and Ginger slivers (for dipping)
steps: Make Aspic: Boil pork skin/trotters for hours. Strain liquid and chill until it turns into a firm jelly. Dice the jelly.
Mix ground pork with ginger, wine, and seasonings. Fold in the diced jelly cubes.
Make dough with hot water (hot water dough is softer). Roll into thin circles.
Place filling in center. Pleat the edges (traditionally 18 pleats) and seal the top.
Steam in a bamboo steamer lined with cabbage or paper for 8-10 minutes.
Eat carefully: Bite a small hole, sip the soup, then eat the dumpling.

drink.dish: Shikumen Huangjiu (石库门黄酒) – Shanghai Rice Wine
drink.description: Shanghai is known for huangjiu (yellow rice wine) traditions; Shikumen-style huangjiu is typically served slightly warmed or at cool room temperature.
ingredients: 5 oz (150 ml) huangjiu (Shanghai/Shikumen style if available)
steps: Serve at cool room temperature, or gently warm (do not boil) for a softer aroma.
Pour into small cups and sip alongside food.

Chongqing.description: A signature dish of Chongqing cuisine, famous for its numbing heat. It consists of bite-sized pieces of chicken deep-fried until crispy, then stir-fried with a mountain of dried red chilies and Sichuan peppercorns. The experience is often described as 'finding chicken in chili'.
ingredients: 2 cups Dried Red Chilies (cut in half)
steps: Marinate chopped chicken with salt, wine, and soy sauce for 20 mins.
Deep fry chicken in hot oil until golden and crispy (twice-fried is best). Drain.
Leave a little oil in the wok. Fry ginger, garlic, and peppercorns until fragrant.
Add the dried chilies. Fry briefly (don't burn).
Toss in the fried chicken. Stir fry rapidly to coat with spice aroma.
Sprinkle with sugar, sesame seeds, and scallions. Serve immediately.

drink.description: A modern, lighter-style baijiu brand closely associated with Chongqing, commonly enjoyed neat or as a simple mixer.
ingredients: Optional: 4 oz (120 ml) chilled soda water + lemon wedge (highball)
steps: Traditional: serve neat in small cups at cool room temperature and sip or toast.
Highball option: fill a tall glass with ice, add baijiu, top with soda, and squeeze in lemon.

Guangxi.description: The pride of Guilin. These thick, round rice noodles are traditionally eaten 'dry' with a splash of brine/gravy, topped with crispy roasted pork or beef slices, fried peanuts, and sour pickled beans/bamboo shoots.
ingredients: 1 lb Fresh Rice Noodles (thick round type)
Brine/Gravy: Star anise, cinnamon, fennel, licorice, ginger, soy sauce, rock sugar (simmered for hours)
Toppings: Fried Peanuts, Pickled Long Beans (Sour beans), Pickled Bamboo Shoots
Meat: Crispy Pork Belly or Braised Beef slices
steps: Prepare the brine by simmering spices and soy sauce until concentrated.
Blanch the rice noodles in boiling water for 10-20 seconds. Shake dry.
Place noodles in a bowl. Add a ladle of the brine.
Top generously with meat slices, fried peanuts, pickled beans, and bamboo shoots.
Add chili oil and herbs. Toss well before eating.

drink.description: A classic rice spirit from Guilin in Guangxi, usually enjoyed neat in small pours.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Guilin Sanhua jiu (rice spirit)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Sip slowly; pair with savory snacks.

ingredients: 2 cups long beans, cut into 2–3 inch pieces
steps: Bring vinegar, water, sugar, and salt to a simmer to dissolve; cool slightly.
Pack beans (and garlic/chili if using) into a jar; pour brine over to cover.
Chill at least 24 hours. Keeps 2–3 weeks refrigerated.

Hainan.description: The ancestor of the famous Singaporean Hainanese Chicken Rice. Originating from Wenchang city, this dish uses free-range chickens fed on coconut and banyan seeds. The chicken is poached simply to highlight its natural flavor and served with a ginger-garlic dip.
ingredients: Dip: Minced Ginger, Minced Garlic, Salt, Hot Oil, Lime juice
steps: Rub chicken with salt. Stuff cavity with ginger and scallions.
Poach in sub-boiling water for 40-50 mins (skin should be intact). Plunge into ice water to make skin jelly-like.
Make the dip: Mix minced ginger, garlic, and salt. Pour sizzling hot oil over it.
Chop chicken bone-in.
Serve with 'oily rice' cooked with chicken fat and broth.

drink.description: Hainan is famed for coconuts; fresh coconut water (or lightly sweetened coconut milk drink) is a classic local refreshment.
ingredients: 1 fresh young coconut (or 8–12 oz / 240–355 ml bottled coconut water)
Optional: pinch of salt or squeeze of lime
steps: Chill coconut or coconut water well.
Serve straight, optionally with a pinch of salt or a squeeze of lime.

Xinjiang.description: A hearty, spicy stew that reflects the fusion of cultures in Xinjiang. Chunks of chicken and potatoes are braised in a rich, spicy sauce often flavored with beer. It is always served on a massive communal plate, with wide hand-pulled noodles added at the end.
ingredients: Sauce: 2 tbsp Doubanjiang (Bean Paste), Dried Chilies, Star Anise, Cumin, 1 can Beer
steps: Caramelize sugar in oil until brown. Add chicken and coat in the color.
Add dried chilies, star anise, ginger, and garlic. Stir fry.
Add doubanjiang and beer. Bring to boil.
Add potatoes. Simmer until chicken and potatoes are tender (20 mins).
Add peppers and onions. Cook 5 more mins.
Serve on a huge plate. Mix boiled wide noodles into the sauce.

drink.description: A traditional Uyghur grape wine from Xinjiang, typically enjoyed as a sweet, fragrant local pour.
ingredients: 5 oz (150 ml) Musallas (or another Xinjiang-style sweet grape wine)
steps: Serve at cellar temperature or lightly chilled.
Pour into small wine glasses and sip slowly.

preliminary_steps.item: Pixian Doubanjiang (Fermented Chili Bean Paste) – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: Pixian doubanjiang (recommended to purchase)
steps: Pixian doubanjiang is a long-fermented chili broad-bean paste; the traditional process takes months.
For authenticity, purchase a reputable Pixian doubanjiang and use as directed in the recipe.
If the recipe calls for cooking it, stir-fry it briefly in oil to ‘bloom’ the flavor before adding liquids.

Hubei.description: The quintessential breakfast of Wuhan. Alkaline noodles are cooked, oiled, and then tossed in a rich, thick sauce made of sesame paste (tahini), soy sauce, and chili oil. It is 'dry' because there is no soup, just the creamy, nutty coating.
ingredients: Sauce: 4 tbsp Chinese Sesame Paste, 1 tbsp Soy Sauce, 1 tbsp Dark Soy Sauce, 1 tsp Sugar
Toppings: Pickled Radish (finely chopped), Pickled Long Beans, Scallions, Garlic water
steps: Dilute sesame paste with a little sesame oil until smooth and pourable.
Boil noodles until al dente. Drain well.
Toss noodles with a little oil to prevent sticking if not serving immediately.
To serve: Place hot noodles in a bowl.
Pour over the sesame sauce, soy sauces, and garlic water.
Top with pickled radish, beans, and chili oil. Mix thoroughly until noodles are coated in brown paste.

drink.dish: Enshi Yulu Green Tea (恩施玉露)
drink.description: A famed Hubei green tea, known for a clean sweetness; brew with cooler water to avoid bitterness.
steps: Warm cup/teapot; discard water.
Add tea leaves and pour 175°F/80°C water over them.
Steep 1–2 minutes; drink and re-steep 2–3 times.

ingredients: 2 cups long beans, cut into 2–3 inch pieces
steps: Bring vinegar, water, sugar, and salt to a simmer to dissolve; cool slightly.
Pack beans (and garlic/chili if using) into a jar; pour brine over to cover.
Chill at least 24 hours. Keeps 2–3 weeks refrigerated.

ingredients: 1 cup daikon or red radish, finely chopped or julienned
steps: Stir vinegar, water, sugar, and salt until dissolved.
Add radish and chill 30 minutes (better after a few hours). Keeps 1 week.
Mix minced garlic with warm water and a pinch of salt.
Let stand 5–10 minutes before using (mellows the raw bite).

Gansu.description: The most famous noodle soup in China, originating from the Silk Road city of Lanzhou. It is defined by five colors: clear broth, white radish, red chili oil, green cilantro, and yellow noodles. The noodles are hand-pulled to order in seconds.
ingredients: High-gluten Flour (for noodles) or Fresh Wheat Noodles
Spices: Star Anise, Cinnamon, Sichuan Peppercorns, Ginger, Sand Ginger
steps: Soak beef in water to remove blood. Boil with spices for 3-4 hours to make a clear, aromatic broth.
Remove beef, let cool, and slice thin.
Cook radish slices in the beef broth until translucent.
Cook noodles separately (if fresh) or pull dough if skilled.
Assemble: Noodles in bowl, ladle hot broth and radishes, top with beef slices.
Finish with a generous spoon of red chili oil and chopped cilantro.

drink.description: A regional lager from Lanzhou, Gansu—simple, crisp, and made for cold serving.
steps: Chill well.
Pour into a glass (optional) and serve immediately.

Guizhou.description: A signature dish of the Miao people in Kaili. The vibrant red soup base is made from fermented tomatoes and rice water, creating a unique sour and spicy flavor that is distinct from vinegar-based sourness. It is often served as a hot pot.
ingredients: 1 cup Red Sour Soup Base (Fermented Tomato Paste)
Litsea Oil (Mu Jiang Zi) - essential lemon-scented spice
steps: Fry ginger, garlic, and tomatoes in oil until soft.
Add the Red Sour Soup base and fry until fragrant.
Add water or stock. Bring to a boil.
Add the fish (cut into chunks). Simmer until cooked.
Add a few drops of Litsea oil (crucial for authentic aroma).
Serve with a dipping sauce of chili powder, fermented bean curd, and cilantro.

drink.description: Guizhou’s most famous baijiu, traditionally served neat in tiny pours during formal toasts.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5 oz at a time into small cups.
Toast and sip; it’s intense—small pours are the point.

Hebei.description: A famous street food from Baoding. The saying goes: 'In Heaven there is dragon meat, on Earth there is donkey meat.' Savory, braised meat is chopped and stuffed into a crispy, flaky, rectangular bun.
ingredients: 1 lb Donkey Meat (or Beef Shank substitute)
Braising Liquid: Soy Sauce, Star Anise, Cinnamon, Cloves, Fennel
Dough: Flour, Water, Oil (for the bun)
steps: Braise the meat in the spiced master stock for hours until it falls apart. Let it cool in the juices.
Make a dough. Roll it out, brush with oil, roll up, and flatten to create layers.
Pan-fry the buns until golden and crispy.
Chop the braised meat finely (mix with a little green pepper if desired).
Slice the hot bun open and stuff it with the cold or warm meat and a spoonful of the braising jus.

drink.description: A distinctive baijiu style associated with Hebei, traditionally served neat in small cups.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with hearty food.

Heilongjiang.description: A classic Harbin dish created for Russian tastes in the early 20th century. Sliced pork is coated in potato starch and fried twice until shattering crisp, then tossed in a sweet and sour sauce made with vinegar and sugar (no ketchup).
ingredients: 1 cup Potato Starch (soaked in water for 30 mins, water poured off)
Sauce: 1/2 cup Sugar, 1/2 cup White Vinegar, 1 tsp Salt
steps: Mix the soaked wet starch with a little oil to make a thick batter. Coat pork slices.
Deep fry pork at 350°F until set. Remove.
Increase heat to 400°F. Fry again until golden and extremely crispy.
In a wok, heat the vinegar and sugar until it bubbles and thickens slightly (syrupy).
Toss in the ginger and carrots.
Add the pork. Toss rapidly to coat (5 seconds max). Serve immediately.

drink.description: A well-known lager associated with Heilongjiang’s Harbin—best ice-cold alongside grilled and smoked foods.
steps: Chill well.
Pour into a glass (optional) and serve immediately.

Henan.description: One of China's top ten noodles. It features wide, hand-stretched noodles in a nourishing, milky-white mutton broth. The soup is rich with the essence of bone marrow and herbs.
steps: Boil mutton bones and meat on high heat for 2-3 hours to create a milky white broth.
Soak kelp and tofu sheets.
Cook the wide noodles in the mutton broth.
Add the kelp, tofu sheets, and vermicelli.
Serve in a large bowl topped with sliced mutton, cilantro, and chili oil.

drink.description: A storied baijiu name associated with Henan; typically served neat for meals and toasts.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Dukang baijiu (or another Henan baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and drink with food.

Inner Mongolia.description: The ultimate dish of the grasslands. Large chunks of mutton are boiled simply in water to preserve the natural flavor of the meat, served with salt and wild chive sauce. It is traditionally eaten with hands using a knife.
ingredients: Dip: Wild Chive Flower Sauce (or Garlic, Soy Sauce, Vinegar)
steps: Soak the lamb in cold water for 1 hour to remove blood.
Place lamb in a pot with cold water. Bring to a boil.
Skim off the foam meticulously until the broth is clear.
Add ginger, onion, and peppercorns. Do not add salt yet (it toughens the meat).
Simmer on low heat for 1.5 to 2 hours until the meat can be easily pierced with a chopstick.
Add salt in the last 10 minutes.
Serve the meat on a platter with the dipping sauce and a bowl of the broth on the side.

drink.dish: Mongolian Milk Tea (奶茶 / Suutei Tsai style)
drink.description: A salty, comforting milk tea common in Inner Mongolia—more like a meal-drink than a sweet café tea.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea leaves (or 2–3 black tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a simmer. Add tea and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Stir in milk and salt; gently simmer 2–3 minutes.
Optional: whisk in butter for a traditional richer cup.
Strain (if using loose tea) and serve hot.

Jiangxi.dish: Steamed Pork with Rice Flour (Fen Zheng Rou)
Jiangxi.description: A rustic dish where pork belly slices are coated in a coarse, spiced rice powder and steamed. The rice absorbs the pork fat, becoming soft and flavorful, while the pork becomes melt-in-the-mouth tender without being greasy.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Sticky Rice + 1/2 cup Regular Rice
Spices: Star Anise, Cinnamon, Sichuan Peppercorns
Marinade: 2 tbsp Soy Sauce, 1 tbsp Fermented Bean Curd juice, 1 tsp Sugar
steps: Toast the rice and dry spices in a dry pan until golden and fragrant. Grind into a coarse powder.
Marinate pork slices with soy sauce, bean curd juice, and sugar for 30 mins.
Coat each pork slice thoroughly in the rice powder.
Place potato cubes at the bottom of a steamer bowl.
Layer the rice-coated pork on top.
Steam for 1.5 to 2 hours until the pork is gelatinous and the rice powder is soft.

drink.description: A representative baijiu from Jiangxi, traditionally enjoyed neat in small toasting pours.
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip alongside food.

Jilin.dish: Chicken Stew with Hazel Mushrooms (Xiao Ji Dun Mo Gu)
Jilin.description: A famous Northeastern (Dongbei) stew. It uses wild hazel mushrooms which have a distinct, intense aroma, simmered with chicken and glass noodles. It is a warming winter staple.
ingredients: Star Anise, Ginger, Scallions, Dried Chilies
steps: Sauté chicken pieces in oil until browned and fat renders.
Add ginger, scallions, star anise, and chilies. Stir fry until fragrant.
Add soy sauces and sugar. Stir to coat.
Add the soaked mushrooms and water to cover. Bring to a boil.
Simmer for 40 minutes.
Add the glass noodles and cook for another 10 minutes until noodles are soft and have absorbed the broth.

drink.description: Jilin is famed for Changbai Mountain ginseng; a common traditional preparation is ginseng infused in strong spirit, served in small medicinal pours.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) baijiu or neutral spirit (vodka works)
1–2 tbsp dried ginseng slices (or 1 whole small dried root)
steps: Add ginseng (and sugar/honey if using) to a clean jar and cover with spirit.
Seal and steep in a cool dark place for 2–4 weeks, shaking every few days.
Strain if desired (or leave the ginseng in for continued infusion).
Serve 1–2 tbsp (15–30 ml) in small cups after a meal.

Liaoning.dish: Suan Cai Bai Rou (Sour Cabbage with Pork)
Liaoning.description: A Manchu-style hot pot dish. Pickled Chinese cabbage (Suan Cai) is stewed with pork belly slices and blood sausage. The acidity of the cabbage cuts through the rich fat of the pork.
ingredients: 1 lb Pickled Chinese Cabbage (Suan Cai), rinsed and shredded
1 lb Pork Belly (boiled whole, then sliced)
steps: Boil the whole block of pork belly with ginger and anise until cooked through. Let cool, then slice paper-thin.
In a wok or pot, stir fry the shredded sour cabbage to release aroma.
Pour in the pork cooking broth (or stock).
Layer the pork slices and blood sausage on top of the cabbage.
Simmer for 15 minutes.
Add vermicelli and cook until soft.
Serve with a dipping sauce of minced garlic and soy sauce.

drink.description: A historic baijiu brand associated with Shenyang, Liaoning—served neat for toasts and meals.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Laolongkou-style baijiu (or another Liaoning baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with savory dishes.

ingredients: 1 medium napa cabbage (about 2 lbs), cut into large pieces
2 tbsp kosher salt (about 2% by weight; adjust for cabbage size)
Optional: 2–3 slices ginger or a few Sichuan peppercorns
steps: Toss cabbage with salt and massage 2–3 minutes until it starts releasing liquid.
Pack tightly into a clean jar or crock. Add enough water to submerge if needed (a light brine).
Weight cabbage under the brine (use a fermentation weight or a small bag filled with brine).
Ferment at cool room temperature 3–7 days until pleasantly sour. Skim any surface foam as needed.
Refrigerate when it tastes right. Rinse before cooking if very salty/sour.

Ningxia.description: Ningxia is the 'Home of Goji Berries'. This dish pairs the region's high-quality Tan sheep meat with local wolfberries (goji), creating a dish that is both savory and slightly sweet, believed to be very nourishing.
ingredients: 2 lbs Lamb Chops or Stew Meat
steps: Blanch lamb in boiling water. Drain.
Heat oil and melt rock sugar until amber colored.
Add lamb and coat in the sugar. Add ginger and scallions.
Add soy sauce, wine, and water to cover.
Simmer for 1 hour until tender.
Add the goji berries in the last 10 minutes (cooking them too long destroys nutrients).
Reduce sauce until thick and glossy.

drink.description: Ningxia is China’s most famous modern wine region; this is the signature local pour.
ingredients: 5 oz (150 ml) Ningxia red wine (Cabernet blend is common)
steps: Serve slightly below room temperature (about 60–65°F / 16–18°C).
Pour into a wine glass and let it breathe a few minutes before drinking.

Qinghai.description: A hearty staple of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Small squares of dough are pinched off by hand and thrown into a savory mutton or beef broth loaded with vegetables like tomatoes, squash, and radishes. It is simple, warming, and filling.
steps: Make a stiff dough with flour and water. Let rest.
Stir-fry meat with aromatics. Add vegetables and water to make a rich broth.
Flatten the dough into strips. Pull and snap small squares of dough directly into the boiling broth.
Cook until noodles float. Stir in leafy greens just before serving.

drink.dish: Qingke Baijiu (青稞酒) – Highland Barley Spirit
drink.description: A traditional highland barley liquor of the Tibetan Plateau (common in Qinghai and Tibet), served neat and warming.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Qingke baijiu (highland barley liquor)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour small toasting pours (0.5–1 oz).
Sip slowly; it’s strong and aromatic.

Shanxi.description: The 'King of Noodles'. The chef holds a large block of dough and shaves noodles directly into boiling water with a special curved knife. The resulting noodles are thick in the middle and raggedly thin at the edges, creating a unique texture.
ingredients: Water (ratio is crucial for stiff dough)
Pork Meat Sauce: Ground Pork, Sweet Bean Paste, Soy Sauce, Star Anise
steps: Knead a very stiff dough. Rest for 30 mins.
Make the meat sauce: Fry pork, add bean paste and spices. Simmer.
Boil a large pot of water. Hold the dough block and shave strips into the water using a sharp knife.
Boil until floating. Drain.
Top with meat sauce, vinegar, and fresh cucumber.

drink.description: Shanxi’s famous light-aroma baijiu, traditionally served neat for toasts.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Fenjiu (or another Shanxi light-aroma baijiu)
steps: Serve neat at cool room temperature.
Pour 0.5–1 oz into small cups.
Toast and sip with food.

preliminary_steps.item: Pork Meat Sauce (Sweet Bean Paste Sauce)
ingredients: 2 tbsp sweet bean paste (tianmianjiang) or hoisin
steps: Heat oil; brown pork.
Stir in sweet bean paste, soy sauce, and sugar; fry 1 minute to bloom.
Add water/stock (and star anise if using) and simmer 10–15 minutes until saucy.

Tibet.description: The most iconic dish of the Himalayas. These steamed dumplings are filled with yak meat (or beef/pork substitute) and onions, flavored simply with ginger and Sichuan pepper, served with a fiery chili sepem (sauce).
ingredients: Filling: 1 lb Ground Beef or Yak, 1 cup Onion (finely chopped), 1 tbsp Ginger, 1 tsp Sichuan Pepper (ground)
Dip: Dried Red Chilies, Garlic, Tomato
steps: Mix flour and water to make a smooth dough.
Mix filling ingredients. The onion ratio should be high for juiciness.
Roll small circles of dough. Place filling in center.
Pleat the edges to seal (round or crescent shape).
Steam for 10-15 minutes.
Serve hot with chili sauce.

drink.description: A salty, buttery tea traditionally churned until emulsified—built for cold, high-altitude weather.
ingredients: Optional: 1/4 cup (60 ml) milk for a softer profile
steps: Pour hot tea into a blender (or use a thermos and vigorous shaking).
Add butter, salt, and milk (optional). Blend 20–30 seconds until foamy and emulsified.
Taste and adjust salt/butter.
Serve hot.

drink.description: A widely loved Chinese-style tea: fragrant jasmine aroma over a clean green-tea base.
ingredients: 1 tsp jasmine green tea (loose leaf) per 8 oz water
steps: Heat water to about 175°F (a gentle simmer, not a rolling boil).
Add tea to a teapot or infuser.
Pour in hot water and steep 2–3 minutes.
Strain and serve plain (traditional), or re-steep the leaves for additional infusions.

ingredients: 2 tbsp neutral oil (for brushing between pancakes)
steps: Mix flour with boiling water, stirring with chopsticks/spoon until shaggy. Add room-temp water as needed to form a soft dough.
Knead 5–8 minutes until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Divide into 12–16 pieces. Roll one piece into a small circle, brush lightly with oil, top with a second circle, and roll the pair together thin (about 6 inches).
Cook in a dry skillet over medium heat 30–60 seconds per side until pale golden spots appear (don’t brown heavily).
While warm, peel the two pancakes apart. Keep covered with a towel to stay soft.

CIV.description: An Ivorian chicken stew cooked ‘à l’étouffée’ (covered) with vegetables and aromatics—traditionally with little to no added liquid.
ingredients: 1 tbsp vegetable oil (optional; traditional versions may omit)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: In a heavy pot with a tight lid, combine chicken, onions, tomatoes, pepper, eggplant (if using), garlic, ginger (if using), chiles, salt, pepper, and thyme.
If using oil, drizzle it over the top. Cover tightly.
Cook over medium-low heat 45–60 minutes, shaking or stirring gently every 10 minutes so it doesn’t stick.
When chicken is tender and vegetables have collapsed into a sauce, uncover and simmer 5–10 minutes to thicken if needed.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve with rice, attiéké, or plantains.

drink.description: Ivory Coast’s popular ginger drink—spicy, citrusy, and served ice-cold.
ingredients: 8 oz fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend ginger with 2 cups water until very smooth. Strain through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a pitcher.
Add remaining 6 cups water, sugar, citrus juice, a pinch of salt, and mint (if using). Stir well.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice.

CMR.description: Cameroon’s famous bitterleaf-and-peanut stew, often made with beef and shrimp and served with plantains, rice, or fufu.
ingredients: 1/2 cup dried shrimp (or 1 lb fresh shrimp, peeled)
1 cup smooth peanut butter (or 1 1/2 cups ground roasted peanuts)
1/4 cup red palm oil (or vegetable oil)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Wash and squeeze bitterleaf repeatedly in hot water until the bitterness is reduced (see preliminary steps). Drain well.
Simmer beef in stock with half the onion, salt, and pepper until tender, 45–75 minutes.
In a pot, heat palm oil. Sauté remaining onion until soft. Add garlic and ginger; cook 1 minute.
Stir in peanut butter and a splash of hot stock to loosen, making a smooth sauce.
Add cooked beef with its broth, then add bitterleaf and shrimp. Simmer 15–20 minutes until thick and glossy.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot.

drink.description: A Cameroonian hibiscus drink commonly infused with ginger and served chilled.
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add hibiscus and ginger, reduce to a simmer, and cook 5 minutes.
Turn off heat, cover, and steep 20 minutes.
Strain, sweeten while warm, and cool. Stir in lime juice if desired.
Chill thoroughly and serve over ice.
Rinse bitterleaf, then soak in hot water for 5 minutes.
Squeeze and rinse repeatedly until the bitterness is reduced to your preference.
Drain very well before adding to the stew.

COG.description: A Congolese-style chicken stew enriched with moambe (palm butter) and served with rice or a starchy mash.
ingredients: 1 cup moambe (palm butter) or palm nut concentrate
steps: Season chicken with salt and pepper. Brown in oil in a heavy pot. Remove to a plate.
Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic; cook 30 seconds.
Add tomatoes and tomato paste; cook 5 minutes.
Return chicken to the pot. Add stock and chile (if using). Cover and simmer 30 minutes.
Stir in moambe until dissolved. Add okra (if using) and simmer uncovered 10–15 minutes until thick and glossy.
Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot.

drink.description: Fresh palm sap that begins fermenting within hours; best consumed the same day for a lightly fizzy, mildly alcoholic drink.
ingredients: Fresh palm sap (from palm wine tapping), as available
steps: Collect fresh palm sap into a very clean container and keep it shaded and cool.
Let it ferment naturally at room temperature 4–8 hours for a lightly sweet, lightly fizzy palm wine.
Chill and drink the same day. Longer fermentation makes it stronger and more sour.

COL.description: A caloric juggernaut from the Antioquia region, originally designed to fuel coffee growers for an entire day. This 'Paisa Platter' is a challenge to the appetite, featuring nine distinct components including beans, chorizo, chicharron, and avocado.
ingredients: 2 cups Red Beans (cooked with pork hock)
steps: Cook beans until creamy. Stir in a 'hogao' (tomato/onion sauce).
Score pork belly skin, rub with baking soda, boil water off, then fry until skin blisters and cracks.
Cook rice and ground beef separately.
Fry plantains and eggs.
Assembly: On a large platter, arrange the beans and rice. Place the chicharron, beef, chorizo, plantain, arepa, and avocado slice around.
Top the rice with the fried egg.

drink.description: Anise-flavored sugarcane spirit popular in parts of South America, commonly served chilled in small pours.
steps: Serve chilled in a small glass.
Sip or take as a small shot; chase with citrus if desired.

COM.description: A Comorian classic: cassava leaves simmered with aromatics and coconut milk, often cooked with fish.
ingredients: 1 lb cassava leaves (frozen is easiest), thawed
1 lb firm white fish (or tuna), cut into chunks
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Heat oil in a pot. Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic, ginger, and turmeric; cook 1 minute.
Add cassava leaves, coconut milk, and water/stock. Season with salt and add chile (if using). Simmer covered 25 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add fish and simmer gently 10–12 minutes until fish is just cooked through.
Finish with lime juice. Taste and adjust salt. Serve with rice.

drink.dish: Tchayi ya Dziwa (Comorian Spiced Milk Tea)
drink.description: Comoros-style chai: black tea simmered with warm spices and milk.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea (loose) or 4 tea bags
steps: In a saucepan, bring water to a boil with cardamom, cloves, cinnamon, and ginger (if using). Simmer 5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes. Add milk and sugar, then bring back just to a gentle simmer.
Turn off heat and steep 3–5 minutes. Strain and serve hot.

CPV.description: Cape Verde’s national stew of hominy and beans, slow-cooked with meats and vegetables; versions range from ‘pobre’ to ‘rica’.
ingredients: 2 cups dried hominy (or dried corn kernels)
1 cup dried lima beans (or another white bean)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
1 lb squash or sweet potato, cubed
steps: Drain soaked hominy and beans. Add to a large pot with 8 cups water and bring to a simmer.
In a separate heavy pot, cook bacon until it renders. Add chorizo and brown briefly. Add onion and cook until soft, 5–7 minutes. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Add tomatoes, paprika, bay leaves, salt, and pepper; cook 5 minutes.
Add chicken and brown lightly. Pour in the hominy/bean mixture with enough of its liquid to cover. Simmer partially covered until hominy and beans are tender, 2–3 hours (add water as needed).
Add carrots, cabbage, and squash/sweet potato. Simmer 25–35 minutes until vegetables are tender and the stew is thick.
Rest 10 minutes. Taste and adjust salt. Serve hot.

drink.description: Cape Verde’s classic punch: grogue sweetened with cane syrup/molasses and brightened with citrus.
ingredients: 2 oz grogue (or unaged rhum agricole/cachaça as substitute)
1 oz cane syrup, honey, or light molasses
steps: Add grogue, syrup, and lime juice to a shaker with ice. Shake 10 seconds.
Strain into a small glass over fresh ice. Garnish with lime.
Soak hominy and beans separately overnight (8–12 hours).
Drain and rinse before cooking.

CRI.description: Meaning 'Spotted Rooster' for its speckled appearance, this is the heartbeat of Costa Rican breakfast. The secret isn't just the rice and beans, but the alchemy of frying them with Salsa Lizano, a vegetable condiment that defines the Tico flavor profile.
ingredients: 2 cups Cooked White Rice (day old is best)
1 cup Cooked Black Beans (with some broth)
3 tbsp Salsa Lizano (Vegetable sauce, essential for authenticity)
steps: Sauté onion and bell pepper in oil until soft.
Add the beans and a few tablespoons of their black broth.
Add the rice. Stir fry to mix evenly. The rice should take on the dark color of the beans.
Add Salsa Lizano. Cook until liquid evaporates and rice is slightly fried.
Stir in cilantro.
Serve with scrambled eggs, fried plantains, tortillas, and 'natilla' (sour cream).

drink.description: Costa Rica’s sugarcane spirit, commonly used in mixed drinks or served with citrus.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add guaro, lime juice, and syrup.
Top with soda and stir.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Whisk everything together in a small saucepan.
Simmer 5–8 minutes until slightly reduced and cohesive.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

CUB.description: Literally translating to 'Old Clothes', this dish's shredded beef resembles tattered rags, but tastes like royalty. Originating from Sephardic Jews in Spain, it became Cuba's national symbol, featuring flank steak braised until it falls apart in a rich tomato-wine sauce.
steps: Boil the flank steak with aromatics until very tender (1.5 - 2 hours). Shred the meat with forks.
In a large pan, sauté onions and peppers until soft.
Add garlic, tomato sauce, wine, cumin, oregano, and the shredded beef.
Simmer for 20-30 minutes allowing flavors to meld.
Stir in olives near the end.
Serve with white rice and black beans (Moros y Cristianos).

drink.description: Cuba’s famous rum-and-mint highball: lime, mint, sugar, rum, and soda—bright and cooling.
steps: In a glass, gently muddle mint with sugar and lime juice.
Fill the glass with ice and add rum.
Top with soda water and stir gently.
Garnish with a mint sprig.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

CUW.description: A testament to Caribbean ingenuity. Like its Aruban cousin, this dish originated when Dutch colonists discarded cheese rinds. Locals filled them with spiced meat and raisins, baking them into a gooey, savory-sweet masterpiece that defines the island's cuisine.
steps: Sauté meat with onions and spices. Add prunes, olives, and piccalilli. Cook until done.
Grease a baking dish. Line the bottom and sides completely with cheese slices.
Pour in the meat filling. Pour beaten eggs over the meat.
Cover the top with remaining cheese slices.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 30 mins until bubbly and golden.

drink.description: A simple, locally-relevant highball built around Curaçao’s famous blue liqueur.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add blue curaçao and top with tonic.
Stir gently and garnish with lime.

CYM.description: A Christmas tradition from the days when fresh beef was a rare luxury. Local cattle were slaughtered and slow-cooked in their own juices with fiery Scotch Bonnet peppers until the meat shredded effortlessly, creating a spicy, savory holiday feast.
steps: Cut beef into chunks. Season heavily with garlic, pepper, and thyme.
Place in a heavy pot with the whole scotch bonnets (do not burst them).
Cover and simmer on very low heat for 3-4 hours. The beef will release its own juices.
Once tender, remove the lid and turn up heat to fry the beef in its own rendered fat until dark and shredded.
Serve with rice and beans.

drink.description: A creamy cocktail closely tied to Grand Cayman—vodka, coffee liqueur, and Irish cream served over ice or blended.
ingredients: Optional: chocolate syrup for the glass
steps: Optional: drizzle chocolate syrup inside a rocks glass.
Shake vodka, coffee liqueur, and Irish cream with ice.
Strain over fresh ice and serve.
Whisk cocoa, sugar, water, and salt in a saucepan.
Simmer 2–3 minutes, whisking, until smooth and slightly thickened.
Cool; stir in vanilla if using. Refrigerate up to 3 weeks.

CYP.description: Literally 'Stolen Meat'. Historically, bandits stole sheep and cooked them in sealed underground pits to avoid smoke revealing their location. Today, it's leg of lamb slow-roasted in parchment paper until it falls off the bone.
ingredients: 1 Leg of Lamb (bone-in, chopped into portions)
steps: Marinate lamb and potatoes with lemon juice, olive oil, garlic, oregano, salt, and pepper for 2 hours.
Place a portion of lamb and potatoes onto a large sheet of parchment paper.
Wrap it tightly into a parcel (tie with string if needed).
Bake at 320°F (160°C) for 3 to 4 hours.
The meat should be meltingly tender and the potatoes soaked in juices.

drink.description: A Cypriot classic: brandy brightened with lemon and bitters, then topped with soda—light, citrusy, and meant for warm evenings.

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar dissolves (do not boil hard).
Cool completely, then store covered in the fridge up to 2 weeks.
Fill a highball with ice.
Add brandy, lemon juice, simple syrup, and bitters.
Stir briefly to chill.
Top with soda water and stir once more.
Garnish with a lemon slice and serve.

CZE.description: A masterpiece of Czech Sunday lunches. Beef sirloin is larded with bacon, braised in a vegetable cream sauce, and served with bread dumplings and a tart cranberry garnish.
ingredients: 2 lbs Beef Sirloin (larded with bacon strips)
steps: Sear the beef in a pot. Remove.
Sauté the root vegetables until soft. Add sugar to caramelize slightly.
Return beef, add water/stock, and braise until tender (2 hours). Remove beef.
Blend the vegetables and liquid into a smooth sauce. Stir in cream and boil briefly.
Slice beef. Serve with sauce, dumplings, and a dollop of cranberries on a lemon slice.

drink.description: A Czech staple highball—its name comes from BEcherovka + TONic. Herbal, bitter, and very easy.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Pour in Becherovka.
Top with tonic water.
Give a gentle stir.
Squeeze in the lime wedge and drop it in.

Chandigarh.description: While popular across North India, this is the quintessential indulgence of Chandigarh. Spicy, tangy chickpeas (Chole) served with puffy, deep-fried bread (Bhature).
ingredients: Bhatura Dough: Flour, Yogurt, Semolina, Baking Powder
steps: Boil chickpeas with tea bags and whole spices.
Cook gravy with onions, tomatoes, and spice powders.
Simmer chickpeas in gravy.
Roll out dough and deep fry into balloon-like breads.
Serve with pickled onions.

drink.description: A Chandigarh/Punjab-region staple: thick yogurt drink, lightly sweet.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) cold water or milk
steps: Blend until frothy.
Serve cold.

DEU.description: A dish of patience and history. This pot roast is marinated for days in vinegar, wine, and spices to tenderize the meat and infuse it with a distinct sourness, balanced by a sweet gravy thickened with gingersnaps.
ingredients: 3 lbs Beef Roast (Rump or Bottom Round)
steps: Marinade: Boil vinegar, wine, water, and spices. Pour over raw beef in a container.
Refrigerate for 3 to 5 days, turning daily.
Remove meat, pat dry. Sear in oil until brown. Remove.
Sauté onions in the same pot. Add the marinade liquid.
Return meat. Cover and braise in oven (325°F/160°C) for 3-4 hours.
Remove meat. Strain gravy.
Stir crumbled gingersnaps into gravy to thicken and sweeten it.
Slice meat and serve with gravy, potato dumplings (Kartoffelklöße), and red cabbage.

drink.description: A classic German shandy: lager mixed with sparkling lemonade—lower ABV, crisp, and ideal in warm weather.
ingredients: 6 oz sparkling lemonade (or lemon soda), well-chilled (180 ml)

preliminary_steps.item: Quick Sparkling Lemonade (If You Don’t Have Lemon Soda)
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz simple syrup (45 ml) (or 3 tbsp sugar, dissolved)
steps: Stir lemon juice and simple syrup in a pitcher.
Top with club soda and stir gently.
Chill and use as the lemonade component.
Chill a tall glass.
Add ice if you want (many serve without).
Pour in the lager.
Top with sparkling lemonade in a 1:1 ratio.
Stir once gently and serve.

DJI.description: Djibouti’s signature spiced rice dish, often made with lamb and warm aromatics similar to the wider Horn of Africa.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lb lamb shoulder, cut into 1-inch pieces
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Heat oil/ghee in a pot. Brown lamb on all sides. Add onion and cook until soft, 6–8 minutes.
Add garlic and tomato paste; cook 1 minute. Stir in spices, salt, and pepper; cook 30 seconds.
Add hot stock/water and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook 35–45 minutes until lamb is tender.
Stir in rice (and raisins if using). Cover and cook on low 15 minutes.
Turn off heat and rest covered 10 minutes, then fluff. Garnish with cilantro if desired.

drink.description: A Horn of Africa-style spiced tea served in Djibouti: black tea simmered with cardamom and cloves, finished with milk and sugar.
ingredients: 2 tbsp black tea (loose) or 4 tea bags
steps: Bring water to a boil with cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon (if using). Simmer 5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes. Add milk and sugar and bring back to a gentle simmer.
Turn off heat, steep 3–5 minutes, then strain and serve hot.

DMA.description: The soul of the 'Nature Island'. This vibrant green soup is a celebration of the dasheen (taro) plant, blending its tender leaves with coconut milk and land crabs caught during the rainy season for a creamy, earthy, and distinctly Caribbean flavor.
ingredients: 2 Crabs (cleaned and cracked) or Salted Pork
steps: Sauté onion, garlic, and herbs.
Add chopped dasheen leaves and water. Boil until leaves are very soft.
Add coconut milk and crab/meat. Simmer for 20 mins.
Drop in small flour dumplings (spinners). Cook until dumplings float.
Adjust seasoning. The soup should be thick and creamy.

drink.description: Dominica is known for “bush rum”—rum infused with local herbs/spices. This is a simple home infusion.
ingredients: 1/2 vanilla bean or 1 tsp vanilla extract (optional)
steps: Combine everything in a jar and seal.
Infuse 5–14 days, tasting occasionally, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

DNK.description: The undisputed national dish of Denmark. Thick slices of pork belly are fried until crispy and served with boiled potatoes and a rich, creamy parsley sauce.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lb pork belly slices (about 1/2-inch thick) (680 g)
2 lb small waxy potatoes (Yukon Gold) (900 g)
For parsley sauce: 3 tbsp butter (42 g)
For parsley sauce: 3 tbsp all-purpose flour (24 g)
For parsley sauce: 2 cups whole milk (480 ml), warmed
For parsley sauce: 1/2 cup finely chopped flat-leaf parsley
steps: Boil potatoes in salted water until tender, 15–20 minutes; drain and keep warm.
Season pork belly lightly with salt and pepper.
Pan-fry or bake: Cook pork belly until crisp and browned (pan: medium heat 6–8 min per side; oven: 425°F/220°C on a rack 20–30 min, flipping once).
Make parsley sauce: melt butter in a saucepan, whisk in flour 1 minute. Slowly whisk in warm milk until smooth.
Simmer gently 3–5 minutes until thick enough to coat a spoon; season with salt, pepper, and optional nutmeg.
Stir in chopped parsley right before serving.
Serve crisp pork belly with boiled potatoes and lots of parsley sauce.

drink.description: Nordic mulled wine served through winter: warm red wine steeped with spices, citrus, raisins, and almonds—optionally fortified with aquavit.
ingredients: 1/2 cup granulated sugar (100 g) (or to taste)
Zest of 1 orange (plus 2 strips of peel)
Optional: 3/4 cup aquavit or vodka (180 ml)
steps: In a pot, combine water, sugar, orange zest/peel, and spices; warm 5 minutes to dissolve sugar.
Add red wine and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
If using aquavit/vodka, add off heat.
Ladle into mugs, including a spoonful of raisins/almonds in each.

DOM.description: The 'Dominican Flag' on a plate, representing the nation's tricolor. White rice (peace), red beans (blood of heroes), and meat (strength) form the holy trinity of the Dominican lunch table, served daily with a side of crispy tostones.
ingredients: Beans: 2 cups Red Kidney Beans, Squash (Auyama), Cilantro, Onion, Garlic
Meat: 2 lbs Chicken or Beef, Sugar (for browning), Sofrito (Peppers, Onions, Garlic, Cilantro), Tomato paste
steps: Meat: Marinate with sofrito and oregano. Heat oil, add 1 tsp sugar and let it caramelize to dark brown. Add meat and sear (this gives color). Add water and tomato paste. Stew until tender.
Beans: Simmer cooked beans with squash chunks, cilantro, and onion until the sauce is creamy and thick.
Rice: Cook white rice until fluffy (Concon/crust at bottom is prized).
Assembly: Arrange on plate like a flag—Rice (White), Beans (Red), Meat.
Serve with a simple salad and tostones.

drink.description: Dominican infused rum traditionally made by steeping herbs and woods, then topped up with rum, red wine, and honey.
ingredients: 2 oz prepared mamajuana infusion (store-bought or pre-steeped)
steps: Serve mamajuana at room temperature or over ice.
Sip slowly; it’s typically served as a digestif.

ingredients: 1 bottle of mamajuana ‘raíces’ (commercial dried bark/herb mix)
steps: Cure (first soak): fill the bottle with rum (or a rum/wine mix) to cover the raíces. Seal and steep about 5–7 days. Discard this first liquid (it’s typically used to ‘wash’ the herbs).
Finish: add the rum, red wine, and honey. Stir or shake gently to dissolve honey.
Steep at least 24 hours in the fridge; better after several days to 1 week. Shake gently once per day.
Serve chilled as small pours (digestif) or mix into cocktails.
Refill method: when the bottle is ~1/3 full, top back up using roughly the same rum/wine/honey balance and let rest 1–2 days before serving again.

DZA.description: The ultimate celebratory dish of Algeria, featuring fluffy semolina grains and a rich seven-vegetable meat stew.
steps: In the bottom of a couscoussier (steamer), brown the lamb and chicken in oil with onions and spices.
Add tomato paste, chickpeas, and 2 liters of water. Simmer for 30 minutes.
Rub couscous grains with olive oil and water. Place in the steamer basket above the boiling stew.
Steam couscous for 15 minutes. Remove, fluff with water/butter, and steam again (repeat twice for fluffiness).
Add carrots and turnips to the stew. Cook 20 mins. Add zucchini and merguez last.
Serve couscous mounded on a platter, topped with meats and veggies, with broth served on the side.

drink.description: Sweet mint tea served throughout North Africa—green tea brewed with fresh mint and plenty of sugar.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Chinese green tea (gunpowder) per 3 cups water
steps: Rinse the tea leaves briefly with a splash of hot water; discard the rinse (optional but traditional for gunpowder tea).
Add tea and water to a teapot and steep 3 minutes.
Add mint and sugar; steep 2 more minutes.
Pour a small amount into a glass and return it to the pot (to mix), then serve. Traditionally poured from height to aerate.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 2–3 months.

ingredients: 6 dried red chilies (or 2 tbsp chili flakes; adjust heat)
steps: If using whole dried chilies, cover with hot water 20 minutes; drain.
Blend chilies with garlic, spices, lemon juice, salt, and olive oil into a thick paste.
Refrigerate up to 2 weeks (cover surface with a thin layer of oil).

Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu.description: Daman is famous for its seafood and Portuguese influence. Fresh crabs are cooked simply in a rich sauce of butter, garlic, and pepper to highlight the sweetness of the meat.
steps: Melt butter in a wok.
Add garlic and sauté until golden.
Add crabs and toss to coat.
Add a splash of water, cover, and steam for 10 mins.
Finish with lots of black pepper and spring onions.

drink.description: The coastal west has strong Portuguese-era spirit traditions; cashew feni served as a simple highball fits the region well.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add feni and lime, top with soda, stir gently, and serve.

ECU.description: Ecuador's national obsession and the ultimate 'levanta muertos' (hangover cure). This robust tuna and yuca soup, topped with tangy pickled onions, traces its roots to the Valdivia culture (3500 BC), proving that good fish stew is timeless.
ingredients: Broth: Tomatoes, Onion, Garlic, Cumin, Cilantro, Chili powder
Toppings: Chifles (Plantain chips), Toasted corn, Lime
steps: Boil tuna in water with onion, tomato, and spices until cooked. Remove tuna and flake into chunks.
Blend the vegetables from the broth to thicken it. Return to pot.
Add yuca to the broth. Boil until soft.
Serve in a bowl: Yuca and broth at bottom, topped with tuna chunks and a mountain of pickled red onions.
Garnish with cilantro and serve with chifles and popcorn on the side.

drink.description: A traditional Ecuadorian hot cinnamon drink, sweetened with panela/sugar and finished with aguardiente.
ingredients: 6–8 oz aguardiente (or white rum), to taste (about 1–2 oz per mug)
steps: In a pot, combine the water, cinnamon sticks, and panela. Bring to a simmer and cook 10–15 minutes, stirring until the panela dissolves and the cinnamon infuses.
Remove from the heat and let it cool slightly (so the alcohol doesn’t boil off).
Stir in aguardiente to taste (start with ~1 oz per mug).
Serve hot in mugs.

ingredients: 1/2 cup fresh lime juice (or a mix of lime + vinegar)
steps: Toss onions with salt (and sugar if using).
Add lime juice; massage briefly. Let sit 30 minutes to 2 hours until pink and softened.
Refrigerate up to 1 week.

EGY.description: Egypt's national street food. A carb-heavy powerhouse of pasta, rice, and lentils topped with spicy tomato sauce.
ingredients: Sauce: Tomato puree, Garlic, Vinegar, Cumin, Chili flakes
steps: Boil lentils until tender. Boil macaroni until al dente. Cook rice.
Crispy Onions: Fry onion slices in oil until dark brown and crispy. Drain. Save the oil.
Sauce: Fry garlic in the onion oil. Add vinegar (sizzle!), then tomato puree and spices. Simmer.
Dak'ka (Garlic Sauce): Mix minced garlic, vinegar, lemon juice, cumin, and water.
Assembly: Layer rice, then lentils, then macaroni.
Top with tomato sauce, chickpeas, and a mountain of crispy onions. Serve with Dak'ka on side.

drink.description: A popular Egyptian-style hibiscus drink—tart, ruby-red, and served hot or cold.
steps: Bring water to a boil, add hibiscus, and simmer 5 minutes.
Turn off heat and steep 10 minutes.
Strain and sweeten to taste.
Serve hot, or chill and serve over ice.

ESP.description: The original Paella. No seafood here—just rabbit, chicken, beans, and saffron.
steps: Level the paella pan over the fire. Add olive oil.
Fry chicken and rabbit slowly until well browned.
Push meat to edges. Fry beans in center. Add paprika (don't burn) and grated tomato.
Add water to the rivets of the pan. Boil for 20 mins to make broth. Add saffron.
Sprinkle rice evenly. Do not stir after this point.
Cook on high for 10 mins, then low for 8 mins.
Listen for the 'socarrat' (crackling sound of rice caramelizing on bottom).
Let rest 5 mins before eating straight from the pan.

drink.description: Spain’s classic wine punch: red wine with fruit, citrus, a little sweetener, and a splash of brandy—served cold over ice.
steps: In a pitcher, dissolve sugar into the orange juice.
Add wine, brandy, and citrus slices.
Chill at least 2 hours (overnight is better).
Just before serving, add soda water to taste.
Serve over ice with fruit in each glass.

EST.description: A peasant dish from the Mulgimaa region that conquered the nation. A rustic mash of barley and potatoes, topped with fried onions and bacon, representing the hearty soul of Estonian cuisine.
steps: Put barley in a pot with water. Place potatoes on top. Do not stir.
Boil until both are soft and water is mostly absorbed.
Mash everything together with a splash of hot milk and butter.
Fry bacon and onions until crispy.
Serve the mash topped generously with the bacon-onion mix.

drink.description: A classic Estonian serve: hot coffee spiked with Vana Tallinn liqueur and topped with cream.
ingredients: 2 tbsp lightly whipped cream (or float heavy cream)
steps: Warm a heatproof glass or mug with hot water, then discard the water.
Add Vana Tallinn (and sugar if using).
Pour in hot coffee and stir.
Gently float whipped cream on top (spoon it over the back of a spoon).
Serve hot; sip through the cream.

ETH.description: A spicy, slow-cooked chicken stew that is the hallmark of Ethiopian cooking.
ingredients: 1 Whole Chicken, cut into 12 pieces (skin removed)
steps: In a heavy pot, cook the onion puree without oil for 45-60 minutes until dry and starting to brown.
Add the Niter Kibbeh. Fry for 10 mins.
Add Berbere spice. Cook for 15 mins (adding splash of water if burning). This forms the 'Kulet' base.
Add chicken pieces. Simmer on low for 45 minutes until tender.
Score the boiled eggs and add them to the sauce for the last 10 minutes.
Serve hot atop a platter of Injera bread (fermented teff flatbread).

drink.description: An Ethiopian honey wine traditionally fermented and lightly spiced (often with gesho). This is a simplified home style.
ingredients: 1/4 tsp wine yeast (or active dry yeast for a rustic ferment)
Optional: a small piece of ginger or a strip of citrus peel
steps: Dissolve honey in water in a sanitized jar.
Add yeast and optional flavorings/raisins.
Cover with an airlock (or a loose lid) and ferment at room temperature until lightly fermented (several days).
Chill, strain if needed, and serve. (Traditional tej uses gesho; this is a simplified approximation.)
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Toast gently in a dry pan for 30–60 seconds to bloom (optional).
Cool completely and store airtight up to 2–3 months.
Melt butter over very low heat. Add onion, garlic, ginger, and spices.
Simmer very gently 20–30 minutes; do not let it brown.
Strain through a fine mesh (or cheesecloth) into a jar.
Cool and refrigerate. Use within 2–3 weeks (or freeze).

FIN.description: Karelian Pies. These iconic rye crust boats filled with savory rice porridge are a protected cultural heritage. They are baked at high heat and traditionally brushed with egg butter.
ingredients: For crust: 2 cups rye flour (240 g)
For crust: 1/2 cup all-purpose flour (65 g)
For crust: 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), plus as needed
Rice porridge filling (see preliminary step), cooled
To finish: 2 tbsp melted butter (28 g)
To finish: 1/4 cup warm milk (60 ml) (optional for brushing)
Egg butter (see preliminary step), for serving
steps: Make rice porridge filling and cool completely (see preliminary step).
Make dough: mix rye flour, all-purpose flour, and salt. Add water and knead briefly into a firm dough (it should be pliable, not sticky). Rest 10 minutes.
Divide dough into 12 pieces. Roll each into a thin oval (about 1/16 inch).
Spoon a line of cooled rice porridge down the center of each oval and spread, leaving a border.
Crimp edges upward in small pleats to form the classic open boat shape.
Bake on a hot stone or sheet at 500°F/260°C for 10–12 minutes until the crust is firm and lightly browned.
Brush hot pies with melted butter (optionally mixed with warm milk) to soften.
Serve warm with egg butter.

drink.description: Finland’s iconic “long drink” (originally popularized around the 1952 Helsinki Olympics): gin lengthened with grapefruit soda—refreshing and dangerously easy.
ingredients: 6 oz grapefruit soda (180 ml) (or homemade quick grapefruit soda)
1/2 cup grapefruit juice (120 ml) (fresh or bottled)
1 tbsp simple syrup (15 ml) (or 2 tsp sugar)
steps: Stir grapefruit juice and simple syrup (or sugar) until dissolved.
Top with club soda and stir gently.
Use immediately as the “grapefruit soda” component.
Fill a highball with ice.
Pour in gin.
Top with grapefruit soda (or the quick homemade substitute).
Stir gently and garnish with grapefruit if you like.
Serve cold.
Rinse rice briefly. Bring water to a simmer and stir in rice.
Simmer 10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until most water is absorbed.
Add milk and salt. Cook on very low heat 35–45 minutes, stirring often, until thick and creamy.
Stir in butter if using. Cool completely before filling pies.
Mash butter with a fork until spreadable.
Fold in chopped eggs and a pinch of salt.
Chill or serve at cool room temperature.

FLK.dish: Roast Mutton with Diddle Dee Jam
FLK.description: A dish born of the rugged South Atlantic landscape. With sheep outnumbering people, mutton is the staple, roasted simply and paired with the unique tartness of Diddle Dee berries, a native heath shrub that cuts through the rich meat.
ingredients: Diddle Dee Jam (or Cranberry/Redcurrant jelly substitute)
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C).
Rub mutton with garlic, rosemary, salt, and pepper.
Roast for 20 mins per lb plus 20 mins extra.
Add potatoes to the roasting pan in the last hour to cook in the fat.
Serve the roast slices with the tart jam to cut through the richness.

drink.description: A common everyday drink on the Falkland Islands is tea (British influence).
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes.
Add milk/sugar if desired.

FRA.description: A classic French boiled dinner: beef and marrow bones simmered gently with aromatics, then vegetables added so everything finishes tender. Traditionally served in two courses—first the broth, then the meat and vegetables with mustard, cornichons, and flaky salt.
ingredients: 3 1/2 lb beef for stewing (mix of chuck/shank/brisket), cut into large chunks (1.6 kg)
12 cups cold water (2.8 L), plus more if needed
2 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
2 leeks, cleaned and cut into 3-inch pieces
4 carrots, peeled and cut into 3-inch pieces
1 bouquet garni (parsley stems + thyme + bay leaf, tied)
To serve: Dijon mustard, cornichons, coarse/flake salt; optional toasted baguette
steps: Put beef and bones in a large pot. Cover with cold water (about 12 cups).
Bring just to a simmer over medium heat. As foam rises, skim thoroughly for a clear broth.
Add salt, onion with cloves, garlic, bouquet garni, and peppercorns. Keep at a bare simmer (tiny bubbles), partially covered, 2–2 1/2 hours.
Add leeks, carrots, turnips, and celery. Continue simmering 45–60 minutes, until vegetables are tender and beef is very tender.
Taste broth and adjust salt. Remove bouquet garni and onion.
Serve traditionally in two parts: ladle broth into bowls first, then plate the meat/bones and vegetables. Offer mustard, cornichons, and coarse salt at the table.

drink.description: A French apéritif: crème de cassis topped with Champagne (or Crémant). Lightly fruity, dry, and celebratory.
ingredients: 1/2 oz crème de cassis (blackcurrant liqueur) (15 ml)
steps: Chill a flute or small wine glass.
Pour in crème de cassis.
Top slowly with Champagne.
Give a single gentle stir to combine.
Serve immediately.

FRO.description: Salt cod mashed with potatoes and butter, gratinated in the oven.
steps: Poach cod. Flake it.
Mash with potatoes, onion, and milk.
Bake at 400°F until golden.

drink.description: Beer is commonly consumed in the Faroe Islands.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

GBR.description: The dish that fueled the Industrial Revolution. Fresh cod or haddock is encased in a crispy, golden beer batter and served with thick-cut chips. It is a national institution best eaten with plenty of salt and malt vinegar.
ingredients: 1 cup All-purpose Flour (plus extra for dredging)
steps: Cut potatoes into thick chips (fries). Soak in cold water for 30 mins. Drain and dry thoroughly.
Heat oil to 320°F (160°C). Blanch chips for 3-4 mins (do not brown). Remove and cool.
Batter: Whisk flour, baking powder, and cold beer until smooth (consistency of heavy cream).
Increase oil heat to 375°F (190°C).
Season fish. Dredge in flour, dip in batter, and carefully lower into hot oil.
Fry fish for 4-5 mins until golden and crisp. Drain.
Fry chips again at 375°F until golden brown.
Serve immediately with salt and plenty of malt vinegar.

drink.description: A classic British summer drink: Pimm’s No. 1 lengthened with lemonade and packed with fresh garnishes.
ingredients: Garnish: cucumber slices, orange slice, strawberries, mint (use what you have)
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add Pimm’s.
Top with lemonade and stir gently.
Add lots of garnishes (cucumber + mint is the core).
Serve immediately.

GEO.description: The legendary cheese boat. A soft dough gondola filled with molten cheese, topped with a raw egg yolk and butter.
steps: Shape dough into a boat.
Fill with cheese.
Bake at 450°F for 15 mins.
Top with raw egg yolk and butter immediately upon serving.

drink.description: Georgia’s ancient wine culture is closely tied to qvevri winemaking traditions.
steps: Serve at appropriate temperature.

GGY.description: A rich, slow-cooked bean stew with pork trotter.
steps: Combine all ingredients in a pot.
Cover with water.
Bake at 300°F for 6-8 hours until creamy.

drink.description: Guernsey’s drink culture commonly includes local beer and cider.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

GIB.description: A savory baked pancake made from chickpea flour and olive oil.
steps: Whisk ingredients into thin batter. Rest 1 hour.
Pour into hot oiled pan.
Bake at 425°F for 45-60 mins.

drink.description: A classic G&T reflecting Gibraltar’s British ties and Mediterranean climate.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add gin and top with tonic.
Garnish with lime.

GLP.description: A delicious collision of French and Indian cultures. Created by indentured laborers from India in the 19th century, this curry uses 'Colombo powder'—a Caribbean evolution of curry powder with toasted rice and mustard seeds—to transform pork into a fragrant yellow stew.
steps: Marinate pork with lime, garlic, and 1 tbsp Colombo powder for 1 hour.
Brown pork in oil. Add onion and garlic.
Add water to cover, remaining Colombo powder, and thyme. Simmer 30 mins.
