Add vegetables and whole scotch bonnet (for flavor, not heat).
Simmer until sauce thickens and veggies are soft.
Serve with rice.

drink.description: A French-Caribbean classic from rum agricole islands: rum, lime coin, and sugar—no juice, just perfume.
ingredients: 1 lime coin (a small round slice, lightly squeezed)
1 tsp cane sugar or 1 sugar cube
steps: Add sugar and the lime coin to a small glass.
Pour in rhum agricole and give it a brief stir (some prefer no ice).
Sip slowly.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 2–3 months.

GRC.description: A culinary monument of the Mediterranean. Layers of fried eggplant and potatoes are bound by a cinnamon-spiced meat sauce and crowned with a thick, velvety béchamel layer that puffs up golden brown in the oven.
ingredients: Béchamel: 4 tbsp Butter, 4 tbsp Flour, 3 cups Milk, Nutmeg, 2 Egg yolks
steps: Salt eggplant slices and let drain for 30 mins. Rinse and pat dry. Fry in oil until golden. Set aside.
Meat Sauce: Sauté onion and meat. Add wine, tomato puree, cinnamon, salt, and pepper. Simmer until thick.
Béchamel: Melt butter, whisk in flour. Gradually add milk, whisking constantly until thick. Remove from heat, stir in cheese, nutmeg, and egg yolks.
Assemble: Layer half the eggplant in a baking dish. Top with meat sauce. Top with remaining eggplant.
Pour the béchamel sauce over the top. Sprinkle with more cheese.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 45-50 minutes until golden and bubbly. Let stand 15 mins before cutting.

drink.description: The iconic Greek iced coffee: instant coffee shaken into a thick foam, then poured over ice with water (and optionally milk).
ingredients: 2 tbsp cold water (30 ml) (to foam the coffee)
1/2 cup cold water (120 ml), plus more to taste
Optional: 2–4 tbsp milk or evaporated milk (30–60 ml)
steps: In a shaker (or jar), combine instant coffee, sugar, and 2 tbsp water.
Shake hard 20–30 seconds until thick and foamy.
Fill a tall glass with ice and spoon in the foam.
Top with cold water (and milk if using).
Stir gently and drink with a straw.

GRD.description: The ultimate communal one-pot meal from the 'Spice Isle'. Breadfruit, salted meat, and dumplings are steamed in turmeric-infused coconut milk until all the liquid is absorbed and only the savory coconut oil remains—hence the name 'Oil Down'.
steps: Layer the pot: Seasoned meat at the bottom.
Add breadfruit slices and dumplings on top.
Top with callaloo leaves to seal steam in.
Mix coconut milk with turmeric and pour over everything.
Cover and simmer on low heat until liquid is absorbed and oil separates ('oil down'). Do not stir.

drink.description: Grenada is the “Spice Isle”—nutmeg shows up everywhere, including in creamy punch-style cocktails.
ingredients: 1/2 tsp freshly grated nutmeg (plus more to garnish)
steps: Shake rum, milk, simple syrup, and nutmeg with ice.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish with extra grated nutmeg.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

GRL.description: Survival in a bowl. This traditional Inuit soup provided essential warmth and energy in the Arctic. While historically made with seal meat for its rich fat content, modern versions often feature reindeer or muskox, thickened with barley or rice.
ingredients: 2 lbs Meat (Lamb, Reindeer, or Seal), cut into chunks
steps: Boil the meat in water. Skim off any foam.
Add chopped onions. Simmer until meat is nearly tender (approx 1 hour).
Add potatoes and rice (or barley).
Cook until rice and potatoes are soft and soup thickens slightly.
Season with salt and pepper. Serve hot.

drink.description: A warm, spiked coffee drink often served with a layered, flamed presentation.
steps: Add Kahlúa and whisky to a warm mug.
Pour in hot coffee.
Float orange liqueur and (optionally) flame briefly.
Top with whipped cream.

GTM.description: Guatemala's national dish. A rich, dark, spicy stew made with roasted seeds and chilies. It is a fusion of Spanish and Mayan cuisines, often served on special occasions.
ingredients: Sauce Base: 4 Tomatoes, 4 Tomatillos, 2 Dried Guaque chilies, 2 Dried Pasa chilies
Thickener: 1/2 cup Pumpkin seeds (Pepitoria), 1/2 cup Sesame seeds, 1 Tortilla (toasted)
steps: Boil chicken in water with onion and salt to make broth.
Dry roast the seeds, chilies, and tortilla on a comal/pan until fragrant. Grind to a powder.
Char the tomatoes and tomatillos. Blend them with the seed powder and a little broth.
Fry this sauce in a little oil. It should be thick and dark.
Add the chicken and vegetables to the sauce. Simmer until vegetables are tender.
Serve with rice and corn tortillas.

drink.description: A widely recognized Guatemalan beer.
steps: Serve chilled.

GUF.description: A legendary Easter stew said to possess a charm: 'If you eat the Bouillon d'Awara, you will return to Guiana.' It takes days to prepare, centering on the bright orange pulp of the Awara palm fruit, smoked meats, and local seafood.
ingredients: 2 lbs Awara Pulp (or palm nut concentrate)
steps: Dilute Awara pulp in water to make a thick broth. Simmer for 2 hours.
Add salted meat and fish (desalted beforehand). Simmer 1 hour.
Add vegetables and smoked chicken. Simmer 1 hour.
Add crab last. The stew is done when oil rises to the top and it is a uniform orange color.
Serve with white rice.

drink.description: In French Guiana, infused “rhum arrangé” styles are common—rum steeped with fruit/spice.
ingredients: 1 vanilla bean (split) or 1 tsp vanilla extract
steps: Combine rum, fruit, vanilla, and sugar in a jar.
Infuse 7–21 days, tasting as you go, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) over ice or neat.

GUY.description: An ancient Amerindian dish that became the national Christmas breakfast. Its deep black color and preservative qualities come from Cassareep (boiled cassava juice), allowing this spicy, rich meat stew to sit on the stove and develop flavor for days.
ingredients: 2 lbs Mixed Meat (Beef, Pork, Oxtail, Cow heel)
steps: Wash meat with lime. Place in a large pot.
Add water to cover, cassareep, cinnamon, sugar, peppers, and garlic.
Bring to a boil, then simmer on low heat for 3-4 hours until meat is tender and sauce is thick and dark.
The flavor improves over days (traditionally left on the stove).
Serve with dense homemade plait bread to soak up the sauce.

drink.description: Guyana’s identity is tied to Demerara rum—this punch keeps it simple: rum, citrus, and tropical juice.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake everything with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Store-bought cassareep (recommended for safety and authenticity)
steps: Cassareep is traditionally made by extracting cassava juice, fermenting/settling, and boiling it down for a long time with spices.
Because raw cassava juice can contain cyanogenic compounds, the safest approach is to use reputable store-bought cassareep.
If you are set on making it from scratch, follow a trusted Guyanese/Caribbean method and boil the liquid thoroughly for an extended time; do not use any ‘quick’ method.

HND.description: The fuel of Honduras. Legend says a woman named Baleada sold these thick flour tortillas, or that they resemble 'bullets' (balas) of beans. Regardless of origin, this folded comfort food of beans, salty cheese, and mantequilla is a daily necessity.
ingredients: Tortillas: 3 cups Flour, 1 tsp Baking powder, 1/3 cup Oil, Warm water/Milk
Mantequilla (Honduran style sour cream - slightly runny and salty)
steps: Dough: Mix flour, baking powder, and oil. Add warm liquid until soft dough forms. Knead well. Let rest 30 mins.
Divide into balls. Pat and stretch by hand (or roll) into thick tortillas.
Cook on a dry comal/skillet until bubbly and browned spots appear.
Assembly: Spread a generous layer of hot refried beans on one half.
Sprinkle with cheese and drizzle with mantequilla.
Fold in half like a taco. Eat warm.

drink.description: A traditional Honduran drink made from toasted corn and cacao ground into a powder, then cooked with milk and sweetened.
ingredients: For pinol powder: 2 lb toasted white corn, 1/2 cup toasted cacao, 1 cinnamon stick, 2 cloves, 1 1/2 cups grated rapadura/panela (or piloncillo), crushed
For the drink: 2 cups milk, 1/4 cup sugar, 6 cups water, 1 Tbsp vanilla extract
steps: Make pinol powder: Grind the toasted corn with the toasted cacao, cinnamon, and cloves to a fine powder. Sweeten the powder by mixing in the grated rapadura/panela.
In a pot, heat the milk and add the sugar. Bring just to a gentle boil, stirring so it dissolves.
Whisk in 1 cup of the pinol powder and stir constantly until the mixture is smooth and thickened slightly.
Remove from heat. Stir in the water (lukewarm or room temperature) and the vanilla.
Serve warm (or chill and serve cold).

HRV.description: The crown jewel of Dalmatian cuisine. A beef round is stuffed with garlic and bacon, marinated in vinegar overnight, then slow-cooked for hours with prunes, dessert wine (Prošek), and root vegetables to create a rich, dark, sweet-and-sour sauce.
ingredients: Bacon strips and Garlic slivers (for larding)
Sauce: Onions, Parsley root, Carrots, Prunes, Prošek (or Port wine), Tomato paste
steps: Pierce beef and stuff with bacon and garlic. Marinate in vinegar water overnight.
Sear the beef. Remove.
Sauté chopped vegetables. Add beef back with marinade and wine.
Simmer for 3 hours. Add prunes and spices (cloves, nutmeg).
Remove beef. Blend the sauce until smooth and thick.
Slice beef, return to sauce, and serve with homemade gnocchi.

drink.description: A sour built around Dalmatian maraschino liqueur (famously produced in Zadar). Bright citrus and a floral-cherry backbone.
ingredients: 1/2 oz simple syrup (15 ml) (or 2 tsp sugar)
Optional: 1 egg white (for a silky foam)
Garnish: lemon peel or cocktail cherry

steps: Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar dissolves (do not boil hard).
Cool completely, then store covered in the fridge up to 2 weeks.
Add maraschino, lemon juice, simple syrup (and egg white if using) to a shaker.
If using egg white, dry-shake (no ice) 10 seconds to foam.
Add ice and shake hard 10–15 seconds.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe (or over fresh ice in a rocks glass).
Garnish with a lemon peel or cherry.

HTI.description: The undisputed king of Haitian cuisine. Pork shoulder is bathed in sour orange and scotch bonnet, boiled until tender, and then fried to a golden crisp. It's a celebration of texture, especially when paired with spicy Pikliz and twice-fried plantains.
ingredients: 2 lbs Pork Shoulder, cut into large cubes
Marinade: 1 cup Sour Orange juice (or Lime/Orange mix), Scotch Bonnet pepper, Thyme, Parsley, Garlic, Scallions
Pikliz: Cabbage, Carrots, Scotch Bonnet, Vinegar (pickled beforehand)
steps: Clean pork with lime. Blend marinade ingredients. Pour over pork and marinate overnight.
Place pork and marinade in a pot. Add water to cover. Boil until meat is tender and water evaporates completely.
Allow the pork to fry in its own rendered fat (add oil if needed) until dark golden and crispy.
Remove pork.
Slice plantains, fry once, smash flat, fry again (Banyann Peze).
Serve pork and plantains topped with spicy Pikliz.

drink.description: Haiti’s traditional cane spirit (clairin/kleren) is often taken with lime and a little sweetness.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) clairin (or unaged cane rum)
1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Stir clairin, lime juice, and sugar in a small glass (ice optional).
Sip slowly.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 2 cups green cabbage, very thinly sliced
1–2 Scotch bonnet peppers (whole or sliced; adjust heat)
steps: Pack cabbage, carrots, onion, peppers (and garlic/spices if using) into a clean jar.
Pour vinegar over to fully submerge; add salt and stir/shake.
Cover and refrigerate at least 24 hours (better after 3–7 days). Keeps 2–3 weeks refrigerated.

HUN.description: The soup of the Magyar herdsmen. Often misunderstood abroad as a stew, authentic Gulyás is a rich soup heavily spiced with paprika, loaded with tender beef, potatoes, and handmade 'csipetke' noodles.
steps: Fry onions in lard/oil. Remove from heat, stir in paprika (to prevent burning).
Add beef and sear. Add water to cover. Simmer 1.5 hours.
Add vegetables. Cook until tender.
Make stiff dough with flour and egg. Pinch small pieces (csipetke) into the boiling soup.
Serve when noodles float. Eat with bread.

drink.description: Hungary’s spritzer culture in a glass: local white wine topped with soda water. The “kisfröccs” is the classic 1:1.
steps: Chill a large wine glass.
Add ice if desired.
Pour in the wine.
Top with soda water (1:1 for a kisfröccs).
Stir once gently and serve.

IDN.description: Indonesian fried rice, distinguished by the use of sweet soy sauce (Kecap Manis) and shrimp paste.
steps: Mash garlic, shallots, chilies, and shrimp paste into a 'bumbu' (spice paste) using a mortar.
Fry the spice paste in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken or shrimp (optional). Cook through.
Crank heat to high. Add rice. Toss vigorously to break clumps.
Drizzle Kecap Manis around the edges of the wok (to caramelize). Mix well.
Push rice aside. Fry an egg sunny-side up.
Serve rice topped with the egg, fresh cucumber, and crispy prawn crackers.

drink.description: A traditional Indonesian herbal tonic (often turmeric-based), taken for wellness.
ingredients: 1 tbsp grated turmeric (or 1 tsp turmeric powder)
steps: Simmer turmeric, ginger, sugar, and water 10 minutes.
Strain.
Add lime juice if desired; serve warm or chilled.
Shrimp paste is a fermented ingredient; for authenticity, purchase it.
Toast a small piece briefly in a dry pan or wrap in foil and heat until fragrant, then mash into the sauce/curry.

IMN.description: Queen Scallops cooked with salty bacon and garlic butter.
steps: Fry bacon.
Sauté garlic and scallops.
Add wine and butter.
Serve with crusty bread.

drink.description: The Isle of Man has notable local beers and ales.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

IND.description: The world famous aromatic rice dish. Requires the 'Dum' method of steam cooking.
ingredients: Spices: Cinnamon, Cardamom, Cloves, Star Anise, Shahi Jeera
steps: Marinate chicken with yogurt, ginger-garlic, salt, red chili, turmeric, raw papaya paste (tenderizer), and half the fried onions. Let sit 4 hours.
Boil water with whole spices and salt (water should taste like sea water).
Add soaked rice. Boil until 70% cooked (grain still has a bite). Drain.
In a heavy-bottomed pot, spread the raw marinated chicken.
Layer the rice over the chicken.
Top with saffron milk, ghee, mint, cilantro, and remaining fried onions.
Seal the pot with dough or heavy foil. Cook on high for 5 mins, then lowest flame for 35 mins.
Rest for 15 mins before opening.

Andhra Pradesh.description: The fiery pride of Andhra. Tender mutton is simmered with Sorrel leaves (Gongura), which impart a distinctive sour tang.
steps: Cook mutton with spices until tender.
Sauté Gongura leaves until mushy. Mash them.
Fry onions and chilies. Add mutton and Gongura paste.
Simmer until oil separates.

drink.description: A traditional Andhra drink—jaggery-sweet with ginger, pepper, and cardamom, especially common during festivals and hot weather.
ingredients: 3/4 cup (150 g) grated jaggery (or packed dark brown sugar)
steps: Dissolve jaggery in water (stir well; strain if there are impurities).
Stir in ginger, pepper, cardamom, and salt.
Chill 30 minutes, then taste and adjust sweetness/spice.
Optional: add lemon juice just before serving.

ingredients: 1 cup fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
2–4 tbsp neutral oil or water (as needed)
steps: Blend garlic and ginger with a little oil/water into a smooth paste.
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in tablespoon portions.

Arunachal Pradesh.description: A savory pickle-like accompaniment made from pork fat and bamboo shoots, flavored with alkaline ash (Khar).
steps: Boil pork with bamboo shoots and baking soda until water evaporates.
Allow pork to fry in its own rendered fat.
Add chili flakes and sauté until crispy.

drink.description: A traditional rice beer associated with communities in Arunachal Pradesh. This is a simplified home method using a starter culture.
ingredients: 4 cups cooked rice, cooled to room temperature
1–2 tbsp rice-beer starter culture (ragi / herbal starter), crushed
steps: Mix cooled cooked rice with crushed starter in a clean container.
Cover loosely and ferment at warm room temperature 2–4 days (until lightly sour/fragrant).
To serve, mix with water to your preferred strength, then strain (optional).
Serve cool. Refrigerate and consume within 1–2 days.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

Assam.description: The quintessential sour fish curry. A light, refreshing broth soured with dried mangosteen or tomatoes.
steps: Fry turmeric-marinated fish. Remove.
Crackle fenugreek seeds. Sauté tomatoes to a pulp.
Add water and boil. Add fish.
Simmer 5 mins. Finish with lemon.

drink.description: Assam is one of the world’s great black-tea regions; brewed strong and malty, it’s a daily staple.
steps: Add tea to a cup/teapot and pour in boiling water.
Steep 3–5 minutes (stronger for milk tea).
Strain and add milk/sugar if desired.

Bihar.description: Baked wheat balls stuffed with spiced roasted gram flour (Sattu), dipped in ghee, and served with mashed vegetables (Chokha).
ingredients: Filling: 2 cups Sattu, Onion, Pickle Masala, Mustard Oil
Chokha: Roasted Eggplant, Tomato, Potato mash
steps: Stuff dough balls with spicy Sattu mix.
Roast balls over charcoal or oven (375°F) until crusty.
Dip hot Litti in melted ghee.
Serve with spicy Chokha mash.

drink.description: A classic Bihar summer drink made from roasted gram flour (sattu), lemon, and spices—cooling and filling.
ingredients: Pinch of black salt (kala namak) and regular salt
steps: Whisk sattu into cold water until smooth.
Stir in lemon juice, cumin, and salts; sweeten if you want.
Serve cold; stir before drinking (it settles).

Chhattisgarh.description: Steamed rice flour dumplings, often described as 'Desi Momos', lightly tempered with sesame seeds.
ingredients: Temper: Sesame Seeds, Curry Leaves, Chilies
steps: Make dough with rice flour and hot water.
Roll into finger shapes. Steam for 15 mins.
Toss in oil with sesame and curry leaves.

drink.description: Mahua (mahua flowers) are culturally significant in central India. Traditional spirits are distilled; this infusion gives a home-friendly version.
ingredients: 2 cups (480 ml) neutral spirit or light rum
steps: Rinse and pat dry the flowers. Put them in a clean jar.
Add spirit and sweetener. Seal and shake.
Infuse 5–10 days in a cool dark place, shaking daily.
Strain and bottle. Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or on ice.

Goa.description: A Portuguese-influenced curry. Pork marinated in vinegar, garlic, and Kashmiri chilies. No potatoes!
steps: Grind spices, garlic, and chilies with vinegar.
Marinate pork overnight.
Fry onions. Add pork and marinade.
Simmer 1 hour until tender and oil floats.

drink.description: Goa’s GI spirit, cashew feni, is often enjoyed simply with citrus and soda.
steps: Fill a tall glass with ice.
Add feni and lime juice (and a tiny pinch of salt if you like).
Top with soda, stir gently, and garnish with lime.

Gujarat.description: A winter mixed vegetable casserole traditionally cooked upside down in earthen pots. Features fenugreek dumplings (Muthiya).
ingredients: Baby Eggplants, Potatoes, Yam, Broad Beans
Green Masala: Coconut, Cilantro, Chili, Ginger
steps: Stuff veggies with green masala.
Layer beans, root veggies, stuffed veggies, and Muthiya in a heavy pot.
Add oil and splash of water.
Simmer on low until butter-soft.

drink.description: A Gujarati staple: lightly spiced buttermilk, salty and refreshing with meals.
ingredients: Optional: pinch of asafoetida (hing), chopped cilantro, grated ginger, curry leaves
steps: Whisk yogurt and water until smooth and frothy.
Stir in salt and cumin (and optional aromatics).
Serve chilled.

ingredients: 1 cup fresh coconut (or unsweetened shredded coconut)
steps: Blend everything into a smooth paste, adding water as needed.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 3 days.

Haryana.description: A rustic winter porridge made from crushed pearl millet and lentils, served with plenty of ghee.
steps: Crush bajra slightly.
Cook bajra and dal with water in pressure cooker until mushy.
Serve hot with a large spoon of ghee.

drink.dish: Ganne ka Ras – Fresh Sugarcane Juice
drink.description: Fresh-pressed sugarcane juice is a common North Indian street drink; served ice-cold with ginger and lemon.
ingredients: 1 tsp fresh ginger juice (or a few thin slices)
steps: Combine sugarcane juice with ginger and lemon.
Add ice and a pinch of black salt if you like.
Serve immediately.

Himachal Pradesh.description: Chickpeas slow-cooked in a rich, thick yogurt gravy flavored with cardamom and cloves.
steps: Heat ghee and spices. Add chickpeas.
Whisk rice flour into yogurt.
Pour yogurt in, stirring constantly to boil.
Simmer until thick.

drink.description: Kangra Valley tea from Himachal is often brewed as a clean, aromatic black tea.
steps: Pour boiling water over tea.
Steep 3–4 minutes, then strain.
Sweeten lightly with honey if desired.

Jharkhand.description: Deep-fried rice and lentil pancakes served with a spicy black chickpea curry.
ingredients: Batter: 1 cup Rice, 1/2 cup Chana Dal (soaked and ground)
steps: Make thick batter with ground rice/dal and spices.
Deep fry ladles of batter into puffy discs.
Serve with chickpea curry.

drink.description: Handia is a traditional fermented rice drink associated with tribal communities in eastern/central India; this is a simplified home method.
ingredients: 1–2 tbsp fermentation starter (ragi / rice-beer culture), crushed
steps: Mix cooled cooked rice with crushed starter in a clean container.
Cover loosely and ferment 2–4 days at warm room temperature.
Mix with water to desired strength; strain if you want a clearer drink.
Serve cool; refrigerate leftovers and finish within 1–2 days.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

Karnataka.description: Spicy, soupy lentil rice loaded with vegetables and a unique spice blend, topped with cashews.
steps: Cook rice and dal until soft.
Boil veggies in tamarind water.
Mix everything with spice powder.
Temper with ghee and cashews.

drink.description: Strong decoction-style coffee served with hot milk—classic across South India, including Karnataka.
ingredients: 3 tbsp South Indian coffee-chicory blend (or dark ground coffee)
steps: Brew a strong coffee decoction using a South Indian filter (or make very strong coffee).
Pour 2–3 tbsp decoction into a cup; add hot milk and sugar.
Froth by pouring back and forth between cup and tumbler (optional, traditional).
Soak tamarind in hot water 15–20 minutes.
Mash well, then strain through a sieve. Use as ‘tamarind water’ in recipes.

Kerala.description: Lacy fermented rice hoppers served with a mild, aromatic coconut milk potato stew.
ingredients: Appam: Rice batter with coconut milk
Ishtu: 2 Potatoes (boiled), Onion, Ginger, Coconut Milk
steps: Steam batter in curved pan to make Appam.
Simmer veggies and spices in thin coconut milk.
Finish with thick coconut milk and curry leaves.

drink.description: Fresh palm toddy (kallu) is a traditional Kerala drink, lightly fermented and usually consumed fresh.
steps: Serve well chilled in a glass.
Drink fresh the same day when possible (it continues fermenting).

Madhya Pradesh.description: Wheat dough balls boiled then baked, crumbled into spicy lentils and drowned in ghee.
ingredients: Dough: 2 cups Wheat Flour, 1/2 cup Cornmeal, Ghee
steps: Form dough balls. Boil in water for 20 mins.
Bake at 375°F until golden.
Crush slightly and soak in ghee. Serve with Dal.

drink.description: Mahua is widely used in central India. This infusion gives a practical home version of mahua-flower spirit flavors.
ingredients: 2 cups (480 ml) neutral spirit or light rum
steps: Add flowers and sweetener to a clean jar; cover with spirit.
Infuse 5–10 days, shaking daily.
Strain and bottle. Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

Maharashtra.description: Spicy sprouted bean curry topped with crunchy farsan and onions, served with bread rolls.
steps: Cook sprouts.
Fry spice paste and add sprouts with water to make spicy 'Rassa'.
Serve in bowl, top with farsan and onion.
Eat with bread.

drink.description: A Konkan staple: kokum and coconut milk drink, tangy and soothing—served with spicy seafood and curries.
steps: Soak kokum in warm water 15–20 minutes; squeeze to release color/flavor.
Stir in coconut milk, cumin, salt, and optional garlic/cilantro.
Chill and serve.

ingredients: 1 cup fresh coconut (or unsweetened shredded coconut)
2–4 dried red chilies (or 1–2 tbsp chili flakes)
steps: Blend into a smooth paste, adding water as needed.
Sauté this paste in oil 5–10 minutes in the main recipe to cook out raw flavors.

Manipur.description: A spicy mash of boiled vegetables and fermented fish (Ngari), flavored with the world's hottest chili.
steps: Steam fish and chili.
Mash fish and chili into paste.
Mash boiled veggies into the paste.
Mix with fresh onion and cilantro.

drink.description: A traditional rice beer associated with Manipur; this is a simplified home method using a starter culture.
steps: Mix cooled rice with starter in a clean container.
Ferment 2–4 days at warm room temperature.
Mix with water and strain if desired.
Serve cool; refrigerate and finish within 1–2 days.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

Meghalaya.description: Short-grain red rice cooked with pork and black pepper. Earthy and aromatic.
steps: Fry pork with ginger and onions.
Add rice and turmeric.
Add water and cook until rice is fluffy.

drink.description: Kyat is a traditional rice beer in Meghalaya; this is a simplified home method.
steps: Mix cooled rice and starter in a clean container.
Ferment 2–4 days at warm room temperature.
Mix with water, strain if you want, and serve cool.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

ingredients: 1 cup fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend ginger with a little water to a smooth paste (add water gradually).
Refrigerate in a small jar up to 1 week, or freeze in tablespoon portions.

Mizoram.description: A stew of vegetables, bamboo shoots, and pork sauce, cooked with baking soda.
steps: Boil water with baking soda.
Add bamboo shoots and pork sauce.
Add greens. Simmer until soft.

drink.description: Zu is a traditional fermented rice drink in Mizoram; this is a simplified home method.
steps: Mix cooled rice with starter in a clean container.
Ferment 2–4 days at warm room temperature.
Add water to desired strength; strain if preferred.
Serve cool.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

Nagaland.description: Pork smoked over a fire, then cooked with fermented bamboo shoots and ghost pepper.
steps: Cook pork with water.
Add bamboo shoots and chili.
Simmer until dry and tender.

drink.description: Zutho is a traditional rice beer from Nagaland; this is a simplified home method using a starter culture.
steps: Mix cooled rice and starter; ferment 2–4 days at warm room temperature.
Mix with water to desired strength; strain if you want.
Serve cool; refrigerate leftovers and finish quickly.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

Odisha.description: Lentils cooked with large chunks of vegetables and tempered with Panch Phoron (five spices) and coconut.
steps: Boil dal and veggies together.
Fry spices in ghee.
Pour over dal. Top with coconut.

drink.description: A traditional Odia festival drink (especially around Pana Sankranti): jaggery, banana, milk/yogurt, and spices.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (65 g) grated jaggery (or brown sugar)
2 cups (475 ml) cold milk (or thin yogurt + water mix)
steps: Mash bananas until smooth.
Stir in jaggery until dissolved.
Add milk and spices; whisk well.
Chill and serve.

Punjab.dish: Sarson da Saag & Makki di Roti
Punjab.description: Creamy spiced mustard greens served with cornmeal flatbread and white butter.
steps: Boil and mash greens. Cook with maize flour to thicken.
Make dough with cornmeal and water. Pat into flatbreads.
Cook on griddle with ghee. Serve with greens.

drink.description: Punjab’s signature: thick yogurt drink, lightly sweet and often perfumed with cardamom.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) cold water or milk (for thickness control)
steps: Blend yogurt, water/milk, sugar, and cardamom until frothy.
Taste and adjust sweetness/thickness.
Serve cold (over ice if you want).

Rajasthan.description: Fiery red mutton curry cooked with yogurt and Mathania chilies, smoked with charcoal.
steps: Brown onions in ghee.
Add meat and chili paste. Cook well.
Add yogurt and simmer until tender.
Smoke with charcoal and ghee.

drink.description: A tangy, cumin-forward cooler—popular in Rajasthan and North India, especially in hot weather.
ingredients: 1 tsp black salt (kala namak) or to taste
steps: Whisk everything together until dissolved.
Chill 15–30 minutes.
Serve cold, stir before pouring.
Soak chilies in hot water 20 minutes; drain.
Blend with garlic, salt, and oil into a smooth paste (add a spoonful of soak water if needed).
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in portions.

Sikkim.description: Pork belly stew with radishes and dried chilies. Cooked in its own fat without extra oil.
steps: Cook pork until fat renders.
Add chilies and ginger.
Add radish. Simmer until soft.

drink.description: Tongba is a traditional fermented millet drink in the Himalayan region. Traditionally it’s sipped through a bamboo straw as hot water is added over the ferment.
steps: Mix cooled millet with starter in a clean container and ferment 2–4 days until aromatic.
Pack the ferment into a mug (traditionally a wooden vessel).
Pour in hot water and let steep 2–3 minutes.
Sip (and top up with more hot water a few times until flavor fades).
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

Tamil Nadu.description: Aromatic chicken curry with a complex paste of roasted coconut, stone flower, and peppercorns.
ingredients: Spice Paste: Coconut, Pepper, Fennel, Stone Flower
steps: Roast and grind spices.
Sauté onions. Add chicken.
Add paste and water. Simmer until thick.

drink.description: A South Indian classic: nannari (sarsaparilla) syrup mixed with lemon and water, served ice-cold.
ingredients: 1 cup (240 ml) cold water or soda water
steps: Add syrup and lemon to a glass.
Top with cold water (or soda) and stir.
Serve over ice.

ingredients: Optional: 1/2 tsp citric acid (improves shelf life)
steps: Simmer nannari root in water 20–30 minutes; cool and strain.
Return strained liquid to pan; add sugar and dissolve over medium heat.
Simmer 5 minutes, then add lemon juice (and citric acid if using).
Cool and bottle; refrigerate 2–3 weeks. Dilute to serve (about 1:4 syrup to water/soda).

preliminary_steps.item: Chettinad-Style Spice Paste (Coconut, Pepper, Fennel, Stone Flower)
ingredients: 1 cup fresh coconut (or unsweetened shredded coconut)
1 small piece stone flower (kalpasi/dagad phool) (optional but traditional)
steps: Toast peppercorns and fennel 30–60 seconds; cool.
Blend toasted spices with coconut, stone flower (if using), garlic, ginger, and water into a smooth paste.

Telangana.description: Raw marinated meat and partially cooked rice layered and steam-cooked (Dum) together.
steps: Marinate raw meat with yogurt and spices for 4 hours.
Parboil rice.
Layer meat and rice in pot.
Seal and cook on low heat for 45 mins.

drink.description: Creamy, strong tea served in Hyderabad-style cafés: long-simmered tea with plenty of milk.
ingredients: 2 tsp strong black tea (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Simmer water and tea 3–5 minutes.
Add milk and sugar; simmer 5–10 minutes on low until rich.
Strain into cups. Add cardamom if desired.

Tripura.description: Pork salad made with boiled pork, onions, chilies, and fermented fish paste.
steps: Shred boiled pork.
Roast chilies and fish paste.
Mix everything together with fresh onions.

drink.description: Chuak is a traditional rice beer from Tripura; this is a simplified home method using a starter culture.
steps: Mix cooled rice and starter in a clean container and ferment 2–4 days.
Mix with water to preferred strength; strain if desired.
Serve cool and drink fresh.
Traditional: Use ragi/ranu starter tablets used for regional rice beers; crush and use as directed in the drink recipe.
Fallback (not traditional): Mash cooled cooked rice with sugar and yeast, cover loosely, and ferment 12–24 hours at room temp; use 1–2 tbsp of the bubbly mash as a starter.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) small freshwater fish (e.g., puti/pool barb), cleaned and gutted
2 1/2 tbsp (30 g) kosher salt (about 6–7% by fish weight)
Optional for paste: 1–2 roasted dried red chilies + 1 clove garlic (if you want a ready-to-use berma paste)
steps: Dry the fish: Pat fish very dry. Sun-dry (covered with a mesh) 1–2 days until leathery and mostly dry, or use a dehydrator at 120–130°F (50–55°C) until dry.

Salt and pack: Toss dried fish with the measured salt. Pack tightly into a clean, dry glass jar or earthen pot, pressing down to remove air pockets. Weigh it down with a small clean weight so it stays compressed.
Ferment: Seal and keep in a cool, shaded place for about 3–4 weeks (traditionally longer). If your room is very warm, ferment in the fridge to reduce spoilage risk (it will take longer).
Finish and store: When aromatic and tangy, remove and sun-dry again 1–2 days (traditional) or dehydrate briefly to firm it up. Store airtight in the fridge.

To make a quick berma paste (optional): Lightly roast a small piece of berma in a dry pan to mellow it, then grind with roasted chilies (and garlic if desired). Add a spoon of neutral oil to form a paste; use small amounts in dishes.

Uttar Pradesh.description: Melt-in-the-mouth minced meat kebabs tenderized with raw papaya.
steps: Marinate mince with papaya and spices.
Form patties.
Shallow fry in ghee on low heat.

drink.description: Thandai is a famous North Indian chilled drink; Banaras/Varanasi styles often lean aromatic and nutty.
steps: Grind nuts/seeds with a splash of milk into a smooth paste.
Whisk paste into the remaining milk with sugar and spices.
Chill at least 1 hour; strain if you want it perfectly smooth.
Serve cold.

ingredients: 1 cup raw green papaya, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend raw papaya with a little water into a smooth paste.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 2 days (enzymes are strongest fresh).

Uttarakhand.description: A green curry made of spinach and fenugreek, thickened with rice flour.
steps: Boil and blend greens.
Cook with rice flour slurry until thick.
Temper with cumin and garlic.

drink.description: A Uttarakhand specialty made from rhododendron (buransh) blossoms—tangy, floral, and served cold.
steps: Mix buransh syrup with water (and lemon if using).
Serve over ice.
Simmer petals in water 10 minutes; cool and strain.
Add sugar to the strained liquid and warm until dissolved; simmer 5 minutes.
Add lemon juice (and citric acid if using). Cool and bottle.
Refrigerate 2–3 weeks. Serve diluted with cold water or soda.

West Bengal.description: Slow-cooked mutton in a thick, dark, velvety gravy.
steps: Marinate mutton.
Fry onions and sugar (for color).
Sauté meat for 45 mins until dark and tender.

drink.description: A Bengali summer classic: smoky roasted green mango, salt, and sugar—sharp and refreshing.
steps: Roast mango directly over flame/under broiler until skin chars and flesh softens; cool.
Peel, then mash the pulp into a bowl.
Whisk with water, sugar, and salt (plus cumin if using).
Chill and serve.

Delhi.description: Born in Delhi's Moti Mahal restaurant in the 1950s. Tandoori chicken pieces are simmered in a velvety, tomato-based gravy enriched with butter and cream. It is mild, slightly sweet, and universally loved.
ingredients: 1 lb Chicken Thighs (marinated in yogurt and spices)
Sauce: 2 cups Tomato Puree, 1/2 cup Heavy Cream, 3 tbsp Butter
steps: Grill or bake the marinated chicken until charred.
Simmer tomato puree with butter and spices (cardamom, cloves) until oil separates.
Add cashew paste and cream. Simmer.
Add chicken and crushed fenugreek leaves.
Finish with a dollop of butter.

drink.description: Delhi-style shikanji: lemon-limeade with roasted cumin and black salt—street-drink perfection.
ingredients: Pinch of black salt (kala namak) and regular salt
steps: Whisk lemon juice, sugar, salts, and cumin into water until dissolved.
Serve over ice.
Soak cashews in hot water 20–30 minutes; drain.
Blend with fresh water to a smooth paste. Use immediately or refrigerate up to 3 days.

drink.description: Classic spiced Indian tea—warming, sweet, and milky.
steps: Simmer water with ginger and cardamom 3–5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 1–2 minutes.
Add milk and sugar; simmer 3–5 minutes.
Strain and serve hot.

ingredients: 1 cup fresh ginger, peeled and chopped
2–4 tbsp neutral oil or water (as needed)
steps: Blend garlic and ginger with a little oil/water into a smooth paste.
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in tablespoon portions.

ingredients: 1 cup raw green papaya, peeled and chopped
steps: Blend raw papaya with a little water into a smooth paste.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 2 days (enzymes are strongest fresh).

IRL.description: A dish of purity and comfort. Traditionally made with mutton, potatoes, and onions (and water), it relies on the quality of ingredients. Modern versions use lamb and add carrots, but the soul of the dish remains the same.
ingredients: 2 lbs Lamb Neck or Shoulder chops (bone-in)
steps: Layer the ingredients in a heavy pot: Potatoes, Onions, Carrots, Lamb.
Season each layer with salt, pepper, and thyme.
Add liquid (stock/water) to cover.
Simmer gently on the stove (or bake) for 2 hours until meat falls off the bone and potatoes thicken the broth.
Serve with soda bread.

drink.description: Hot coffee sweetened and spiked with Irish whiskey, topped with lightly whipped cream so the coffee is sipped through the cream.
ingredients: 2 tbsp lightly whipped cream (or float heavy cream)
steps: Warm a heatproof glass with hot water, then discard the water.
Add brown sugar and whiskey; stir to dissolve the sugar.
Pour in hot coffee and stir again.
Gently float lightly whipped cream on top.
Serve hot; sip through the cream.

IRN.description: The king of Persian stews. A deep green herb stew with lamb, kidney beans, and the distinct sourness of dried limes.
ingredients: 1 lb Lamb or Beef stew meat
steps: Finely chop all fresh herbs. Sauté them in oil for 15-20 mins until very dark green and fragrant (crucial step).
In a pot, sauté onion and meat with turmeric until brown.
Add the fried herbs, soaked beans, dried limes, and water. Bring to a boil.
Cover and simmer on very low heat for 2-3 hours until meat is tender and beans are soft.
Season with salt and pepper. The stew should be thick and oily.
Serve over saffron-topped Basmati rice (Chelo) with tahdig.

drink.description: A Persian-style yogurt drink: tangy, lightly salted, and often flavored with mint—served cold.
ingredients: 1 tbsp dried mint (or 1–2 tbsp chopped fresh mint)
steps: Whisk yogurt with water until smooth.
Stir in salt and mint.
Serve cold over ice if desired.

IRQ.description: Often called Iraq’s national dish: a butterflied fish cooked over open fire (or under a broiler at home) until smoky and tender, traditionally served with bread, onions, and tangy amba.
ingredients: 1 whole fish, 3–4 lb (1.4–1.8 kg) carp (or striped bass), cleaned and butterflied
To serve: sliced red onion, lemon wedges, flatbread
steps: Pat fish dry. Rub all over with olive oil, salt, turmeric, cumin, pepper, and lemon juice. Rest 20 minutes.
Broiler method (home-friendly): Place fish skin-side down on a foil-lined tray. Broil 6–10 inches from heat until browned and nearly cooked through, 10–15 minutes depending on thickness.
Flip carefully and broil 3–6 minutes more to finish, keeping it juicy.
Serve immediately with onions, lemon, bread, and amba (see preliminary steps).

ingredients: 1 firm green mango, peeled and diced (about 2 cups / 300 g)
1 tsp ground mustard (or 1 tbsp mustard seeds, crushed)
steps: Bring vinegar, water, sugar, salt, turmeric, mustard, and fenugreek to a boil.
Add mango (and chili if using). Simmer 2 minutes, then remove from heat.
Stir in garlic. Cool, then refrigerate at least 12 hours (better after 2–3 days).
Serve as a tangy condiment for fish and sandwiches.

drink.description: Strong black tea perfumed with cardamom, served sweet and hot in small glasses across Iraq.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
4 cardamom pods, lightly crushed (or 1/4 tsp ground cardamom)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add tea and cardamom, reduce to a simmer 3–4 minutes.
Strain into glasses and sweeten to taste.

ISL.description: A delicious way to preserve fish in the harsh North Atlantic. Boiled cod or haddock is flaked and mixed into a thick, pepper-laden white sauce with potatoes, then gratinated until golden. It is pure Icelandic comfort.
ingredients: Sauce: 4 tbsp Butter, 4 tbsp Flour, 2 cups Milk
steps: Poach fish in water. Flake it.
Sauté onion in butter. Add flour, then milk to make a thick béchamel.
Gently fold in the fish and potatoes. Season heavily with white pepper.
Transfer to a baking dish. Top with cheese (optional) and bake until bubbly.
Serve with dark rye bread and butter.

drink.description: Iceland’s caraway-forward spirit (Brennivín) makes a surprisingly clean highball with tonic and citrus.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add Brennivín.
Top with tonic water.
Stir gently and garnish with lime.

ISR.description: Crispy, golden balls of ground chickpeas and herbs, essential to Israeli street food culture.
ingredients: 2 cups Dried Chickpeas (soaked 24 hours, do not use canned)
steps: Drain chickpeas (do not boil). Pulse in a food processor with onion, garlic, and herbs until coarse (like sand).
Transfer to a bowl. Mix in spices, flour, and baking soda. Refrigerate for 1 hour.
Form mixture into small balls or patties (wet hands helps).
Heat oil to 350°F (180°C). Fry falafel in batches for 3-4 mins until deep brown and crispy.
Serve in warm pita bread with hummus, tahini sauce, and Israeli salad.

drink.description: An anise-flavored spirit commonly enjoyed diluted with water and ice.
steps: Add arak to a glass.
Add water (it will turn milky).
Add ice and sip.

ITA.description: Fresh egg tagliatelle dressed with a long-simmered ragù in the Bolognese style: a soffritto base, meat, wine, tomato, and a final enrichment with milk for a rounded, savory sauce.
ingredients: 1 lb tagliatelle (fresh egg tagliatelle preferred; or 14 oz dried) (450 g / 400 g)
1 cup passata or crushed tomatoes (240 ml)
1 cup beef stock (240 ml), plus more as needed
To finish: 1/2 cup finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano (50 g)
steps: In a heavy pot, warm olive oil over medium heat. Add pancetta and cook until the fat renders and the pancetta lightly browns.
Add onion, carrot, and celery; cook 8–10 minutes, stirring, until very soft (do not rush this).
Add ground beef and pork. Season lightly with salt and pepper and cook until the meat loses its raw color and begins to brown, breaking up clumps.
Pour in wine and simmer until mostly evaporated.
Stir in tomato paste, then passata/crushed tomatoes and stock. Bring to a gentle simmer.
Cook at a very low simmer, partially covered, 2–3 hours. Add a splash of stock/water if it dries out; the sauce should be thick but not dry.
Stir in milk (and nutmeg if using) during the last 15–20 minutes; simmer gently to integrate.
Cook tagliatelle in well-salted water until al dente. Toss with ragù, loosening with a splash of pasta water if needed.
Serve with Parmigiano-Reggiano.

drink.description: An Italian classic: equal parts gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth—stirred, not shaken.
steps: Fill a mixing glass with ice.
Add gin, Campari, and sweet vermouth.
Stir 20–30 seconds until very cold and slightly diluted.
Strain over fresh ice in a rocks glass.
Express an orange peel over the drink and drop it in.

JAM.description: A breakfast that tells a story of the triangular trade. Saltfish from the North Atlantic meets Ackee from West Africa (brought by Captain Bligh). When cooked, the poisonous-if-unripe ackee turns into a buttery, egg-like delicacy that perfectly balances the salty cod.
steps: Soak saltfish overnight or boil in water for 20 mins to remove excess salt. Flake the fish and remove bones.
Sauté onion, peppers, and scallion in oil until soft.
Add the flaked fish and thyme. Cook for 5 mins.
Gently fold in the ackee (be careful not to mash it).
Place the whole scotch bonnet pepper on top for flavor (do not burst it). Steam for 3-5 mins.
Remove pepper. Serve with fried dumplings, boiled green bananas, or yam.

drink.description: A rum-forward tropical punch associated with Jamaica: rum, citrus, and a touch of spice.
ingredients: 1/2 oz (15 ml) grenadine (or 1/2 oz simple syrup)
steps: Shake everything with ice until cold.
Strain into a tall glass over fresh ice.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

JEY.description: The Jersey version of the bean jar, using a mix of beans and pig's trotter.
steps: Soak beans.
Cook all ingredients in crock pot for 8+ hours.
Remove bone. Serve.

drink.description: Jersey has a long tradition of cider production.
steps: Serve chilled and pour into a glass.

JOR.dish: Mansaf (منسف) — Jordanian Lamb with Jameed Sauce
JOR.description: Jordan’s iconic celebratory platter: lamb simmered tender, served over shrak bread and rice, and drenched in tangy jameed (dried yogurt) sauce with toasted nuts and sumac-like brightness.
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) lamb shoulder or shanks, bone-in chunks
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) long-grain rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
3 tbsp (45 g) ghee or unsalted butter
To serve: shrak or markook bread (or very thin lavash), chopped parsley
Garnish: 1/2 cup (70 g) slivered almonds or pine nuts, toasted
steps: Simmer lamb with onion, water, bay, cardamom, peppercorns, and salt until very tender, 1 1/2–2 hours. Skim as needed.
Remove lamb; keep warm. Strain broth; reserve.
Prepare jameed sauce base (see preliminary steps), then keep it warm on low.
Cook rice: in a pot, heat ghee, add drained rice and stir 1 minute. Add 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) hot lamb broth and a pinch of salt. Bring to a boil, cover, cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Assembly: Lay shrak bread on a large platter and splash with a little warm jameed sauce to soften. Mound rice on top. Arrange lamb over rice.
Ladle plenty of jameed sauce over everything. Top with toasted nuts and parsley. Serve extra sauce on the side.

ingredients: 8–10 oz (225–280 g) jameed (dried yogurt), broken up (or 2 cups jameed paste if available)
4–6 cups (950 ml–1.4 L) warm water, as needed
1 cup (240 ml) plain whole-milk yogurt (helps stability)
Reserved lamb broth (from mansaf), as needed
steps: Soak jameed in warm water at least 4 hours (overnight is best) until softened.
Blend soaked jameed with its soaking liquid until completely smooth. Strain if gritty.
Whisk in yogurt (and cornstarch if using).
Warm gently over low heat, stirring constantly. Thin with lamb broth/water to a pourable sauce. Do not let it boil hard.
Keep warm; stir occasionally until serving.

drink.description: A classic Levantine drink: jallab is a dark, caramel-fruity molasses syrup diluted over ice with rose water and topped with pine nuts and raisins.
ingredients: 1/3 cup (80 ml) jallab syrup (date and/or grape molasses blend)
steps: In a pitcher, stir jallab syrup with cold water until fully dissolved.
Stir in rose water. Taste and adjust with more syrup or water.
Fill glasses with ice, pour, and top with pine nuts and raisins.

JPN.description: Vinegared rice paired with seafood. It's all about the rice preparation.
steps: Wash rice repeatedly until water runs clear. Cook in rice cooker.
While rice is hot, transfer to a wooden tub (hangiri).
Drizzle vinegar/sugar/salt mix over rice. Use a paddle to 'slice' and fold rice (don't mash). Fan the rice to cool it to body temp.
Nigiri: Wet hands. Form a small log of rice. Smear a dot of wasabi. Drape a slice of fish over it.
Maki: Place nori on bamboo mat. Spread rice. Add filling. Roll tightly.
Serve with soy sauce and pickled ginger.

drink.description: Junmai sake gently warmed in a hot-water bath (a common traditional serve).
steps: Pour sake into a small heat-safe carafe (tokkuri).
Set the carafe in a saucepan of hot (not boiling) water and warm until the sake reaches about 104°F (40°C).
Pour into small cups (ochoko) and serve immediately.

Jammu and Kashmir.description: A signature dish of Kashmiri Wazwan cuisine. Braised lamb chunks are cooked with a gravy flavored with browned onions, yogurt, garlic, ginger, and aromatic spices (cloves, bay leaves, cardamom, and cinnamon). Its brilliant red color comes from dried Kashmiri chilies.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Kashmiri Chili Powder (for color, mild heat)
steps: Fry lamb in mustard oil.
Add whole spices and chili powder dissolved in water.
Whisk yogurt and add to the pot (keep stirring to prevent splitting).
Add fennel and ginger powders.
Cover and slow cook until meat is tender and oil floats on top.

drink.description: A saffron-and-spice green tea from Kashmir, typically served hot and fragrant.
steps: Simmer water with saffron and spices 3–5 minutes.
Add green tea and steep 1–2 minutes off heat (avoid bitterness).
Strain, sweeten lightly if desired, and top with almonds.

KAZ.description: A Central Asian feast dish strongly associated with Kazakhstan: tender boiled meat served over broad handmade noodles with onion broth. Traditionally eaten communally—its name means ‘five fingers.’
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) bone-in lamb shoulder (or beef shank/short ribs)
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
For noodles: 3 cups (360 g) all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
steps: Boil the meat: combine meat, water, bay, salt, and peppercorns. Bring to a boil, skim, then simmer 2–3 hours until very tender.
Remove meat; keep warm. Strain broth; reserve.
Make noodle dough: mix flour and salt, add egg and water, knead until smooth. Rest covered 30 minutes.
Roll dough thin (about 1/16 in / 2 mm) and cut into large squares or wide ribbons.
Onion sauce: simmer sliced onions in 2 cups (475 ml) broth 5–7 minutes until softened; season lightly.
Cook noodles in the remaining simmering broth in batches, 2–3 minutes until tender; remove with a slotted spoon.
Slice or shred meat. Arrange noodles on a platter, top with meat, spoon onion broth over. Serve with bowls of broth on the side.

drink.description: A traditional steppe drink made by fermenting mare’s milk into a lightly tangy, gently sparkling beverage. Home versions often use cultured starters with cow’s milk.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) plain kefir (as starter) or 1/2 cup active yogurt whey
steps: Combine milk, kefir, and sugar (if using) in the jar. Stir well.
Cover loosely (or use an airlock). Leave at room temperature 18–24 hours, shaking or stirring a few times to keep it mixed.
Refrigerate 6 hours to chill and slow fermentation. Stir before serving.
Serve cold. Use 1/2 cup of this batch as starter for the next batch.

KEN.description: Roasted meat, usually goat, served as a communal meal. Simple, smoky, and chewy.
ingredients: 2 lbs Goat meat (leg or shoulder), cut into chunks
steps: Prepare a charcoal grill. The heat should be medium.
Rub meat with oil and salt.
Place meat on the grill. Roast slowly, turning frequently.
Baste occasionally with salty water to keep it moist.
Cook until the outside is charred and the inside is well done (approx 45-60 mins).
Chop into bite-sized pieces on a wooden board.
Serve with a pile of salt, Kachumbari salad, and Ugali.

drink.description: Spiced milk tea common in Kenya.
steps: Simmer tea in water 3–5 minutes.
Add milk and simmer 2 minutes.
Strain and sweeten.

KGZ.description: Kyrgyzstan’s best-known celebratory meal: boiled meat and noodles dressed with onion broth. It’s a dish tied to nomadic hospitality and communal eating.
ingredients: 3 lb (1.4 kg) bone-in mutton or beef (shanks/short ribs work well)
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
For noodles: 3 cups (360 g) all-purpose flour
steps: Simmer meat with water, salt, peppercorns, and bay leaves until very tender, 2–3 hours; skim foam.
Remove meat; strain and reserve broth.
Knead flour, egg, water, and salt into a smooth dough; rest 30 minutes.
Roll thin and cut into large squares/ribbons. Cook noodles in simmering broth 2–3 minutes; remove.
Simmer onions in a ladle or two of broth until softened; season.
Serve noodles on a platter topped with sliced meat and onions; moisten with broth and serve extra broth in bowls.

drink.description: A traditional Kyrgyz beverage made from roasted grain flour cooked in salted water and lightly fermented. It’s nourishing, slightly tangy, and served chilled.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (60 g) barley flour (or whole-wheat flour)
2 tbsp (30 g) butter or rendered fat
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (or 2 tbsp of a previous batch as starter)
steps: In a pot, melt butter/fat over medium heat. Add flour and cook, stirring, until nutty and medium-brown, 6–8 minutes (do not burn).
Whisk in water gradually to avoid lumps. Add salt (and sugar if using). Bring to a boil, then simmer 20 minutes, stirring often.
Cool to lukewarm (about 90°F / 32°C). Stir in yeast (or starter).
Cover and ferment at room temperature 6–10 hours until lightly tangy and faintly fizzy.
Chill thoroughly, then shake/stir and serve cold.

KHM.dish: Amok Trey (អាម៉ុកត្រី) — Cambodian Fish Amok
KHM.description: Cambodia’s most famous curry: delicate fish in a fragrant kroeung paste with coconut milk and kaffir lime, steamed into a soft custard in banana-leaf cups.
ingredients: 1 1/2 lb (680 g) white fish fillets (cod, tilapia, or catfish), cut into chunks
1 tsp palm sugar or brown sugar
6 kaffir lime leaves, finely sliced (or zest of 1 lime as substitute)
1 cup (30 g) packed spinach or mustard greens (optional lining)
Banana leaves or parchment for cups (optional)
steps: Make kroeung paste (see preliminary steps).
In a bowl, whisk coconut milk, egg, fish sauce, sugar, and 3–4 tbsp kroeung paste. Stir in lime leaves.
Fold in fish (and greens if using).
Divide into small ramekins or banana-leaf cups. Steam over simmering water 15–20 minutes until set like a soft custard.
Rest 5 minutes. Serve with rice and extra lime leaves on top.

preliminary_steps.item: Kroeung Paste (គ្រឿង) — Lemongrass Aromatic Curry Paste
ingredients: 1 tbsp fresh turmeric (or 1 tsp ground turmeric)
steps: Pound in a mortar (or blend) lemongrass, shallot, garlic, galangal, turmeric, and zest until a fine paste forms, adding a little water if needed.
If using shrimp paste, mix it in at the end.
Use immediately or refrigerate airtight up to 3 days.

drink.dish: Kafi Thuk Dak Ko (កាហ្វេទឹកដោះគោ) — Cambodian Iced Coffee
drink.description: Dark coffee sweetened with condensed milk and poured over ice—street-stall fuel across Cambodia.
steps: Stir condensed milk into hot coffee until dissolved.
Fill glasses with ice and pour coffee over. Taste and adjust sweetness.

KNA.description: A colorful plate reflecting the islands' history. Salted cod, a staple of the colonial era, is revitalized in a tomato stew and served with 'droppers' (coconut dumplings) and spicy plantains, creating a sweet, savory, and spicy harmony.
ingredients: Dumplings: 1 cup Flour, 1/2 cup Grated Coconut, Water
steps: Soak and boil saltfish to remove salt. Flake it.
Sauté onion, pepper, and tomato. Add fish and simmer.
Dumplings: Mix flour, coconut, and water. Form shapes. Boil in water.
Plantains: Slice ripe plantains. Toss with ginger and chili. Fry until golden.
Serve all components together with seasoned breadfruit if available.

drink.description: A straightforward island rum punch: rum, lime, tropical juice, and spice.
ingredients: 1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake rum, lime juice, pineapple juice, and sugar with ice.
Strain over fresh ice; add nutmeg if you like.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

KOR.description: Fire meat. Thinly sliced beef marinated in a sweet and savory soy sauce mixture, grilled to perfection.
ingredients: 1 lb Ribeye or Sirloin, thinly sliced (freeze slightly to slice thin)
Marinade: 1/2 cup Soy Sauce, 3 tbsp Sugar, 2 tbsp Sesame Oil, 1 tbsp Minced Garlic, 1 tbsp Sesame Seeds, Black Pepper
steps: Mix the marinade ingredients with the grated pear.
Combine beef and onions with the marinade. Massage well. Let sit for at least 30 mins (or overnight).
Heat a grill pan or skillet over high heat.
Add the meat in a single layer. Cook quickly until browned and caramelized (2-3 mins).
Garnish with scallions and sesame seeds.
Serve with steamed rice, lettuce leaves for wrapping, and kimchi.

drink.description: Korea’s iconic clear spirit, often served chilled and shared at the table.
steps: Chill the bottle well.
Pour into small glasses; traditionally, pour for others first.
Sip alongside food.

KOS.description: A labor of love consisting of layers of crepe-like batter and cream, broiled one by one to create a sun-ray pattern.
steps: Pour stripes of batter from center to edge. Broil.
Brush empty spaces with cream.
Pour batter over cream spaces. Broil.
Repeat for hours until pan is full.

drink.description: A Balkan fruit brandy widely consumed in Kosovo.
steps: Serve neat, at room temperature, as a small pour.

KWT.dish: Mutabbaq Zubaidi (مطبق زبيدي) — Kuwaiti Fish & Rice
KWT.description: A classic Kuwaiti table dish: spiced basmati rice cooked in a tomato-scented broth and layered with fried fish (traditionally zubaidi/pomfret).
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) whole pomfret or firm white fish fillets
3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) water or fish stock
Optional: pinch saffron steeped in 2 tbsp hot water
steps: Season fish with 1 tsp salt, pepper, and turmeric. Fry in 2 tbsp oil until golden and cooked; set aside.
In the same pot, add remaining oil and sauté onion until golden. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Add tomatoes and tomato paste; cook until thick. Add loomi, cardamom, cinnamon, bay, remaining salt, and water/stock. Simmer 5 minutes.
Add drained rice. Bring to a boil, cover tightly, cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Fluff rice, drizzle saffron water if using, and serve topped with fish.

drink.dish: Shai Zafran (شاي زعفران) — Saffron Cardamom Tea
drink.description: A simple Gulf favorite: black tea infused with cardamom and saffron, served sweet.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add tea, cardamom, and saffron; simmer 3–4 minutes.
Strain and sweeten to taste.

LAO.dish: Laap (ລາບ) — Lao Minced Meat Salad
LAO.description: Often described as Laos’s national dish: minced meat seasoned bright with lime, fish sauce, herbs, and toasted rice powder (khao khua) for signature nuttiness.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) ground chicken, pork, or turkey
1/4 cup (60 ml) water or light stock
2 tbsp lime juice, plus more to taste
1–2 tsp crushed dried chili, to taste
3 tbsp toasted rice powder (khao khua) (see preliminary steps)
steps: In a skillet, cook ground meat with water/stock over medium heat, breaking it up, until just cooked through but still juicy.
Off heat, stir in fish sauce, lime juice, and sugar. Taste and adjust salty/sour/sweet.
Fold in shallots, mint, cilantro, scallions, chili, and toasted rice powder.
Serve warm or room temp with sticky rice and raw vegetables.

preliminary_steps.item: Khao Khua (ເຂົ້າຄົວ) — Toasted Rice Powder
ingredients: 1/2 cup (90 g) uncooked sticky rice (or jasmine rice)
steps: Toast rice in a dry skillet over medium heat, stirring constantly, until deep golden and nutty, 10–15 minutes.
Cool completely, then grind to a coarse powder (mortar/pestle or spice grinder).
Store airtight up to 1 month.

drink.dish: Kafae Lao (ກາເຟລາວ) — Lao Iced Coffee
drink.description: A Southeast Asian classic in Lao style: very strong coffee sweetened with condensed milk and served over ice.
ingredients: 2 cups (475 ml) very strong brewed coffee
Optional: 2 tbsp evaporated milk for extra creaminess
steps: Stir condensed milk (and evaporated milk if using) into hot coffee until dissolved.
Pour over ice. Adjust sweetness to taste.

LBN.description: The national dish of Lebanon. A croquette of spiced ground meat and bulgur wheat, stuffed with more meat and pine nuts.
ingredients: Shell: 1 lb Lean Ground Beef/Lamb, 2 cups Fine Bulgur (soaked), 1 Onion (grated), Spices (Cumin, Allspice)
Filling: 1/2 lb Ground Beef/Lamb, 1 Onion (chopped), 1/2 cup Pine Nuts, 1 tsp Sumac, Salt/Pepper
steps: Filling: Sauté onion and meat until brown. Add pine nuts and spices. Let cool.
Shell: Knead the soaked bulgur, lean meat, grated onion, and spices into a smooth dough (use a food processor if needed).
Forming: Take a ball of shell dough. Make a hole with your finger to create a cup. Stuff with filling. Seal the top and shape into a football (torpedo) shape.
Deep fry at 350°F (180°C) until dark brown and crispy.
Serve hot with yogurt sauce or hummus.

drink.description: Lebanese arak is traditionally diluted with water and served with ice.
steps: Add arak to a glass.
Add water, then ice.

LCA.description: Don't be fooled by the name—'Green Figs' are actually unripe bananas, a major island crop. Boiled until firm and starchy, they replace potatoes as the perfect foil for savory, flaked salted cod sautéed with aromatic herbs and peppers.
steps: Cut ends off green bananas. Score the skin. Boil in salted water until tender (skin turns dark). Peel.
Soak and boil saltfish. Flake it.
Sauté onion, garlic, pepper, and herbs in oil.
Add flaked fish. Cook for 5-10 mins to meld flavors.
Serve the boiled green bananas alongside the stewed saltfish.

drink.description: A St Lucian herbal rum infusion (bois bandé) often served as a local “bush rum” style drink.
ingredients: 2 tbsp bois bandé bark (or 1–2 small pieces, if available)
steps: Combine rum, bois bandé bark, and sugar in a jar; seal.
Infuse 7–21 days, shaking occasionally, then strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

LIE.description: The principality's answer to mac and cheese. Small flour dumplings (knöpfle) are layered with pungent local cheese (Sura Kees or Gruyère) and topped with sweet, crispy caramelized onions.
steps: Mix flour, eggs, salt, and water to make a sticky dough.
Press dough through a colander or spaetzle maker into boiling salted water.
When dumplings float, skim them out.
Layer dumplings and cheese in a dish. Repeat.
Fry onions in butter until dark brown and crispy. Top the dish.
Serve immediately with applesauce on the side.

drink.description: A simple alpine spritz: local white wine topped with sparkling water—light, crisp, and easy.
steps: Chill a wine glass and fill with ice.
Pour in the wine.
Top with sparkling water and stir once.
Add a lemon wedge if you like.

LKA.dish: Kottu Roti (කොත්තු රොටි) — Sri Lankan Chopped Flatbread Stir-Fry
LKA.description: Sri Lanka’s street-food icon: shredded godamba roti chopped on a hot griddle with aromatics, curry spices, egg, and often chicken—savory, loud, and addictive.
ingredients: 4–5 godamba roti (or thin plain parathas), sliced into ribbons (see preliminary steps for homemade)
1 tbsp soy sauce (optional, common in modern kottu)
1/2 cup (120 ml) chicken stock or water
steps: Heat oil on a large skillet/griddle. Sauté onion until soft, then add garlic, ginger, and chili; cook 1 minute.
Add cabbage and carrot; stir-fry 2–3 minutes.
Add chicken (if using), curry powder, pepper, and a pinch of salt; stir to coat.
Push everything aside. Scramble eggs in the empty space, then mix through.
Add sliced roti, soy sauce (if using), and stock/water. Chop and toss continuously until roti absorbs flavor and everything is hot, 3–5 minutes.
Serve with lime.

preliminary_steps.item: Godamba Roti (Sri Lankan Flatbread) — Quick Home Version
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 ml) neutral oil, plus more for cooking
steps: Mix flour, salt, and sugar. Add water and oil and knead 8–10 minutes until very smooth.
Rest covered 1 hour.
Divide into 6 balls. Oil hands and surface. Flatten each ball and stretch/roll very thin (as thin as you can).
Cook on a hot lightly oiled skillet 1–2 minutes per side until lightly browned and pliable.
Cool, then slice for kottu.

drink.description: A Sri Lankan-style sour built around Ceylon arrack (coconut sap spirit): bright lime, soft sweetness, and a foamy head.
ingredients: 3/4 oz (22 ml) simple syrup (see preliminary steps)
1 egg white (optional but traditional for foam)
steps: Dry-shake (no ice) arrack, lime, syrup, and egg white 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake hard 10–12 seconds.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass. Add bitters on top if using.
Warm water and sugar together just until dissolved (no need to boil).
Cool and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

LTU.description: Named after the Zeppelin airships they resemble. These massive potato dumplings are a labor of love, made from a unique mix of raw and cooked potato dough, stuffed with meat, and drenched in a bacon-sour cream sauce.
ingredients: For filling: 1 lb ground pork (450 g)
For filling: 1 small onion, finely grated
For filling: 1 tsp kosher salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, optional 1 clove garlic
For potato dough: 4 lb russet potatoes, peeled (1.8 kg)
For potato dough: 1 tsp kosher salt
For potato dough: 1 tbsp potato starch (optional, helps bind)
For serving: 6 oz bacon, diced (170 g)
For serving: sour cream and chopped dill
steps: Mix filling: combine ground pork with grated onion, salt, pepper (and garlic if using). Refrigerate.
Grate potatoes finely. Wrap in a towel and squeeze hard to remove liquid; let the liquid sit, then pour off and keep the potato starch at the bottom.
Combine grated potato with salt, reserved starch, and optional potato starch. The mixture should hold together when pressed; add a little starch if too wet.
With wet hands, take a large handful of potato mixture, flatten, add 1–2 tbsp filling, and shape into an oval ‘zeppelin’ around the filling. Seal well.
Bring a wide pot of salted water to a gentle simmer (not a violent boil). Slide in dumplings and simmer 25–30 minutes, turning gently once or twice.
Meanwhile, fry diced bacon until crisp; add onion and cook until golden.
Lift dumplings with a slotted spoon. Serve topped with bacon-onion, sour cream, and dill.

drink.description: A lightly fermented rye-bread drink—sweet-tart, low alcohol, and traditionally served cold.
ingredients: 8 oz dark rye bread, sliced (225 g)
1/2 cup sugar (100 g), plus more to taste
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, speeds fermentation)
Optional: lemon peel or a few mint leaves
steps: Toast rye bread slices until very dark (but not fully burned) to deepen flavor.
Pour boiling water over the toasted bread in a heatproof bowl; cover and steep 6–12 hours.
Strain out the bread, pressing gently; stir in sugar until dissolved.
Cool to lukewarm; add yeast (or rely on wild yeast/raisins). Add raisins if using.
Ferment loosely covered at room temp 12–24 hours until lightly fizzy.
Strain, bottle, and refrigerate. Serve cold.

LUX.description: The national dish of Luxembourg. Smoked collar of pork (Judd) is soaked to remove salt, then boiled with vegetables and served with a creamy sauce of broad beans (Gaardebounen) and savory.
ingredients: 2 1/2 lb smoked pork collar/neck (or smoked pork shoulder), rinsed (1.1 kg)
2 lb fresh or frozen fava/broad beans (or large lima beans), shelled (900 g) (see note)
To serve: boiled potatoes and Dijon/mustard
steps: Put smoked pork in a pot and cover with water. Add onion, carrot, celery, bay leaves, and peppercorns.
Bring to a gentle simmer and cook 1 1/2–2 hours until the pork is tender (skim if needed).
Meanwhile, cook beans in salted water until tender (fresh fava beans often need 10–20 minutes; frozen are faster). Drain and keep warm.
Remove pork from broth and keep warm. Strain and reserve about 2 cups of the cooking broth.
Make a light sauce: melt butter in a saucepan, whisk in flour 1 minute, then whisk in reserved broth until lightly thickened. Season to taste.
Fold beans into the sauce (and parsley if using).
Slice pork and serve with the beans and boiled potatoes, with mustard on the side.

drink.description: A Luxembourg-leaning riff: crème de cassis topped with local Crémant—lightly sweet and very dry.
ingredients: 4–5 oz chilled Crémant de Luxembourg (120–150 ml)
steps: Chill a flute.
Add crème de cassis.
Top with Crémant and stir once gently.
Serve immediately.

LVA.description: Grey Peas with Bacon. A dish once served at Christmas to ensure prosperity, now a national staple. The unique local grey peas (similar to chickpeas) are stewed and topped with fried speck (bacon) and onions.
ingredients: 1 lb dried grey peas (or dried whole peas) (450 g)
8 cups water (1.9 L), plus more if needed
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
6 oz thick-cut bacon or salted pork belly, diced (170 g)
To serve: rye bread and/or sour cream (optional)
steps: Rinse peas and soak in plenty of water overnight (8–12 hours). Drain.
Simmer peas in fresh water with a pinch of salt until tender but not mushy, 45–90 minutes (time varies by pea). Drain well.
While peas cook, render diced bacon/pork belly in a skillet over medium heat until browned and the fat renders.
Add onion and cook until soft and lightly golden.
Toss drained peas into the skillet; stir to coat in the bacon fat. Add butter if using.
Season with black pepper (and more salt if needed). Serve hot.

drink.description: A popular hot serve using Riga Black Balsam Currant—warming, citrusy, and slightly bitter.
ingredients: 1 2/3 oz Riga Black Balsam Currant (50 ml)
steps: Combine balsam, red wine, and orange juice in a small saucepan.
Heat gently until hot but not boiling.
Pour into a heatproof mug or toddy glass.
Garnish with orange peel and serve hot.

Ladakh.description: A warming noodle soup essential for the cold high-altitude desert. Hand-pulled noodles are cooked in a flavorful broth with meat (mutton or yak) and local vegetables.
steps: Sauté ginger, garlic, and meat.
Add vegetables and stock. Boil.
Add noodles and cook until done.
Season with soy sauce and chili. Serve piping hot.

drink.description: A Ladakhi butter tea variant—salty, warming, and traditionally churned for froth.
steps: Blend hot tea with butter, salt, and optional milk until foamy.
Serve hot.

Lakshadweep.description: A unique island curry where the masala is made by roasting grated coconut until it is dark brown, giving the gravy a rich, nutty, and smoky flavor.
steps: Roast coconut with spices until dark brown. Grind to a paste.
Sauté onions and tomatoes.
Add chicken and seal.
Add the roasted coconut paste and water.
Simmer until chicken is tender and gravy is thick.

drink.description: Lakshadweep’s simplest and most authentic island drink: tender coconut water, ice-cold.
ingredients: 1 young coconut (or 8–12 oz / 240–355 ml coconut water)
steps: Chill and serve straight.

MAR.description: A slow-cooked stew named after the conical clay pot. Aromatic with ginger, saffron, and tangy preserved lemons.
ingredients: Spices: 1 tsp Ginger, 1 tsp Turmeric, 1/2 tsp Cumin, Saffron threads
steps: Marinate chicken with spices, garlic, and herbs for 1 hour.
In a tagine or heavy pot, sauté onions in olive oil.
Add chicken and brown slightly.
Add 1 cup water. Cover and simmer on low heat for 45 minutes.
Add the preserved lemon strips and olives. Simmer for another 15 minutes until sauce is thick.
Serve with crusty bread (Khobz) to scoop up the sauce.

drink.description: Sweet mint tea served throughout North Africa—green tea brewed with fresh mint and plenty of sugar.
ingredients: 1 tbsp Chinese green tea (gunpowder) per 3 cups water
steps: Rinse the tea leaves briefly with a splash of hot water; discard the rinse (optional but traditional for gunpowder tea).
Add tea and water to a teapot and steep 3 minutes.
Add mint and sugar; steep 2 more minutes.
Pour a small amount into a glass and return it to the pot (to mix), then serve. Traditionally poured from height to aerate.

MCO.description: Meaning 'Uncle John' in the local dialect. These savory fritters are stuffed with Swiss chard and ricotta and are traditionally eaten on Monaco's National Day. They are the taste of the Riviera.
ingredients: For dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour (260 g)
For dough: 1/2 cup water (120 ml), plus more as needed
For filling: 10 oz Swiss chard (or spinach), chopped (280 g)
For filling: 1 small onion, finely chopped
For filling: 1/2 cup grated Parmesan (50 g)
For filling: pinch of nutmeg, salt, and black pepper
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt; add egg and water and knead until smooth, adding a little water if needed. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Cook filling: sauté onion in olive oil until soft, add garlic 30 seconds, then add chard/spinach and cook until wilted. Cool and squeeze out excess moisture.
Mix filling with ricotta, Parmesan, egg, nutmeg, salt, and pepper.
Roll dough thin (about 1/16 inch). Cut into 3–4 inch squares or circles.
Place a spoonful of filling on each, fold, and seal well (press edges firmly).
Fry in 350°F/175°C oil until golden, 2–3 minutes, turning once. Drain on a rack.
Serve warm.

drink.description: A spirit-forward classic named for Monte Carlo: rye whiskey sweetened with Benedictine and sharpened with bitters.
steps: Fill a mixing glass with ice.
Add rye whiskey, Bénédictine, and bitters.
Stir 20–30 seconds until well chilled.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice (or serve up in a coupe).
Express an orange peel over the drink and drop it in.

MDA.description: The bread of the mountains. A dense cornmeal porridge (firmer than polenta) turned out onto a board, sliced with a string, and served with salty sheep cheese and sour cream.
ingredients: To serve (traditional): crumbled brânză/feta, sour cream, and/or fried pork (optional)
steps: Bring water and salt to a boil in a heavy pot.
Whisk in cornmeal in a steady stream to avoid lumps.
Lower heat and cook, stirring often, 15–20 minutes until very thick and pulling from the sides.
Stir in butter if using.
Turn out onto a board (it should hold its shape); slice with a string or thin knife.
Serve hot with cheese and sour cream (and/or fried pork) as desired.

drink.description: A classic sour-style cocktail using Moldovan brandy (‘Divin’): bright citrus, orange liqueur, and a sugar rim if you like.
ingredients: 3/4 oz Cointreau or other orange liqueur (22 ml)
Optional: sugar rim and lemon twist
steps: Optional: rim a coupe glass with lemon and dip in sugar; chill the glass.
Add Divin, orange liqueur, and lemon juice to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard 10–12 seconds.
Double-strain into the chilled coupe.
Garnish with a lemon twist.

MDV.dish: Mas Huni (މަސް ހުނި) — Maldivian Tuna & Coconut Salad
MDV.description: A beloved Maldivian breakfast: flaked tuna folded with grated coconut, onion, chili, and lime. Typically eaten with roshi (flatbread) and black tea.
ingredients: 2 cups (300 g) cooked tuna, flaked (or 2 cans tuna in water, drained well)
1 1/2 cups (120 g) freshly grated coconut (or unsweetened dried coconut, rehydrated)
1 small red onion, very finely chopped
2 tbsp lime juice, plus more to taste
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Combine tuna, coconut, onion, and chili in a bowl.
Add lime juice and salt; mix well. Taste and adjust lime/salt.
Serve with roshi or flatbread.

drink.dish: Kalhu Sai (ކަޅު ސައި) — Maldivian Black Tea
drink.description: Strong black tea served hot and sweet (sometimes with condensed milk). The everyday companion to hedhikaa and mas huni.
ingredients: 2 tsp black tea leaves (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil. Add tea and steep 4–5 minutes (or simmer briefly for stronger tea).
Strain, sweeten, and add condensed milk if desired.

MEX.description: The pinnacle of Mexican gastronomy. Born in the convents of Puebla, this dark, baroque sauce blends indigenous chilies and chocolate with Old World spices and nuts. It is not just a sauce, but a symphony of over 20 ingredients representing Mexico's mestizo heritage.
steps: Remove seeds from dried chilies. Fry them briefly in lard (don't burn). Soak in hot water.
