Fry nuts, seeds, plantain slices, and tortillas until golden.
Blend the soaked chilies, fried ingredients, roasted tomatoes, and spices into a smooth paste.
Fry this paste in a pot with oil. It will splatter.
Add chicken broth and the chocolate. Simmer for 1-2 hours until thick and dark.
Poach chicken separately. Serve the Mole sauce poured over the chicken, sprinkled with sesame seeds.

drink.description: A classic Mexican highball: tequila with grapefruit soda and lime—bright, salty, and refreshing.
ingredients: 4–6 oz grapefruit soda (or sparkling water + grapefruit juice)
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add tequila and lime juice; add a pinch of salt if desired.
Top with grapefruit soda and stir gently.
Garnish with a lime wedge.

MKD.description: Beans in a skillet. White beans are stewed with paprika and mint, then baked in traditional earthenware pots until a crust forms. It is the Friday lunch staple of North Macedonia.
ingredients: 1 lb dried white beans (Great Northern or cannellini) (450 g)
8 cups water (1.9 L), plus more as needed
steps: Soak beans overnight in plenty of water. Drain.
Simmer beans in fresh water with bay leaves until just tender, 45–75 minutes. Drain, reserving 2 cups of cooking liquid.
Sauté onion and pepper in olive oil until very soft and lightly caramelized.
Stir in paprika (and tomato paste if using) for 30 seconds, then add beans, mint, salt, and pepper.
Transfer to a baking dish (ideally an earthenware tavче). Add enough reserved bean liquid to keep beans just covered.
Bake at 375°F/190°C for 30–45 minutes until the top is lightly crusted and the sauce thickens.
Rest 10 minutes and serve warm.

drink.description: A honey-sweetened rakija infusion popular across the Balkans; easy to make at home and served as a digestif.
steps: Combine rakija, honey, lemon peel (and cinnamon if using) in a clean jar.
Seal and shake until the honey is dissolved.
Let steep 2–3 days, shaking once daily.
Strain if you want a clearer drink; bottle.
Serve at room temp or lightly chilled.

MLT.description: Rabbit Stew. A dish of resistance—when the Knights of St. John restricted rabbit hunting, locals mastered cooking it as a form of defiance. Slow-cooked in red wine, tomato, and garlic until tender.
steps: Marinate rabbit in wine and garlic overnight.
Sear rabbit pieces. Remove.
Fry onions and garlic. Add tomato paste and the marinade wine.
Return rabbit. Simmer for 2 hours until tender.
Add peas near the end.
Serve sauce with pasta first, then rabbit as main, or all together with potatoes.

drink.description: A Maltese highball built on Kinnie’s bitter-sweet citrus bite—mixed with gin and amaro, finished with mint.
ingredients: 1–2 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz simple syrup) (to taste)
Garnish: mint sprig and lime wedges
steps: Add gin, amaro, lime juice, sugar, a mint sprig, and ice to a shaker.
Shake briefly to chill, then strain into a highball filled with fresh ice and lime wedges.
Top with Kinnie.
Garnish with mint and serve.

MMR.dish: Mohinga (မုန့်ဟင်းခါး) — Myanmar Fish Noodle Soup
MMR.description: Myanmar’s national dish: a fragrant fish broth thickened lightly, poured over rice noodles, and finished with crispy toppings, eggs, and herbs—breakfast, comfort, and identity in a bowl.
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) catfish fillets (or other firm fish)
2 tbsp fish sauce, plus more to taste
2 tbsp toasted rice powder (see preliminary steps) or 3 tbsp chickpea flour
1 lb (450 g) rice vermicelli noodles, cooked
To serve: hard-boiled eggs, chopped cilantro, lime wedges, fried onions, chili oil
steps: Simmer fish with water and lemongrass 12–15 minutes until cooked. Remove fish; strain broth and discard lemongrass.
Flake fish finely, removing bones.
In a pot, heat oil and sauté onion until soft. Add garlic, ginger, and turmeric; cook 1 minute.
Add strained broth, flaked fish, and fish sauce. Simmer 10 minutes.
Whisk toasted rice powder (or chickpea flour) with a little cool water to make a slurry. Stir into soup and simmer 5 minutes until lightly thickened. Adjust seasoning.
Serve over cooked noodles with eggs, herbs, lime, and toppings.
Toast rice in a dry skillet over medium heat until golden and nutty, 10–12 minutes.
Cool, then grind to a fine powder.
Store airtight up to 1 month.

drink.dish: Laphet Yay Cho (လက်ဖက်ရည်ချို) — Burmese Milk Tea
drink.description: Rich, sweet black tea balanced with condensed milk (often with evaporated milk). Tea-shop essential across Myanmar.
ingredients: 2 tbsp loose black tea (or 3 tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a boil and steep tea 5 minutes for a strong brew; strain.
Stir in condensed milk (and evaporated milk if using). Taste and adjust sweetness.
Serve hot or over ice.

MNE.description: A heavy mountain dish designed for energy. Potatoes and wheat flour are mashed together for an hour until elastic, then melted with 'kajmak' (clotted cream) and cheese. It is a fondue-like texture eaten with wooden spoons.
ingredients: 2 large potatoes, peeled and diced small (about 12 oz / 340 g)
1 cup crumbled white cheese (sir/young cheese, feta works) (150 g)
steps: Boil diced potatoes in salted water until very tender, 12–15 minutes. Do not drain; keep the starchy water.
With the pot at a gentle boil, whisk in cornmeal in a steady stream.
Lower heat and cook, stirring often, until thick and pulling from the sides, 10–15 minutes.
Stir in butter and half the cheese until glossy.
Spoon into bowls and top with the remaining cheese. Serve hot.

drink.description: A Balkan winter warmer: rakija heated gently with sugar and spices—served hot, never boiled.
ingredients: 1 tbsp sugar or honey (15–20 g), to taste
steps: Combine rakija, sugar/honey, lemon peel, peppercorns (and cinnamon if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm very gently over low heat until steaming—do not boil.
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass or mug.
Serve hot.

MNG.description: Mongolia’s celebratory dumplings: juicy meat filling sealed in pleated dough and steamed, especially for Tsagaan Sar (Lunar New Year).
ingredients: For dough: 3 cups (360 g) all-purpose flour
For filling: 1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
1/2 cup finely chopped cabbage (optional but common)
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt, add water, knead until smooth. Rest 30 minutes.
Mix filling ingredients thoroughly; the water keeps it juicy.
Divide dough into 24 pieces. Roll each into a 3–4 inch (8–10 cm) round.
Place 1–2 tbsp filling in center. Pleat edges upward, leaving a small vent hole at the top.
Steam over boiling water 12–15 minutes until cooked through.
Serve hot.

drink.dish: Suutei Tsai (Сүүтэй цай) — Mongolian Milk Tea
drink.description: Salty milk tea brewed with tea leaves and sometimes enriched with a bit of fat—everyday warmth on the steppe.
ingredients: 1 tbsp loose green tea (or 2 green tea bags)
steps: Bring water to a simmer, add tea, and simmer 3 minutes.
Add milk and return to a gentle simmer 5 minutes.
Season with salt (and butter if using). Strain and serve hot.

MSR.description: The national obsession of the Emerald Isle of the Caribbean. Despite the thin-sounding name, this is a rich, dark, clove-scented stew inspired by Irish Irish stew but adapted with goat meat, rum, and tropical spices. It is the centerpiece of every celebration.
steps: Sear goat meat in oil. Remove.
Sauté onions and garlic. Add meat back.
Add water, herbs, and spices. Simmer for 2 hours until tender.
Mix flour with water to make a paste. Stir into stew to thicken slightly.
Add a splash of rum/whiskey at the end.
Serve with crusty bread rolls.

drink.description: Montserrat is known for “bush rum”—rum infused with local herbs/spices. This is a practical home version.
steps: Combine in a jar, seal, and infuse 5–14 days.
Strain.
Serve 1–2 oz (30–60 ml) neat or over ice.

MTQ.description: A vibrant red fish stew that captures the Creole spirit. Unlike a French court-bouillon which is a poaching liquid, this is a rich tomato sauce enriched with roucou (annatto) oil and fiery peppers, in which lime-marinated fish is gently poached.
ingredients: 2 lbs Red Snapper or similar fish (whole or steaks)
steps: Marinate fish in lime juice, garlic, and salt for 1 hour.
Sauté onion, scallion, and tomatoes in oil (roucou oil traditionally for red color).
Add water and bring to a boil to make a broth.
Add the fish and the marinade liquid.
Add the whole pepper. Simmer gently for 15-20 mins.
Serve with boiled cassava or breadfruit.

drink.description: Martinique’s signature: rhum agricole, lime coin, and cane sugar—bracing and aromatic.
ingredients: 1 tsp cane sugar or 1 sugar cube
steps: Add sugar and lime coin to a small glass.
Pour in rum and stir briefly.
Sip (often without ice).

MYS.description: Malaysia's national obsession. Fragrant coconut rice served with spicy sambal, anchovies, peanuts, and egg.
ingredients: Sambal: Dried chilies (blended), Onion, Garlic, Tamarind paste, Sugar, Shrimp paste (Belacan)
Garnishes: Fried Anchovies (Ikan Bilis), Roasted Peanuts, Cucumber slices, Hard-boiled eggs
steps: Rice: Wash rice. Cook with coconut milk, water, pandan leaves, and a pinch of salt in a rice cooker.
Sambal: Fry blended chili paste with onions and garlic in oil until oil separates. Add tamarind, sugar, and salt. Cook until deep red and thick.
Fry anchovies and peanuts until crispy.
Serve a mound of coconut rice on a banana leaf.
Top with a ladle of sambal, and arrange the anchovies, peanuts, cucumber, and egg around it.

drink.description: Malaysia’s iconic “pulled tea” with froth from repeatedly pouring between cups.
steps: Steep tea 3–5 minutes and strain.
Stir in condensed milk.
Pour back and forth between two cups to aerate and foam.
Serve hot.
Soak tamarind pulp in hot water 15–20 minutes.
Mash thoroughly, then press through a sieve to remove fibers/seeds.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 1 week.
Shrimp paste is a fermented ingredient; for authenticity, purchase it.
Toast a small piece briefly in a dry pan or wrap in foil and heat until fragrant, then mash into the sauce/curry.

NGA.description: The smoky, spicy, tomato-rice dish that defines West African cuisine. The 'party' version is best.
ingredients: Base: 4 Red Bell Peppers, 3 Habanero/Scotch Bonnet peppers, 2 Onions, 4 Tomatoes (blended)
Spices: Curry powder, Thyme, Bay leaves, Bouillon cubes
steps: Heat oil. Fry sliced onions. Add tomato paste and fry for 5 mins (remove sourness).
Add the blended pepper mixture. Cook down for 15-20 mins until oil floats on top.
Add stock, spices, and salt. Bring to boil.
Wash rice thoroughly. Add to the pot. The liquid should just cover the rice.
Cover tightly with foil and a lid (steam cooks it). Turn heat to low.
Cook for 20-30 mins. Allow the bottom to burn slightly ('party jollof' smoky flavor).
Stir and serve with fried plantains and chicken.

drink.description: A traditional West African drink made from palm sap, served fresh or lightly fermented.
steps: Serve chilled.

NIC.description: A pre-Columbian survivor. 'Old Indian' is a thick, porridge-like stew that dates back to indigenous times. Shredded beef is cooked with maize dough (masa) and flavored with sour orange and mint, creating a hearty dish that is pure Nicaraguan history.
steps: Boil beef with garlic and onion until tender. Shred the meat. Save broth.
Blend the soaked tortillas with some broth to make a smooth batter.
Sauté onion, pepper, and tomato with achiote.
Add the shredded beef and fry briefly.
Pour in the tortilla batter and remaining broth. Stir constantly as it thickens.
Add sour orange juice and fresh mint. Simmer until it reaches a porridge-like consistency.
Serve with fried plantains and cuajada (cheese).

drink.description: Nicaragua’s national cocktail: rum blended with guava and lemon—fruity, bright, and tropical.
steps: Fill a shaker with ice.
Add rum, guava juice, lemon juice, and optional simple syrup.
Shake until very cold.
Strain into an ice-filled glass and serve.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Toast achiote seeds 30–60 seconds.
Blend or grind seeds with vinegar, garlic, salt (and cumin) until a red paste forms.
Strain if gritty. Refrigerate up to 1 week.

NLD.description: The ultimate Dutch winter comfort. Potatoes mashed with curly kale, served with a giant smoked rookworst sausage and a dimple of gravy. It is simple, hearty, and quintessentially Dutch.
steps: Boil potatoes and kale in the same pot (kale on top) for 20 mins.
Place sausage on top to steam for the last 10 mins.
Remove sausage. Drain water.
Mash potatoes and kale with milk and butter.
Stir in crispy bacon bits.
Serve with sliced sausage and a well of gravy in the center.

drink.description: A Dutch bar tradition: an ice-cold tulip glass of genever paired with a small beer—sip the genever first, then chase with beer.
ingredients: 1 1/2 oz jonge genever, very cold (45 ml)
steps: Chill the genever glass (a small tulip) and the beer glass.
Pour genever to the brim of the tulip glass (so full you shouldn’t lift it at first).
Take the first sip by bending down to the glass.
Then drink the beer alongside it, alternating as you like.
Serve immediately while both are cold.

NOR.description: Mutton in Cabbage. Norway's national dish is deceptively simple: layers of mutton and cabbage, peppercorns, and water, steamed until tender. It is celebrated every autumn with its own national day.
ingredients: 3 lb lamb shoulder (bone-in), cut into large chunks (1.4 kg)
1 large green cabbage, cut into wedges (about 2 lb / 900 g)
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
2 tbsp all-purpose flour (for thickening, optional but common)
2 cups water (480 ml), plus more if needed
steps: In a heavy pot, layer lamb and cabbage wedges, sprinkling some salt, peppercorns, and a little flour between layers.
Pour in water; it should come about 1/3 of the way up the ingredients (add more if needed).
Bring to a gentle simmer, cover, and cook very low 2–2 1/2 hours until lamb is tender and cabbage is soft.
Taste broth and adjust salt.
Serve hot, traditionally with boiled potatoes on the side.

drink.description: Norwegian gløgg: mulled red wine steeped with spices and citrus, often finished with a splash of aquavit and served with raisins and almonds.
steps: In a pot, warm water and sugar with orange zest/peel and spices until sugar dissolves.
Add red wine and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
Add aquavit off heat if using.
Ladle into mugs and serve hot.

NPL.description: Nepal’s everyday national meal: lentil soup (dal) with rice (bhat) and a simple vegetable curry (tarkari). It’s practical, balanced, and endlessly variable from home to home.
ingredients: For dal: 1 cup (200 g) red lentils, rinsed
For bhat: 2 cups (400 g) basmati rice, rinsed
To finish: chopped cilantro, lime wedges
steps: Dal: simmer lentils with water, turmeric, and salt until soft, 15–20 minutes.
Tadka: heat oil/ghee, add cumin; when it sizzles add onion, garlic, and ginger; cook until golden. Add tomato and cook until jammy.
Stir tadka into dal and simmer 5 minutes. Adjust thickness with water and salt to taste.
Bhat: cook rice with water (rice cooker or covered pot) until tender; fluff.
Tarkari: heat oil, add cumin. Stir in coriander/curry powder. Add potatoes and cauliflower, toss to coat, add water, cover and simmer 12–15 minutes until tender. Salt to taste.
Serve rice with a ladle of dal and a scoop of tarkari; finish with cilantro and lime.

drink.dish: Masala Chiya (मसला चिया) — Nepali Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Nepal’s daily tea: black tea simmered with warming spices and milk, sweetened to taste.
ingredients: 2 tsp black tea leaves (or 2 tea bags)
steps: Simmer water with ginger, cardamom, and cinnamon 4–5 minutes.
Add tea and simmer 2 minutes.
Add milk and sugar and simmer 3–4 minutes. Strain and serve hot.

NZL.description: A Sunday roast tradition. Tender leg of lamb served with sweet potatoes (Kumara) and mint sauce.
ingredients: 2 lbs Kumara (Sweet Potato), peeled and chunked
Mint Sauce: Fresh mint, Sugar, Vinegar, Boiling water
steps: Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C).
Make small incisions in the lamb. Stuff with garlic slivers and rosemary.
Rub lamb with oil, salt, and pepper. Place in roasting pan.
Roast for 1 hour 30 mins (medium).
Add kumara chunks to the pan around the lamb for the last 45 minutes. Toss in the meat juices.
Rest meat for 20 mins before carving.
Mix chopped mint with sugar and boiling water, then add vinegar. Serve sauce with the lamb.

drink.description: A classic Australian/New Zealand mixed drink: bright citrus with a few dashes of aromatic bitters.
ingredients: 1 tbsp lime cordial (or 1/2 oz fresh lime juice + 1 tsp simple syrup)
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add lime cordial (or lime juice + simple syrup).
Top with lemonade and add bitters.
Stir gently and garnish with lime if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: Zest of 4 limes (use a microplane; avoid bitter white pith)
steps: Rub lime zest into sugar with your fingers until fragrant (this pulls out citrus oils).
Add lime juice and stir until sugar dissolves (or warm gently to dissolve faster, then cool).
Bottle and refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

OMN.description: Oman’s festival centerpiece: meat marinated with spices and aromatics and cooked slowly until it falls apart. Traditionally buried in a sand oven; at home, low-and-slow roasting gets you close.
ingredients: 2 tsp ground paprika or mild chili
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 cup (240 ml) water or stock (for roasting pan)
steps: Mix garlic, ginger, vinegar, oil, spices, and salt into a paste. Rub all over lamb. Cover and marinate 8–24 hours.
Heat oven to 300°F (150°C). Place lamb in a roasting pan; add water/stock to the pan.
Cover tightly with foil (or wrap lamb in parchment then foil). Roast 3 1/2–4 1/2 hours until very tender.
Uncover and roast 10–15 minutes to brown slightly.
Rest 15 minutes, then shred or slice. Serve with rice and salad.

drink.description: Oman’s aromatic coffee—light-bodied and spiced with cardamom and often saffron—served with dates as a ritual of welcome.
ingredients: 2 tbsp (10–12 g) lightly roasted ground coffee
steps: Bring water to a gentle boil. Add coffee and simmer 8–10 minutes.
Add cardamom, saffron (and cloves if using) and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Let settle, strain, and serve in small cups.

PAK.description: A rich, slow-cooked stew made with beef shank and marrow bones, thickened with flour. Traditionally eaten for breakfast.
ingredients: Nihari Masala: Fennel seeds, Dry Ginger, Cumin, Cloves, Cardamom, Cinnamon, Chili powder
Garnish: Ginger julienne, Green chilies, Cilantro, Lemon wedges
steps: Heat oil. Fry onions until golden. Add meat and sear well.
Add the Nihari spices and salt. Fry for a few minutes.
Add 6-8 cups of water. Cover and simmer on low heat for 4-6 hours until meat is falling off the bone.
Slowly stir in the dissolved flour to thicken the gravy.
Simmer for another 15 minutes.
Serve hot, topped generously with fresh ginger, chilies, and a squeeze of lemon. Best with Naan.

drink.description: Pakistani-style milk tea, typically strong and sweet.
steps: Bring milk to a gentle simmer.
Add tea and simmer 3–5 minutes.
Strain and sweeten.
Toast whole fennel seeds briefly and grind (if using whole).
Mix with remaining spices.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

PAN.description: Panama's soul in a bowl. This restorative chicken soup is famous for curing hangovers and bringing families together. Its distinct flavor comes from 'culantro' (a stronger cousin of cilantro) and the starchy creaminess of slow-cooked ñame (yam).
ingredients: 1 bunch Culantro (essential flavor, stronger than cilantro)
steps: Cut chicken into pieces. Season with garlic, oregano, and chopped culantro.
In a large pot, sear the chicken with onions.
Add water to cover. Bring to a boil.
Add the ñame chunks. Simmer until the chicken is soft and the ñame starts to dissolve (this thickens the soup naturally).
Adjust salt. The soup should be slightly thick and very aromatic.
Serve with white rice on the side (to mix in).

drink.description: A common way to enjoy Panama’s Seco Herrerano: mixed with milk/cream and sweetened to taste.
ingredients: 1–2 tsp sugar or condensed milk (to taste)
steps: Fill a glass with ice.
Add Seco and milk; sweeten to taste.
Stir well and serve.

PER.description: Peru's gift to the culinary world. Born from the Moche civilization who used fermented juice, and refined by the Spanish with limes, this dish 'cooks' the freshest raw fish in 'Leche de Tigre'—a spicy, citrusy marinade that is the essence of the Peruvian coast.
ingredients: 1 lb Fresh White Fish (Sea Bass, Flounder) - semi-firm
1 Aji Limo or Habanero chili, minced
steps: Cut fish into uniform 2cm cubes. Place in a cold glass bowl.
Rub a slice of chili around the bowl for aroma.
Add salt and toss fish. Let sit 1 minute.
Add the cold lime juice. Toss. Let sit for 2-3 minutes max (you want the center raw).
Add onions, cilantro, and chopped chili. Toss gently.
Serve immediately alongside a slice of boiled sweet potato (to balance acidity) and corn.

drink.description: A South American classic (claimed by Peru and Chile): pisco shaken with lime, simple syrup, egg white, and bitters.
steps: Add pisco, lime juice, simple syrup, and egg white to a shaker (no ice) and dry-shake 15 seconds.
Add ice and shake hard 15–20 seconds until very cold and frothy.
Double-strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass.
Dot the foam with bitters and serve immediately.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

PHL.description: The unofficial national dish. Chicken braised in vinegar, soy sauce, and garlic until tender and glazed.
steps: Combine chicken, soy sauce, and garlic in a pot. Marinate for 30 mins.
Add vinegar, bay leaves, and peppercorns. Bring to a boil. Do not stir (let vinegar cook off).
Lower heat, cover, and simmer for 30 mins.
Uncover. Simmer until sauce reduces and thickens.
Optional: Remove chicken and fry in oil to crisp the skin, then return to sauce.
Serve over white rice.

drink.description: A coconut spirit traditionally consumed as a shot or with citrus.
steps: Serve as a small pour.
Sip or take as a shot; chase with citrus if desired.

POL.description: The legendary 'Hunter's Stew' that dates back to medieval times. A hearty mix of sauerkraut, fresh cabbage, and various meats (sausage, pork, beef) that is traditionally cooked for days, getting better with each reheat.
steps: In a large pot, fry bacon and onion. Add pork cubes and brown.
Add fresh cabbage and a little water. Cook until soft.
Add sauerkraut, kielbasa, soaked mushrooms (and their liquid), and spices.
Pour in the wine. Cover and simmer on low heat for at least 2-3 hours (traditionally reheated over several days).
The stew should be thick and dark.
Serve with rye bread.

drink.description: A modern Polish favorite nicknamed “apple pie”: bison grass vodka mixed with cloudy apple juice and cinnamon.
ingredients: Garnish: cinnamon stick and/or apple slice
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Pour in Żubrówka.
Top with apple juice and stir gently.
Garnish with a cinnamon stick (and apple slice if you like).
Serve cold.

PRI.description: An Afro-Caribbean icon derived from the West African 'fufu'. Green plantains are fried, then aggressively mashed in a wooden pilón with garlic, olive oil, and crackling pork rinds (chicharron), creating a garlicky, savory mound that is Puerto Rico's unofficial anthem.
steps: Peel plantains and cut into 1-inch chunks.
Deep fry plantains until golden but not brown (cooked through).
In a pilon (wooden mortar), mash garlic and olive oil.
Add fried plantains and chicharron pieces. Mash everything together until combined.
Add a splash of broth to keep it moist.
Form into a tight half-dome shape.
Serve with shrimp in garlic sauce or chicken broth on the side.

drink.description: A Puerto Rican classic: rum, coconut, and pineapple blended into a creamy tropical cocktail.
steps: Add rum, pineapple juice, cream of coconut, and ice to a blender.
Blend until smooth and slushy.
Pour into a chilled glass and garnish if desired.
Note (quick cream of coconut): heat 1/2 cup coconut cream + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool.
Combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
Warm gently, stirring until sugar dissolves and mixture thickens slightly.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks. Shake before use.

PRK.description: North Korea’s most famous dish abroad: chewy buckwheat noodles in a clean, cold beef-and-dongchimi broth, topped with sliced beef, pear, and cucumber. Subtle on purpose—refreshing rather than spicy.
ingredients: For broth: 1 1/2 lb (680 g) beef brisket or shank
1 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
1 cup (240 ml) dongchimi brine (see preliminary steps) or mild pickle brine
For serving: 1 lb (450 g) naengmyeon buckwheat noodles
steps: Make dongchimi (see preliminary steps) at least 2–3 days ahead.
Simmer beef with water, salt, scallions, and garlic until tender, 1 1/2–2 hours. Remove beef; chill for slicing. Strain broth.
Season broth with dongchimi brine; chill until very cold (an hour in the freezer helps).
Cook noodles per package. Rinse under cold running water, then rub/agitate to remove starch; drain well.
Portion noodles into bowls, add cold broth, top with sliced beef, pear, cucumber, and egg. Serve with mustard and vinegar at the table.

ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) Korean radish (daikon), cut into 1-inch (2.5 cm) cubes
steps: Dissolve salt and sugar in water.
Add radish, garlic, ginger, scallions (and chili if using) to a clean jar; pour brine over to submerge.
Cover loosely and ferment at cool room temp 2–3 days until lightly tangy, then refrigerate.
Use the brine for naengmyeon; it continues to develop in the fridge.

drink.description: A warming, slightly bitter-sweet tea made by simmering ginseng and sweetening with honey—common across the Korean peninsula.
ingredients: 10–15 g dried ginseng slices (or 1 small fresh ginseng root, sliced)
steps: Simmer ginseng (and jujubes if using) in water 15–20 minutes.
Strain into cups and sweeten with honey to taste.

PRT.description: A tribute to Portugal's maritime history. Shredded salt cod (bacalhau) is sautéed with onions and shoestring potatoes, then bound together with creamy scrambled eggs. It is said there are 365 cod recipes in Portugal, but this is the favorite.
steps: Sauté onion in generous olive oil until translucent.
Add the shredded cod. Cook for 5 mins.
Add the shoestring potatoes to the pan. Toss to mix.
Lower heat. Pour in the beaten eggs. Stir constantly until eggs are just set but still creamy (do not make dry scrambled eggs).
Remove from heat immediately.
Garnish with black olives and parsley.

drink.description: Portugal’s easy aperitif: dry white port topped with tonic—citrusy, lightly sweet, and very refreshing.
ingredients: Garnish: lemon or orange wedge; optional rosemary sprig
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Pour in the white port.
Top with tonic water.
Stir gently and garnish with citrus (and rosemary if using).

PRY.description: The only 'solid soup' in the world. Legend says a 19th-century chef added too much corn flour to the President's soup, creating a bread instead. The President loved it, and this savory, cheesy, onion-laden cornbread became the national dish.
ingredients: 2 cups Corn Flour (Harina de Maíz - fine)
2 cups Queso Paraguay (or mild white cheese/Mozzarella)
steps: Boil onions in the fat/butter with a little water until soft. Let cool.
Beat eggs until frothy. Add milk, cheese, and the onion mixture.
Gradually fold in the corn flour. The batter should be thick but pourable.
Pour into a greased baking dish.
Bake at 400°F (200°C) for 30-40 minutes until golden brown and set.
Cut into squares and serve warm.

drink.description: Cold yerba mate traditionally sipped through a bombilla; this version is flavored with mint and citrus.
ingredients: Yerba mate (about 1/2 to 2/3 of the cup/gourd)
steps: Fill the guampa/gourd about 1/2–2/3 full with yerba mate.
Add mint (and a squeeze of lemon if using).
Insert the bombilla down the side to the bottom and keep it in place.
Pour in ice-cold water to wet the yerba, sip, and keep refilling with cold water as you drink.

PSE.dish: Musakhan (مسخّن) — Sumac Chicken on Taboon Bread
PSE.description: Often cited as Palestine’s national dish: chicken roasted with onions, olive oil, and sumac, piled onto flatbread so it drinks up the juices, then topped with toasted pine nuts.
ingredients: 1/2 cup (120 ml) extra-virgin olive oil, divided
1 1/2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Heat oven to 425°F (220°C). Toss chicken with 2 tbsp olive oil, salt, pepper, and allspice. Roast 35–45 minutes until cooked.
Meanwhile, cook onions in remaining olive oil over medium-low heat until very soft and golden, 25–35 minutes.
Stir sumac into onions and cook 2 minutes. Taste and adjust salt.
Toast pine nuts in a dry pan until golden.
Assemble: lay bread on a platter, spread onion-sumac mixture over, top with chicken, drizzle pan juices, and finish with pine nuts.

drink.dish: Qamar al-Din (قمر الدين) — Apricot Leather Drink
drink.description: A Ramadan favorite across the Levant: apricot leather dissolved into a thick, tangy-sweet drink scented with orange blossom water.
ingredients: 1 sheet (about 7–8 oz / 200–225 g) apricot leather (qamar al-din) (or make it; see preliminary steps)
steps: Tear apricot leather into pieces and soak in warm water 2–4 hours (or overnight) until very soft.
Blend until smooth. Sweeten to taste and stir in orange blossom water.
Chill and serve over ice.

ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) sugar (adjust to sweetness of fruit)
steps: Simmer apricots with a splash of water until very soft, 10–15 minutes.
Blend to a smooth puree; stir in sugar and lemon juice. Simmer 2–3 minutes to dissolve sugar.
Spread puree thinly (about 1/8 in / 3 mm) on parchment-lined baking sheets.
Dry in a 170°F (75°C) oven 3–5 hours (or until no longer sticky). Peel and store wrapped.

Puducherry.description: A unique fusion of French and Tamil cuisines. This curry uses local seafood and spices but is milder and creamier than typical South Indian curries, often using coconut milk and vinegar.
steps: Sauté fennel and curry leaves.
Add onion paste and tomato puree. Cook well.
Add prawns and cook briefly.
Stir in coconut milk and a splash of vinegar.
Simmer until prawns are pink and tender.

drink.description: A common, beloved café drink in Puducherry and across South India.
ingredients: 3 tbsp South Indian coffee-chicory blend (or dark ground coffee)
steps: Brew a strong decoction (filter preferred).
Add a few tablespoons decoction to a cup, top with hot milk and sugar.
Froth by pouring back and forth (optional).

QAT.description: Qatar’s classic one-pot rice: chicken simmered with warm spices and loomi, then rice cooked in the broth so each grain is perfumed and savory.
ingredients: 1 whole chicken (3–4 lb / 1.4–1.8 kg), cut up
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) basmati rice, rinsed and soaked 20 minutes, drained
4 1/2 cups (1.1 L) water (or enough to cover chicken and later measure stock)
steps: Sauté onion in oil until golden. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Stir in tomato paste and tomatoes; cook until thick.
Add chicken, loomi, whole spices, ground spices, salt, and water to cover. Simmer 35–45 minutes until chicken is cooked.
Remove chicken. Measure broth to 4 1/2 cups (1.1 L), adjusting with water or reduction. Taste and salt.
Add drained rice, bring to a gentle boil, cover and cook on low 15 minutes; rest 10 minutes.
Fluff rice and serve with chicken on top.

drink.dish: Karak Chai (كرك) — Qatari Spiced Milk Tea
drink.description: Qatar’s everyday favorite: strong black tea simmered with cardamom (often with saffron) and finished with milk.
ingredients: 2 tsp loose black tea (or 2 tea bags)
6 cardamom pods, crushed (or 1/2 tsp ground cardamom)
steps: Simmer water with tea and cardamom 3–5 minutes for a strong brew.
Add milk, sugar, and saffron if using. Simmer 5–8 minutes.
Strain and serve hot.

ROU.description: Cabbage rolls raised to an art form. Minced pork and rice are wrapped in sour fermented cabbage leaves, then slow-cooked for hours in tomato sauce and sauerkraut juice. They are the centerpiece of every Romanian holiday.
steps: Mix pork, rice, onion, and spices.
Roll mixture tightly into cabbage leaves.
Layer rolls in a pot with chopped cabbage and smoked meat.
Pour over tomato juice and water.
Simmer on low heat for 3 hours. Serve with polenta (Mămăligă) and sour cream.

drink.description: A Romanian winter warmer: țuică heated gently with sugar and spices. It should steam—never boil.
ingredients: 1 tbsp sugar or honey (15–20 g), to taste
steps: Combine țuică, sugar/honey, lemon peel, peppercorns (and cloves if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm over very low heat until steaming (do not boil).
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass and serve hot.

RUS.description: The heart of Siberia wrapped in dough. These dumplings were originally preserved by freezing them outdoors in the Siberian winter. The thin dough holds a juicy meat filling, traditionally served with sour cream and dill.
ingredients: For dough: 3 cups all-purpose flour (390 g), plus more for dusting
For dough: 3/4 cup warm water (180 ml), plus as needed
For filling: 1/2 lb ground beef (225 g)
For filling: 1/2 lb ground pork (225 g)
For filling: 1 small onion, very finely grated
For filling: 2 tbsp cold water (30 ml) (keeps filling juicy)
To serve: butter, sour cream, dill; optional vinegar or black pepper
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt. Add egg and water and knead 8–10 minutes until smooth; cover and rest 30 minutes.
Make filling: mix meats with grated onion, salt, pepper, and cold water until tacky.
Roll dough thin. Cut 2 1/2–3 inch rounds.
Add about 1 tsp filling to each round. Fold into a half-moon and pinch sealed, then bring ends together and pinch to form the classic shape.
Freeze on a tray if not cooking immediately (then bag once solid).
Boil in salted water or broth: add pelmeni and cook until they float, then 2–3 minutes more (about 5–7 minutes total).
Serve with butter and sour cream, plus dill and black pepper.

drink.description: Traditional kvass: toasted rye bread fermented into a lightly sweet, tangy, low-alcohol drink—served cold.
ingredients: 8 oz dark rye bread, sliced (225 g)
1/2 cup sugar (100 g), plus more to taste
1/4 tsp active dry yeast (optional, speeds fermentation)
Optional: 2 strips lemon peel or a few mint leaves
steps: Toast rye bread slices until very dark to build flavor (avoid turning to ash).
Pour boiling water over toasted bread in a heatproof bowl; cover and steep 6–12 hours.
Strain out bread and stir in sugar until dissolved.
Cool to lukewarm; add yeast (or use raisins for wild fermentation).
Ferment loosely covered at room temp 12–24 hours until lightly fizzy.
Strain, bottle, and refrigerate. Serve cold; open carefully.

SAU.description: The national dish of the Kingdom. Spiced rice and meat (chicken or lamb) cooked together, garnished with nuts and raisins.
ingredients: Kabsa Spice Mix: Cardamom, Cinnamon, Cloves, Black Lime powder, Nutmeg
steps: Sauté onions in a large pot. Add meat and brown.
Add tomato puree, spices, dried limes, and salt. Cook for 5 mins.
Add water to cover meat. Simmer until meat is tender.
Add the soaked rice to the pot (add more water if needed, 1 inch above rice).
Cover and cook on low heat until rice is fluffy and water absorbed.
Transfer to a large platter. Top with fried raisins and almonds.

drink.description: Lightly roasted coffee simmered with cardamom—served in small cups, often alongside dates.
ingredients: 3 tbsp lightly roasted ground Arabic coffee (or light-roast ground coffee)
1/2 tsp ground cardamom (or 4 lightly crushed cardamom pods)
steps: Bring water to a boil in a small pot.
Remove from heat, stir in coffee, and return to very low heat; simmer 8–10 minutes without letting it boil hard.
Add cardamom (and optional saffron/cloves) and steep 2 minutes off heat.
Pour carefully into a dallah or serving pot, leaving grounds behind, and serve in small cups.

ingredients: 1/2 tsp dried lime powder (loomi) (optional but traditional)
steps: Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

SGP.description: Poached chicken served with seasoned rice and chili sauce. Simple but relies on perfect execution.
ingredients: Chili Sauce: Fresh chilies, Garlic, Ginger, Lime juice, Chicken fat
steps: Stuff chicken with ginger and scallions. Poach in sub-boiling water for 40-50 mins. Plunge into ice water immediately (to stop cooking and create jelly skin).
Fry raw rice in chicken fat with minced garlic and ginger. Cook rice using the chicken poaching broth.
Rub cooked chicken with sesame oil. Chop into pieces.
Serve chicken with the savory rice, cucumber slices, and the chili dipping sauce.

drink.description: A famous Singapore cocktail built on gin, cherry, citrus, and bitters—fruity and long.
steps: Add all ingredients to a shaker filled with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled.
Strain into a tall glass with fresh ice (or serve up, if preferred).
Garnish with a pineapple wedge or cherry if desired.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

SLV.description: A pre-Hispanic tradition that has conquered the world. These thick, handmade corn tortillas are stuffed with quesillo cheese, beans, or chicharrón before being cooked. The art is in the 'palmear'—patting the dough so the filling stays inside while the outside crisps.
ingredients: Filling: Quesillo or Mozzarella cheese (finely shredded)
steps: Mix masa and water to form a soft, non-sticky dough. Keep covered.
Take a ball of dough. Indent the center to make a cup.
Fill with cheese, beans, and pork. Pinch the top closed to seal the filling inside.
Gently pat back and forth between hands to flatten into a thick disk (do not let filling burst).
Cook on a lightly oiled griddle until browned on both sides.
Serve hot with Curtido and tomato salsa.

drink.description: A Salvadoran horchata made with morro seeds and spices (distinct from Mexican rice horchata).
ingredients: 2 tbsp horchata mix (morro-based) or prepared horchata
steps: Mix horchata base with liquid until smooth.
Sweeten to taste.
Serve over ice.

ingredients: 2 tbsp cacao nibs (or unsweetened cocoa beans/chunks)
1 tsp coriander seeds (semillas de culantro) (optional but traditional)
steps: Toast each ingredient separately over medium-low heat until fragrant (be careful not to burn the rice). Cool completely.
Grind everything to a fine powder (spice grinder or high-powered blender).
Store in a clean, dry jar. Keeps 1–2 months in a cool pantry.
To make the drink: mix 2 tbsp powder with 8 oz cold water (or a 50/50 mix of water and milk), then strain if desired and sweeten to taste.
Toss cabbage, carrots, onion, oregano, and salt in a bowl.
Pack into a jar; add vinegar and water to cover.
Refrigerate at least 4 hours (better after 24–48 hours). Keeps 2 weeks.

SMR.description: Meaning 'Swallow's Nests', this Sammarinese classic features fresh pasta sheets rolled with ham, cheese, and béchamel, sliced into coils, and baked until golden and bubbling. It is a comforting, oven-baked pasta dish.
steps: Lay out pasta sheets. Spread with béchamel.
Layer ham and cheese slices.
Roll up the pasta like a jelly roll.
Slice into 2-inch rounds (nests).
Place cut-side up in a baking dish. Top with more béchamel and parmesan.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) until golden.

drink.description: San Marino’s ‘Doma’ is a local citrus liqueur. This home method follows the traditional citrus-peel infusion approach used across the region.
ingredients: Peel of 6 oranges + 2 lemons (avoid white pith)
steps: Put citrus peels in a large jar and pour in the spirit. Seal and infuse 7–10 days in a cool dark place, shaking daily.
Strain out the peels and discard.
Make syrup: warm water and sugar until dissolved; cool completely.
Combine infusion and syrup (start with all syrup; adjust sweetness next day if needed).
Bottle and rest 1–2 weeks for flavors to meld.
Serve well chilled from the freezer.

SRB.description: The 'Serbian Dream'. A rolled veal or pork cutlet stuffed with kajmak (clotted cream), breaded, and fried. It resembles a soldier's order and is named after the revolutionary Karađorđe.
ingredients: 4 boneless pork cutlets (or veal), pounded thin (about 1 1/2 lb total / 680 g)
4 tbsp kajmak (or thick cream cheese + a little butter) (60 g)
4 thin slices smoked ham (optional but common)
For breading: 1 1/2 cups fine breadcrumbs (120 g)
Oil for frying (or shallow pan-fry), plus optional butter for finishing
To serve: lemon wedges; optional tartar sauce
steps: Season pounded cutlets with salt and pepper.
Spread a line of kajmak down the center of each; add a slice of ham if using.
Roll tightly, tucking ends, to make a ‘log’. Chill 15 minutes to help set.
Dredge in flour, then egg, then breadcrumbs, pressing to adhere (double-bread if you want a thicker crust).
Fry in 350°F/175°C oil (or shallow fry) until deep golden and cooked through, 4–6 minutes depending on thickness.
Drain briefly on a rack. Serve hot with lemon.

drink.description: A Serbian winter drink: rakija gently heated with sugar/honey and pepper—served hot, never boiled.
ingredients: 6 oz rakija (plum or grape brandy) (180 ml)
1 tbsp honey or sugar (15–20 g), to taste
4 whole peppercorns (or a pinch of ground black pepper)
steps: Combine rakija, honey/sugar, pepper, lemon peel (and cinnamon if using) in a small saucepan.
Warm over very low heat until steaming (do not boil).
Taste and adjust sweetness.
Strain into a small heatproof glass and serve hot.

SUR.description: A unique fusion of Jewish and Creole cultures. Portuguese Jewish plantation owners replaced potatoes with the local Pomtayer root to make this oven casserole. Baked with chicken and citrus juices, it is the golden, crusty centerpiece of every Surinamese celebration.
steps: Season chicken with salt, pepper, and nutmeg. Fry in oil until brown. Remove chicken.
In the same oil, sauté onions and tomatoes to make a gravy. Add a little water.
Mix the grated Pomtayer with the citrus juices, sugar, and half the gravy. It should be a smooth paste.
Grease a baking dish. Layer half the Pom mixture. Place chicken on top. Cover with remaining Pom mixture.
Pour remaining gravy over the top.
Bake at 350°F (180°C) for 1.5 hours until golden brown and crusty.

drink.description: Suriname’s Borgoe rum is often enjoyed simply as a highball.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Borgoe rum (or another dark rum)
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add rum and top with cola.
Garnish with lime if desired.

SVK.description: Slovakia's national pride. Small, soft potato dumplings (halušky) are tossed with Bryndza (a pungent fermented sheep cheese) and topped with crispy smoked bacon fat. It is rich, tangy, and filling.
ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour (195 g), plus more as needed
6 oz bryndza (sheep cheese) (170 g) (sub: feta + a splash of milk)
2 tbsp bacon fat (from rendering) or butter (optional)
steps: Grate potatoes finely; squeeze out excess liquid.
Mix grated potato with flour and salt to make a thick, sticky batter (add flour a tablespoon at a time if too loose).
Bring a pot of salted water to a simmer.
Press batter through a spaetzle maker/colander or cut small pieces off a board into the water.
Cook until dumplings float, then 1–2 minutes more; drain.
Meanwhile render diced bacon until crisp; reserve some fat.
Toss hot dumplings with bryndza (and a spoonful of bacon fat if needed) until creamy; top with bacon and chives.

drink.description: A Slovak highball using borovička (juniper spirit), topped with tonic and citrus.
steps: Fill a highball with ice.
Add borovička.
Top with tonic water.
Stir gently and garnish with lime.

SVN.description: Slovenia's rolled dumplings. A thin dough is spread with a filling (savory cottage cheese or sweet walnut), rolled up, and boiled or baked. It is a versatile dish served as a side or dessert.
ingredients: For dough: 2 cups all-purpose flour (260 g)
For dough: 1/2 cup warm water (120 ml), plus as needed
For filling: 2 cups farmer cheese/cottage cheese, well-drained (450 g)
For filling: 2 tbsp sour cream (30 g)
For filling: 2 tbsp butter, melted (28 g)
For filling: salt to taste; optional chopped herbs
To finish: 3 tbsp butter (42 g) + toasted breadcrumbs (optional)
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt; add egg, oil, and water and knead until smooth. Cover and rest 30 minutes.
Mix filling: combine cheese, egg, sour cream, melted butter, and salt (add herbs if using).
Roll dough very thin into a rectangle. Spread filling evenly, leaving a border.
Roll up tightly (like a jelly roll) and wrap in a clean cloth or plastic wrap suitable for boiling.
Simmer gently in water 25–30 minutes (do not hard-boil).
Unwrap, slice, and drizzle with melted butter; optionally top with toasted breadcrumbs.

drink.description: A light spritz using Slovenian brandy with local white wine and sparkling water—served cold with citrus.
steps: Fill a wine glass with ice.
Add brandy and white wine.
Top with sparkling water and stir once gently.
Garnish with an orange slice and serve.

SWE.description: More than just furniture store food. These small, tender meatballs are a staple of Swedish home cooking. The secret is the blend of beef and pork, the use of allspice, and the essential accompaniment of tart lingonberry jam to cut the richness.
ingredients: 1/2 cup Breadcrumbs soaked in 1/2 cup Milk
Sauce: Butter, Flour, Beef Broth, Heavy Cream, Soy Sauce
steps: Mix meat, soaked breadcrumbs, onion, egg, salt, pepper, and allspice. Mix until smooth.
Roll into small balls (smaller than Italian meatballs).
Fry in butter until browned on all sides and cooked through. Remove.
Sauce: In the same pan, melt butter, whisk in flour. Add broth and cream. Simmer until thick.
Return meatballs to sauce.
Serve with mashed potatoes and lingonberry jam.

drink.description: Swedish glögg: mulled wine steeped with spices and citrus, served hot with raisins and blanched almonds.
ingredients: 1/2 cup port wine (120 ml) (optional but traditional in many versions)
Optional: 1/2 cup vodka or aquavit (120 ml)
steps: Warm water and sugar with orange zest/peel and spices until sugar dissolves.
Add red wine (and port if using) and heat gently until steaming (do not boil).
Cover and steep 20–30 minutes off heat.
Stir in raisins and almonds.
Add vodka/aquavit off heat if using.
Serve hot, including a spoonful of raisins/almonds in each mug.

SYR.dish: Kibbeh Bil Sanieh (كبة بالصينية) — Syrian Baked Kibbeh
SYR.description: A Levantine classic strongly associated with Syria: spiced ground meat and bulgur pressed into a tray with a savory filling and baked until crisp at the edges.
ingredients: For kibbeh shell: 2 cups (360 g) fine bulgur
1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
1 lb (450 g) ground lamb or beef
For baking: 3 tbsp (45 ml) olive oil or melted butter
steps: Soak bulgur in hot water 10 minutes; drain well and squeeze out excess water.
Mix bulgur with ground meat, grated onion, salt, allspice, and cinnamon until it comes together into a paste-like dough (pulse briefly in a food processor for a finer texture if desired).
Make filling: sauté onion in oil until golden, add meat and cook until browned. Stir in pine nuts, spices, and salt; cool.
Heat oven to 400°F (200°C). Oil a 9x13 in (23x33 cm) baking dish.
Press half the kibbeh mixture into the dish. Spread filling evenly. Top with remaining kibbeh, smoothing with wet hands.
Score into diamonds. Drizzle with olive oil/butter.
Bake 30–40 minutes until browned. Rest 10 minutes before serving.

drink.description: A tart-sweet tamarind drink common across the Levant, especially in warm weather and during Ramadan.
ingredients: 4 oz (115 g) tamarind pulp (seedless if possible)
1/2 cup (100 g) sugar, plus more to taste
steps: Soak tamarind pulp in 2 cups (475 ml) hot water 20 minutes, then mash well.
Strain through a fine sieve, pressing to extract liquid. Discard fibers/seeds.
Stir in remaining 4 cups (950 ml) cold water and sugar until dissolved. Add lemon if using.
Chill and serve over ice.

TCA.description: The pride of the Caicos banks. The Queen Conch is so vital here it's on the flag. 'Cracked' refers to the method of pounding the tough meat until tender, before breading and frying it into a golden delicacy that rivals any calamari.
steps: Pound the conch meat with a mallet until very thin and tender (crucial).
Dip in egg wash (egg + milk).
Dredge in seasoned flour.
Deep fry at 375°F (190°C) for 2-3 minutes until golden. Do not overcook.
Serve with tartar sauce and lemon wedges.

drink.description: Turks & Caicos’ local Bambarra rum works perfectly in a simple punch build.
ingredients: 2 oz (60 ml) Bambarra rum (or another Caribbean rum)
1 tsp sugar (or 1/2 oz / 15 ml simple syrup)
steps: Shake all ingredients with ice until cold.
Strain over fresh ice in a tall glass.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

TCD.description: A Chadian staple: a firm millet (or sorghum) boule served with a savory okra-tomato sauce.
ingredients: 2 medium tomatoes, chopped (or 1 (14 oz) can diced tomatoes)
1 tsp kosher salt (plus more to taste)
steps: Make the sauce: heat oil in a pot. Sauté onion until soft. Add garlic 30 seconds.
Add okra, tomatoes, water/stock, salt, pepper, and chile (if using). Simmer 15–20 minutes until okra is tender and sauce thickens. Keep warm.
Make the boule: bring 4 cups water and salt to a boil in a heavy pot.
Reduce heat to low. Whisk in millet flour gradually until thick. Switch to a sturdy spoon and stir vigorously 5 minutes.
Cover and cook on very low 10 minutes, stirring every couple of minutes, until smooth and elastic.
Shape boule into balls with a wet spoon. Serve with okra sauce.

drink.description: A tart hibiscus drink popular in Chad and the Sahel, served hot or iced.
steps: Bring water to a boil with hibiscus and (if using) cinnamon and ginger. Boil 2 minutes, then turn off heat.
Cover and steep 15–20 minutes.
Strain, sweeten, and serve hot, or chill and serve over ice.

THA.description: A balance of sweet, sour, and salty. Essential street food.
ingredients: Sauce: 3 tbsp Tamarind paste, 3 tbsp Fish Sauce, 2 tbsp Palm Sugar
steps: Soak noodles in warm water for 30 mins (don't boil).
Mix sauce ingredients. Taste—it should be tangy and funky.
Sear tofu and shrimp in wok. Push aside.
Add noodles and a splash of water. Stir fry until soft.
Add the sauce. Stir to coat noodles.
Push noodles aside. Scramble eggs in the empty space.
Toss everything together with sprouts, chives, and peanuts.
Serve with lime wedge and chili flakes.

drink.description: Sweet, creamy, and strongly brewed tea poured over ice—an iconic Thai street drink.
ingredients: 2 tbsp Thai tea mix (or strong black tea)
1–2 tbsp evaporated milk or whole milk
steps: Bring water to a boil, add tea, and steep 4–5 minutes.
Strain and cool slightly.
Stir in condensed milk; adjust sweetness.
Fill a glass with ice and pour tea over.
Drizzle evaporated milk (or whole milk) on top and serve.
Soak tamarind pulp in hot water 15–20 minutes.
Mash thoroughly, then press through a sieve to remove fibers/seeds.
Use immediately or refrigerate up to 1 week.

TJK.description: Tajikistan’s beloved pilaf: rice steamed over a rich ‘zirvak’ base of browned meat, onions, and carrots—so culturally central it’s recognized on UNESCO’s Intangible Cultural Heritage list.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) lamb or beef, cut into chunks
4 large carrots, cut into matchsticks (about 6 cups / 600 g)
2 tbsp whole cumin seeds (zira), lightly crushed
1 tbsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
3 cups (600 g) long-grain rice, rinsed until water runs mostly clear
1 whole head of garlic, outer papery skin removed
Hot water, as needed (about 5–6 cups / 1.2–1.4 L)
steps: Heat oil in a heavy pot. Add onions and fry until deep golden.
Add meat and brown well. Add carrots and cook 5 minutes.
Add cumin and salt. Pour in hot water to just cover. Simmer 30–45 minutes to make the zirvak.
Spread rinsed rice over the top (do not stir). Add enough hot water so it sits about 1 inch (2.5 cm) above the rice.
When water is mostly absorbed, push garlic head into the rice. Cover tightly and steam on very low heat 20–25 minutes.
Rest off heat 10 minutes, then gently fluff, bringing some carrots/meat through. Serve hot.

drink.description: A simple, homey drink across Central Asia: fruit (often dried) simmered in water and lightly sweetened, served chilled.
ingredients: 8 oz (225 g) mixed dried fruit (apricots, apples, raisins, prunes)
1/4–1/2 cup (50–100 g) sugar or honey, to taste
steps: Rinse dried fruit. Combine with water (and cinnamon/lemon if using) in a pot.
Bring to a boil, then simmer 15–20 minutes until fruit plumps and flavors the liquid.
Sweeten to taste. Cool, then chill.
Serve cold with some fruit in the glass if you like.

TKM.description: Often presented as Turkmenistan’s national dish: a hearty stuffed flatbread/pie filled with seasoned meat and vegetables, baked until browned.
ingredients: For dough: 4 cups (480 g) all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
3 tbsp (45 ml) melted butter or oil
For filling: 1 lb (450 g) ground lamb (or beef)
steps: Make dough: mix flour and salt, add water and melted butter/oil, knead until smooth. Rest covered 30 minutes.
Mix filling ingredients; add a splash of water so it’s moist but not soupy.
Heat oven to 450°F (230°C).
Divide dough into 4 balls. Roll each into a large thin round. Place filling on one half, leaving a border.
Fold over to a half-moon and crimp edges tightly. Poke a few small vents.
Bake on a hot baking sheet 18–25 minutes until browned and cooked through. Rest 5 minutes before slicing.

drink.description: A cooling dairy drink common in Turkmen cuisine: yogurt thinned with water and lightly salted, sometimes fizzy if lightly fermented.
steps: Whisk yogurt and water until smooth and frothy.
Season with salt (and mint if using). Serve very cold.

TLS.dish: Batar Da'an (Batar Da’an) — Corn, Mung Bean & Squash Stew
TLS.description: A comforting Timor-Leste staple: corn, beans, and squash simmered into a simple, nourishing stew that’s both everyday food and a symbol of resilience.
ingredients: 1/2 lb (225 g) dried mung beans, rinsed
1 lb (450 g) corn kernels (fresh or frozen)
2 lb (900 g) pumpkin or butternut squash, peeled and diced
2 tsp kosher salt, plus more to taste
steps: Simmer mung beans in 4 cups (950 ml) water until nearly tender, 25–35 minutes.
Add corn and squash and simmer 15–20 minutes until squash is tender.
In a skillet, sauté onions in oil until golden, add garlic 30 seconds, then scrape into the pot.
Season with salt and pepper. Add water as needed for a stew consistency. Serve hot.

drink.description: Timor-Leste is known for its coffee. Brew it strong and serve simply; many households sweeten it lightly.
steps: Brew coffee strong (pour-over, French press, or moka pot).
Sweeten to taste; add condensed milk if desired.
Serve hot.

TTO.description: The ultimate 'lime' (hangout) food. This one-pot wonder begins with 'browning'—caramelizing sugar in hot oil until nearly burnt—which gives the chicken and rice its signature nutty, sweet-savory depth. It's a melting pot of African, Indian, and colonial influences.
ingredients: Green Seasoning (blended herbs: culantro, scallion, garlic, thyme)
steps: Season chicken with Green Seasoning. Marinate.
Heat oil in a heavy pot. Add sugar. Let it melt and bubble until dark frothy brown (burnt sugar).
Immediately add chicken and stir to coat. Cook for 5 mins.
Add rice, peas, pumpkin, and coconut milk. Stir.
Cover and simmer until liquid is absorbed and rice is tender.
Serve with coleslaw and a slice of avocado.

drink.description: Trinidad and Tobago’s famed swizzle: rum, lime, and bitters churned with crushed ice until frosty.
steps: Fill a tall glass with crushed ice.
Add rum, lime juice, and simple syrup.
Swizzle (or stir vigorously) until the glass frosts.
Add bitters on top and serve with a straw.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.
Blend everything into a thick green paste, adding water as needed.
Refrigerate up to 1 week, or freeze in ice-cube portions.

TUR.description: From Bursa, Turkey. Doner meat served over bread with tomato sauce and butter.
ingredients: 1 lb Lamb/Beef Doner slices (or thinly sliced roast lamb)
steps: Cut pide bread into cubes. Toast lightly in oven.
Heat the meat in a pan.
Prepare a simple tomato sauce with butter, tomato paste, and water.
Brown the sheep's butter in a small pan until nutty.
Assembly: Layer the bread cubes on a plate. Top generously with meat.
Pour hot tomato sauce over the meat.
Drizzle the sizzling browned butter over everything.
Serve with a dollop of cold yogurt on the side.

drink.description: Strong black tea served in small tulip-shaped glasses.
steps: Brew strong tea (often via a two-pot çaydanlık method).
Dilute with hot water to taste and serve.

TWN.dish: Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup (紅燒牛肉麵)
TWN.description: Taiwan’s most iconic bowl: beef shank braised with doubanjiang, aromatics, and warm spices into a deep red broth, served with wheat noodles and pickled mustard greens.
ingredients: 2 lb (900 g) beef shank or brisket, cut into large chunks
1/4 cup (60 ml) Shaoxing wine (or dry sherry)
2 tbsp (25 g) rock sugar or brown sugar
1 lb (450 g) fresh or dried wheat noodles
To serve: blanched bok choy, chili oil
steps: Blanch beef: cover beef with cold water, bring to a boil 3 minutes, drain and rinse.
Heat oil in a pot. Fry doubanjiang 1 minute. Add garlic, ginger, and scallions; cook until fragrant.
Add beef, soy sauce, wine, sugar, water/stock, and spices. Bring to a boil, then simmer 1 1/2–2 hours until tender.
Remove beef to slice. Strain broth if you want it clean; return to pot and adjust seasoning.
Cook noodles per package. Divide noodles into bowls, ladle broth, add sliced beef, bok choy, and pickled mustard greens.

preliminary_steps.item: Quick Pickled Mustard Greens (酸菜 quick)
ingredients: 3 cups (250 g) mustard greens or napa cabbage, shredded
steps: Toss greens with salt and sugar; let sit 15 minutes, then squeeze out excess liquid.
Bring vinegar and water to a simmer, then cool slightly.
Pack greens in a jar and pour over brine. Chill at least 1 hour (better overnight).

drink.description: Taiwan’s most famous drink: black tea with milk and chewy tapioca pearls, usually sweetened and served over ice.
ingredients: 2 cups (475 ml) strongly brewed black tea, cooled
2–3 tbsp sugar or brown sugar syrup (see preliminary steps)
1 cup cooked tapioca pearls (see preliminary steps)
steps: Stir sweetener into the cooled tea, then stir in milk.
Fill a tall glass with ice and add cooked tapioca pearls.
Pour in milk tea and serve with a wide straw.

ingredients: 1/2 cup (85 g) dried black tapioca pearls
steps: Bring water to a rolling boil. Add pearls and stir so they don’t stick.
Boil 20–30 minutes (check package), until centers are no longer chalky.
Turn off heat, cover, and rest 10 minutes. Drain and rinse briefly.
Toss warm pearls with brown sugar to lightly glaze.
Simmer sugar and water 2–3 minutes until slightly thickened.
Cool; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Taiwan.description: The national dish of Taiwan. Braised beef shank, tendon, and chewy noodles swim in a dark, aromatic broth infused with soy sauce, chili bean paste, and Chinese herbs. It is often served with pickled mustard greens.
ingredients: Broth: Star Anise, Cinnamon, Fennel, Ginger, Garlic, Doubanjiang (Bean Paste), Soy Sauce, Rock Sugar
steps: Blanch beef. Sauté aromatics and bean paste.
Add beef, soy sauce, sugar, and water. Simmer for 2-3 hours until tender.
Cook noodles separately.
Assemble: Noodles, Beef, Broth, blanched Bok Choy.
Top generously with pickled mustard greens and scallions.

drink.description: Taiwan’s most famous modern drink: sweet milk tea with chewy tapioca pearls (boba).
ingredients: 2 tbsp brown sugar (for syrup) + 2 tbsp water
1 cup (240 ml) strong black tea, chilled
steps: Boil tapioca pearls in water per package directions until chewy; drain.
Make brown sugar syrup: simmer brown sugar + water 1–2 minutes until glossy.
Toss warm pearls in syrup and let sit 5 minutes.
Add pearls to a glass, add ice, then pour in tea and milk; stir and serve with a wide straw.
Warm brown sugar and water in a saucepan, stirring until dissolved.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 1 medium napa cabbage (about 2 lbs), cut into large pieces
2 tbsp kosher salt (about 2% by weight; adjust for cabbage size)
Optional: 2–3 slices ginger or a few Sichuan peppercorns
steps: Toss cabbage with salt and massage 2–3 minutes until it starts releasing liquid.
Pack tightly into a clean jar or crock. Add enough water to submerge if needed (a light brine).
Weight cabbage under the brine (use a fermentation weight or a small bag filled with brine).
Ferment at cool room temperature 3–7 days until pleasantly sour. Skim any surface foam as needed.
Refrigerate when it tastes right. Rinse before cooking if very salty/sour.

preliminary_steps.item: Pixian Doubanjiang (Fermented Chili Bean Paste) – sourcing note
ingredients: Authentic option: Pixian doubanjiang (recommended to purchase)
steps: Pixian doubanjiang is a long-fermented chili broad-bean paste; the traditional process takes months.
For authenticity, purchase a reputable Pixian doubanjiang and use as directed in the recipe.
If the recipe calls for cooking it, stir-fry it briefly in oil to ‘bloom’ the flavor before adding liquids.

UKR.description: The crimson soul of Ukraine. This sour beet soup is not just a dish but a cultural touchstone. Packed with vegetables and often meat, its signature deep red color and sweet-sour balance come from beets and fermented beet sour (kvass) or vinegar.
ingredients: 1 lb Beef shank or ribs (for broth)
1 tbsp Vinegar or Lemon juice (to keep color)
steps: Make broth: Boil beef in water for 1.5 hours. Skim foam.
Add potatoes and cabbage to broth. Cook 15 mins.
Sauté onion and carrot in oil. Add grated beets, vinegar, and tomato paste. Simmer for 10 mins.
Add the beet mixture to the soup pot. Simmer another 10 mins.
Add garlic and fresh dill. Turn off heat. Let sit for 20 mins (flavors meld).
Serve with a dollop of sour cream and Pampushky (garlic bread).

drink.description: A traditional Ukrainian-style pepper vodka: horilka infused with hot peppers and honey for a warm, aromatic bite.
steps: Combine horilka/vodka, chili peppers, honey, and optional peppercorns/lemon peel in a clean jar.
Seal and shake until honey dissolves.
Infuse 24–72 hours, tasting daily until heat level is right.
Strain out peppers (and spices) and bottle.
Rest at least 1 day before serving; serve chilled in small glasses.

URY.description: The 'Little Goat' that contains no goat. Created in 1946 for a tourist who asked for goat meat, a quick-thinking chef threw a beef tenderloin on a bun and piled it high with ham, cheese, bacon, and egg. It became a national obsession and a monument to excess.
steps: Season beef and sear quickly on a hot griddle.
Place ham and cheese on top of the steak to melt.
Toast the bun. Spread generous mayonnaise.
Assemble: Bun, lettuce, tomato, steak with ham/cheese, bacon, egg, top bun.
Serve with French fries and Russian salad.

drink.description: Uruguay is strongly associated with mate (often prepared very strong).
steps: Prepare and sip as traditional mate, refilling with hot water repeatedly.

USA.description: The undisputed icon of American cuisine. Evolving from the steak tartare of Hamburg, Germany, it became an American phenomenon in the 20th century. A perfectly seared beef patty, melted American cheese, and a soft bun represent the ultimate comfort food exported to the globe.
steps: Divide beef into 4 loose balls. Do not overwork the meat.
Heat a cast-iron skillet or grill to high heat.
Place beef balls on hot surface and smash flat with a spatula. Season generously with salt and pepper.
Cook for 2-3 mins until a deep crust forms. Flip.
Place cheese on patties. Cook 1 min until cheese melts.
Toast the buns on the grill.
Assemble: Bun, sauce, lettuce, tomato, patty, onion, pickles, top bun.

Alabama.description: A Northern Alabama icon invented by Big Bob Gibson in 1925. Unlike the tomato-based sauces of the rest of the country, this tangy, peppery, mayonnaise-based sauce keeps smoked chicken incredibly moist.
ingredients: Sauce: 2 cups Mayonnaise, 1 cup Apple Cider Vinegar
steps: Season chicken with salt and pepper. Smoke at 250°F (120°C) with hickory wood until internal temp reaches 160°F.
Whisk sauce ingredients together. It should be thin and tangy.
Dunk the hot chicken completely into the white sauce (or brush heavily).
Return to grill for 10 mins to set the sauce.
Serve with extra white sauce on the side.

drink.description: A classic sweet highball associated with Alabama.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add Southern Comfort, amaretto, and sloe gin.
Top with orange juice and stir gently.
Garnish if desired.

Alaska.description: The taste of the last frontier. Fresh Copper River salmon is grilled on cedar planks and glazed with a reduction of wild Alaskan berries (blueberries, cranberries, or salmonberries), marrying the ocean and the tundra.
ingredients: 1 side Wild Alaskan Salmon (Sockeye or King)
steps: Simmer berries, honey, and vinegar until berries burst and sauce thickens into a glaze. Strain if desired.
Place salmon on the soaked cedar plank. Season with salt and pepper.
Grill covered on medium-high heat.
Brush generously with berry glaze during the last 5 minutes of cooking.
Serve immediately on the plank.

drink.description: A layered shot popular in Alaska.
steps: Pour coffee liqueur into a shot glass.
Carefully layer Irish cream over the back of a spoon.
Layer whisky on top.
Serve as a layered shot.

Arizona.description: The accidental invention of Tucson. Legend says a burrito was dropped into a deep fryer, and the cook exclaimed 'Chimichanga!' (thingamajig) instead of a curse word. It is now the crispy, golden soul of Sonoran-Mexican cuisine.
ingredients: Filling: 1 lb Shredded Beef (Machaca) or Chicken
steps: Warm tortillas. Place meat, beans, and cheese in the center.
Fold in sides and roll tightly (secure with toothpick if needed).
Deep fry at 375°F (190°C) until golden brown and crispy.
Drain and serve smothered in cheese and sauce ('Enchilada style') or plain with dips.

drink.description: A tequila-and-citrus cocktail with a sunrise gradient.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add tequila and orange juice; stir.
Slowly pour grenadine down the side; it will sink and create the gradient.
Garnish if desired.
Note (quick grenadine): simmer equal parts pomegranate juice + sugar until dissolved; cool before using.
Warm pomegranate juice and sugar in a saucepan over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (avoid a hard boil).
Cool; stir in orange blossom water if using.
Bottle; add vodka if using for shelf-life.
Refrigerate and use within 3–4 weeks (longer if vodka added).

Arkansas.description: The staple of the Delta. Farm-raised catfish is coated in a seasoned cornmeal crust and fried until it shatters, traditionally served with hushpuppies and pickled green tomatoes.
steps: Soak fillets in buttermilk for 30 mins.
Mix cornmeal, flour, and spices in a shallow dish.
Dredge fish in the mixture, pressing to adhere.
Fry in hot oil (350°F) for 5-7 minutes until floating and golden.
Serve hot with lemon and tartar sauce.

drink.description: A creamy, coffee-forward cocktail associated with Arkansas.
steps: Fill a shaker with ice.
Add vodka, rum, amaretto, coffee liqueur, and cream.
Shake well and strain into an ice-filled rocks glass.
Mix all spices thoroughly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

California.description: San Francisco's answer to Bouillabaisse. Created by Italian fishermen in North Beach who chipped in ('chip in' -> cioppino) their catch of the day. It is a tomato-rich seafood stew loaded with Dungeness crab, clams, shrimp, and scallops.
ingredients: Broth: 1 can Crushed Tomatoes, 2 cups Fish Stock, 1 cup Red Wine, Onion, Garlic, Fennel, Basil
steps: Sauté onions, garlic, and herbs. Add wine, tomatoes, and stock. Simmer 30 mins.
Add clams and mussels. Cover and cook 5 mins.
Add crab, fish, and shrimp. Simmer gently until seafood is cooked through.
Serve in large bowls with sourdough bread to sop up the broth.

drink.description: A tiki classic (rum, citrus, and almond) often associated with California’s tiki culture.
steps: Add rum, lime juice, curaçao, orgeat, and simple syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake briefly and pour into a glass filled with crushed ice.
Garnish if desired.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Note (quick orgeat): heat 1/2 cup almond milk + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool, then add a few drops of orange flower water if you have it.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

ingredients: 1 1/2 cups unsweetened almond milk (or strained almond infusion)
1/2 tsp orange blossom water (or 1 tsp, to taste)
steps: Warm almond milk and sugar over medium heat, stirring until dissolved (do not boil hard).
Cool, then stir in orange blossom water (and rose water if using).
Bottle; add vodka if using.
Refrigerate and use within 2–3 weeks (longer if vodka added).

Colorado.description: The lifeblood of the Rockies. Not just a sauce, but a stew-like gravy made with Pueblo chiles, pork, and tomatoes. It is eaten in a bowl with tortillas or smothered over literally everything.
ingredients: 2 cups Roasted Green Chiles (Pueblo or Hatch), chopped
Chicken Stock, Cumin, Oregano, Flour (to thicken)
steps: Brown pork cubes in oil. Remove.
Sauté onion and garlic. Stir in flour to make a roux.
Add stock, tomatoes, spices, and pork.
Simmer for 1-2 hours until pork is tender.
Stir in the roasted green chiles. Simmer another 30 mins.
Serve with warm flour tortillas.

drink.description: A White Russian-style drink topped with cola.
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Add vodka and coffee liqueur.
Add cream and stir gently.
Top with a splash of cola.

Connecticut.description: The 'Apizza' legend of Frank Pepe. A thin, coal-fired crust topped simply with olive oil, oregano, garlic, grated pecorino, and fresh littleneck clams. No mozzarella, no tomato sauce—just pure briny perfection.
ingredients: Pizza Dough (high gluten flour, cold fermented)
1 dozen Littleneck Clams (shucked, chopped, keep juice)
steps: Stretch dough into a thin, oblong shape.
Brush heavily with olive oil.
Scatter garlic, oregano, and clams (with a little juice) over the dough.
Sprinkle generously with Pecorino.
Bake at max oven temp (ideally 500°F+ on a stone) until charred and bubbly.
Slice into irregular strips.

drink.description: A rum-and-ginger beer highball.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add ginger beer and lime juice (if using).
Float dark rum on top.
Garnish with lime.
Note: ginger beer is usually purchased; in a pinch, use ginger ale (sweeter) or top with club soda and add a little ginger syrup.

Delaware.description: The culinary signature of the Delmarva Peninsula. Unlike fluffy Southern dumplings, these are large, flat, rectangular noodles made simply of flour and water, boiled directly in a rich, savory chicken broth until 'slippery' and tender.
steps: Boil chicken with celery, onion, and seasoning until tender. Remove chicken, shred meat, and return to pot.
Make dough: Mix flour, salt, and water until stiff. Roll out very thin on a floured surface.
Cut dough into 2-inch squares or rectangles.
Bring broth to a rolling boil. Drop dumplings in one by one.
Reduce heat and simmer until dumplings are tender and broth has thickened from the flour.
Serve hot.

drink.description: A bright citrus cocktail popular on the Mid-Atlantic coast.
steps: Fill a pint glass with ice.
Add vodka, triple sec, and orange juice; stir.
Top with lemon-lime soda.
Garnish with an orange wedge.
Mix thoroughly and crush rosemary slightly so it distributes evenly.
Store airtight up to 3 months.

Florida.description: The sandwich that built Tampa and Miami. Roast pork, sweet ham, Swiss cheese, pickles, and mustard are pressed between Cuban bread until the cheese melts and the crust cracks like eggshells.
steps: Slice bread open. Spread mustard on both sides.
Layer: Ham, Pork, Cheese, Pickles.
Close sandwich. Butter the outside crust.
Press in a plancha (sandwich press) until flat, hot, and crispy (cheese must melt).
Slice diagonally.

drink.description: A fruity vodka cocktail commonly associated with Florida.
steps: Fill a highball glass with ice.
Add vodka and peach schnapps.
Add cranberry and orange juice; stir.
Garnish if desired.

Georgia.description: Once a humble fisherman's breakfast, now a Southern delicacy. Plump wild Georgia shrimp are sautéed with bacon and served over creamy, stone-ground grits.
steps: Simmer grits in liquid until creamy (45 mins). Stir in butter and cheese.
Fry bacon until crisp. Remove, keep fat.
Sauté shrimp and garlic in bacon fat. Add a splash of lemon and stock to make a gravy.
Spoon grits into bowls. Top with shrimp, gravy, bacon bits, and scallions.

drink.description: A Southern Comfort cocktail commonly linked with Georgia.
steps: Fill a rocks glass with ice.
Add Southern Comfort, cranberry juice, and lime juice.
Stir and garnish.

Hawaii.description: The essence of the islands. 'Poke' means to slice or cut. Fresh raw yellowfin tuna is cubed and marinated in soy sauce, sesame oil, and seaweed. It is a dish that requires the highest quality fish.
ingredients: Inamona (Roasted Kukui nut) or Macadamia nuts
steps: Cut tuna into 3/4 inch cubes.
In a bowl, gently toss tuna with soy sauce, sesame oil, onions, and seaweed.
Sprinkle with crushed nuts and sesame seeds.
Serve immediately over warm rice or on its own.

drink.description: A tropical cocktail with blue curaçao and pineapple.
steps: Add rum, blue curaçao, pineapple juice, and cream of coconut to a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into an ice-filled glass.
Note (quick cream of coconut): heat 1/2 cup coconut cream + 1/2 cup sugar until dissolved; cool.
Combine coconut milk, sugar, and salt in a saucepan.
Warm gently, stirring until sugar dissolves and mixture thickens slightly.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks. Shake before use.

Idaho.description: Idaho's claim to fame (besides potatoes). Strips of steak are battered and deep-fried, invented at the Torch Lounge in Boise. They are the ultimate bar food, best dipped in cocktail sauce.
ingredients: 1 lb Top Sirloin, cut into finger-sized strips
steps: Marinate steak strips in buttermilk and egg for 1 hour.
Season the flour with spices.
Dredge steak strips in flour.
Deep fry at 375°F (190°C) for 2-3 minutes until golden brown.
Serve with fry sauce or cocktail sauce.

drink.description: A whiskey sour accented with huckleberry (common in the Northwest).
ingredients: 3/4 oz huckleberry syrup (or huckleberry jam thinned with water)
steps: Add whiskey, lemon juice, and huckleberry syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake and strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice.
Garnish if desired.
Simmer berries and water 5–8 minutes until berries burst.
Strain (optional), return liquid to pan, add sugar and lemon juice, and simmer 2–3 minutes until slightly syrupy.
Cool and bottle; refrigerate up to 2 weeks.

Illinois.description: Chicago's casserole-like pizza. A buttery, high-walled crust is filled with layers of mozzarella cheese, meat (sausage/pepperoni), and topped with a chunky tomato sauce. It is eaten with a knife and fork.
ingredients: Deep Dish Dough (with cornmeal and butter)
1 lb Italian Sausage (raw, removed from casing)
steps: Press dough into a deep cake pan or cast iron skillet, pushing up the sides.
Layer sliced mozzarella directly on the dough (prevents sogginess).
Press a layer of raw sausage over the cheese.
Top with the chunky tomato sauce. Sprinkle with parmesan.
Bake at 425°F (220°C) for 30-40 minutes until crust is golden.

drink.description: A classic American whiskey cocktail.
steps: Add syrup and bitters to a rocks glass.
Add whiskey and ice; stir until chilled.
Express orange peel over the glass and drop in.
Note (simple syrup): stir equal parts sugar + hot water until dissolved; cool.
Combine sugar and water in a small saucepan.
Warm over medium heat, stirring, just until the sugar fully dissolves (do not boil for long).
Cool, then bottle and refrigerate up to 2–3 weeks.

Indiana.description: A sandwich that defies physics. A piece of pork loin is pounded until it is huge and thin, breaded, fried, and served on a bun that looks comically small in comparison.
steps: Pound pork chops between plastic wrap until very thin and wide (dinner plate size).
Dredge in flour, dip in egg wash, coat in crumbs.
Fry in oil until golden and crispy (about 3 mins per side).
Serve on a toasted bun with pickles and mustard. The meat should overhang the bun significantly.

drink.description: An Indiana-themed whiskey sour variation using apple cider and maple syrup.
steps: Add whiskey, apple cider, lemon juice, and maple syrup to a shaker with ice.
Shake hard until well chilled.
Strain into a rocks glass over fresh ice (or serve up in a coupe).
Garnish with an apple slice if desired.

Iowa.description: The 'Loose Meat' sandwich. Ground beef is steamed and seasoned rather than fried into a patty, served on a bun with mustard and pickles. It's a sloppy, savory classic from 1926.
steps: Brown the beef and onion in a skillet. Break it up into fine crumbles.
Add broth, mustard, Worcestershire, and sugar.
Simmer until liquid evaporates but meat is moist and steamed.
Scoop onto warm buns. Serve with pickles.

drink.description: A mule made the Iowa way with rye (often associated with Templeton Rye) and ginger beer.
steps: Fill a copper mug or highball with ice.
Add rye and lime juice, then top with ginger beer.
Stir briefly and garnish with a lime wedge.

Kansas.description: The heart of American BBQ. Pork ribs are dry-rubbed, smoked low and slow over hickory, and finished with a thick, sweet, molasses-based tomato BBQ sauce.
